questions.text: In case of endometriotic lesions, histology represents its?
questions.solution:
Positive estrogenic activity, or a hormonal environment, is often believed to aide the growth of the endometrial cells and contribute to the histopathology of endometriosis. 

Pathogenesis/Pathophysiology of Endometriosis.
 
  • Theory of retrograde menstruation (implantation theory or transplantation theory)-  most widely accepted theory.
  • This theory proposes that endometriosis results from endometrial cells that are transported via the fallopian tubes in backward menstrual flow, known as retrograde menstruation. The endometrial cells which enter the pelvic cavity can then attach
  • themselves to the pelvic structures and grow, developing into endometriotic lesions. 
  • Positive estrogenic activity aids in the growth of endometrial cells into endometriotic lesions. 




Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 235.

questions.text: In the first two months of pregnancy, what produces the hormones estrogen and progesterone?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Corpus luteum
 
  • hCG secretion maintains the corpus luteum for the first trimester of pregnancy. During this time the corpus luteum maintains the pregnant state by secreting estradiol and progesterone.
  • By the beginning of 2nd trimester, the placenta becomes competent to secrete enough estrogen and progesterone to sustain the pregnancy. hCG secretion tapers off and the corpus luteum becomes nonfunctional.
  • During the first 2 to 4 weeks or pregnancy, rising hCG levels maintain production of estradiol in the corpus luteum. Ovarian production of both progesterone and estrogens drops significantly by the 7th week of pregnancy.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 101, 176.

questions.text: The growth of granulosa cells prior to ovulation is dependent on:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. FSH
 
  • The major functions of granulosa cells include the production of sex steroids, as well as myriad growth factors thought to interact with the oocyte during its development.
  • The sex steroid production begins with follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary, stimulating granulosa cells to convert androgens (coming from the thecal cells) to estradiol by aromatase during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.
  • However, after ovulation the granulosa cells turn into granulosa lutein cells that produce progesterone.



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 352.

questions.text: Select the correct statement regarding 'multiple pregnancies':
questions.solution:
• The twin peak sign indicates the presence of a dichorionic-diamniotic twin gestation.
  • The twin peak represents the extension of placental villi into the potential space that is formed from the reflection of apposed amniotic and chorionic layers from each fetus.

 
  • Fetuses of same gender excludes dichorionicity – This is not true. Same-gender fetuses can still be dichorionic if they result from the splitting of a single zygote (monozygotic twins) or if they are dizygotic twins.
  • Thick separating membrane is a feature of monochorionic twins – Monochorionic twins share a chorion, and the separating membrane, if present, is typically thinner compared to dichorionic twins.
  • Chorionicity can be reliably detected only after 16 weeks of gestation – Chorionicity is best detected early, particularly in the first trimester (before 14 weeks)

questions.text: Which of the following factors does the WHO consider as the most important marker of male fertility?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Spermatocyte morphology
 

Sperm morphology, which assesses the shape and structure of sperm cells, is considered a key indicator of male fertility. Abnormal morphology can impair a sperm’s ability to swim effectively and penetrate the egg, thus affecting fertilization potential. While sperm motility and count are also significant, morphology is often highlighted as a primary marker because it reflects the quality of the sperm more directly in terms of fertilization capability.

Other options:

  1. Spermatocyte count: Important but not as significant as morphology in assessing sperm quality.
  2. Spermatocyte motility: While essential, it is generally secondary to morphology in overall fertility assessments.
  3. Semen volume: This affects total sperm output but does not directly indicate sperm quality or fertility.

WHO semen analysis criteria:





Reference: Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility, 8th edition, Page no 1270.

questions.text: What is the effect of twin gestation if division occurs on the seventh day?
questions.solution:
• Option 2, Diamniotic, monochorionic, is the correct answer if division of the zygote occurs on the seventh day after fertilization.
  • When a single zygote divides into two embryos, the resulting twins can either share a chorion (the outermost fetal membrane) and/or an amniotic sac (the innermost fetal membrane).
  • The chorion can either be shared (monochorionic) or separate (dichorionic), while the amniotic sac can either be shared (monoamniotic) or separate (diamniotic).
  • Division of the zygote on the seventh day results in two separate embryos that each have their own amniotic sac, but share a chorion. This is because the chorion starts to form on the fifth day after fertilization and is usually complete by the seventh day.
  • Therefore, the twins are diamniotic, meaning they each have their own amniotic sac, but monochorionic, meaning they share a chorion.
  • It is important to note that the timing of division is critical in determining the type of twinning that occurs. If division occurs earlier or later than the seventh day, different types of twinning can result, such as dichorionic, diamniotic twins if division occurs before the third day, or monochorionic, monoamniotic twins if division occurs after the eighth day.


Sustained/marked rise in Estrogen
Students should remember the division and corresponding days for twin gestation.

questions.text: A 16-year old female with primary amenorrhea has cyclical abdominal pain every month. On physical examination she has a suprapubic bulge. P/R examination reveals swelling along the whole length of vagina. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The young female with primary amenorrhea experiences cyclic pain every month. The presence of a suprapubic bulge raises suspicion of cryptomenorrhea, which is confirmed by a per-rectal examination which reveals hematocolpos.

Causes of cryptomenorrhea include:
  1. Intact/ imperforate hymen: seen as bluish bulging membrane.
  2. Transverse vaginal septum: On examination, the vagina may appear shortened and the cervix may not be identifiable. Secondary sexual characteristics appear normal. The diagnosis can be confirmed with ultrasound or MRI. (option C)
  3. Vaginal agenesis: Vaginal introitus is not visible. On examination, the hymenal ring is normal, proximal to which only a vaginal dimple or small pouch is found. (option B)
  4. Agenesis of the lower vagina: A vaginal dimple may be noted on external inspection. Since these girls have normal cyclic pituitary-ovarian-endometrial function at menarche, the upper vagina will distend with blood products and secretions, which can be palpated as a mass on recto abdominal examination. Ultrasound and MRI may be used to help define the presence of a uterus, cervix, and upper vagina.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 418, 421.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy ?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy is gestational thrombocytopenia. This may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption in pregnancy.
Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. Hematological changes in pregnancy
include:
• All clotting factors are increased (except factor 11,13) and fibrinogen levels are also increased.
• Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected.
• The viscosity of blood doesn't increase since plasma volume increases more in comparison to red cell volume, it merely decreases whole blood viscosity.
• Anticoagulants Protein C, Protein S and antithrombin decrease during pregnancy.
• Fibrinolytic activity remains depressed till about 15 minutes after pregnancy. Ref - Williams obstetrics 26th edition Page 61-62

questions.text: Which of the following peaks marked in the image below is responsible for ovulation ?
questions.solution:
The menstrual cycle consists of distinct phases regulated by coordinated hormonal changes that orchestrate ovarian follicle development, ovulation, and uterine lining preparation for pregnancy.

1. Follicular Phase (Days 0–14)

  • This phase begins with the maturation of a primordial follicle into a dominant Graafian follicle, while other follicles undergo atresia.

  • Hormonal changes include a gradual rise in Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary.

  • Estradiol secretion by the developing follicle increases steadily, stimulating proliferation of the endometrial lining.

  • Initially, rising estradiol exerts negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary, suppressing FSH and LH to prevent multiple follicle maturation.

  • Progesterone remains low during this phase.

2. Ovulation (Around Day 14)

  • Ovulation typically occurs about 14 days before the start of the next menses, making the exact day variable with overall cycle length.

  • A critical threshold of rising estradiol induces a positive feedback loop on the hypothalamus and pituitary, causing a sudden LH surge.

  • This surge triggers follicular rupture and release of the ovum.

  • Cervical mucus changes, becoming more copious, clear, and less viscous, which facilitates sperm motility and fertilization.

3. Luteal Phase (Days 14–28)

  • Following ovulation, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which secretes high levels of progesterone along with some estradiol.

  • Progesterone promotes a secretory transformation of the endometrium, increasing glandular activity and vascularization to support potential embryo implantation.

  • The basal body temperature rises slightly due to progesterone’s thermogenic effect, which can be tracked for fertility awareness.

  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum involutes, resulting in a sharp decline in progesterone and estradiol levels, initiating endometrial breakdown.

4. Menstruation (Days 0–4 of the next cycle)

  • The withdrawal of progesterone and estradiol causes vasoconstriction of endometrial vessels and breakdown of the functional layer.

  • Menstrual bleeding ensues as the uterus sheds the lining, marking the start of a new cycle.

The menstrual cycle’s phases represent a finely tuned hormonal interplay regulating ovulation and uterine readiness for pregnancy. A thorough understanding of these phases is vital for managing reproductive health, fertility planning, and diagnosing menstrual disorders.


Reference: Williams gynaecology 3rd edition page no 347

questions.text: Which tests can be performed safely to determine the earliest stage of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The safest and most effective test to determine the earliest stage of pregnancy is: Option 3. Serum β-hCG levels
 

  • Serum β-hCG levels: This is a reliable and early marker for detecting pregnancy. Serum β-hCG can typically detect pregnancy as early as 8–11 days post-conception, even before a missed period.
  • USG for fetal cardiac activity (Option 1): While a transvaginal ultrasound can detect an early pregnancy sac around 4–5 weeks gestation, fetal cardiac activity usually isn’t visible until around 6–7 weeks.
  • Fetal cardiac Doppler study (Option 2): This is typically not used in early pregnancy detection, as it’s meant to assess fetal cardiac function, which becomes relevant at later stages.
  • MRI pelvis (Option 4): MRI is rarely used in early pregnancy due to the lack of necessity and higher cost; it’s also generally reserved for specific clinical indications later in pregnancy.

So, serum β-hCG levels is the best and safest option for determining early pregnancy.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no: 175-177.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is used in a patient with Anti-Phospholipid Antibody syndrome to stop additional abortions?
questions.solution:
• In a patient with Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome, Pregnancy related morbidity and additional abortions are prevented by a combination of heparin with aspirin 80 mg daily.
  • This helps in preventing/developing thrombotic events leading to abortions.
  • Aspirin + LMWH is the cornerstone of APLA management during pregnancy.
  • Close monitoring of the pregnancy and careful management of anticoagulation are key to minimizing risks for both mother and fetus.
  • Anticoagulation is continued postpartum to reduce the risk of venous thromboembolism, particularly in the first 6 weeks.
  • LMWH or warfarin can be used postpartum.
  • Heparin is typically discontinued 24 hours before labor induction or scheduled C-section to reduce the risk of bleeding.
  • Delivery is usually planned around 37-39 weeks, depending on maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Steroids (prednisolone) or IVIg may be considered in specific cases, especially if there is an associated autoimmune disease, but these are not routinely recommended solely for APLA.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no:1116.

questions.text: A woman who is 36 weeks pregnant is admitted to your ward. She is depicted in the illustration lying supine during the morning rounds. She complains of faintness and lightheadedness. Which syndrome is pictured below?
questions.solution:
• Supine hypotensive syndrome/Supine vena cava syndrome (also referred to as inferior vena cava compression syndrome) is caused when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava when a pregnant woman is in a supine position, leading to decreased venous return centrally.
  • That's why pregnant women are advised to lie in left lateral position.
 

Supine Hypotension Syndrome is a condition that can occur during pregnancy, particularly in the later stages, when the heavy uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is lying flat on her back. This compression reduces venous return to the heart, leading to decreased cardiac output and hypotension.

  • Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, weakness, nausea, palpitations, and in severe cases, fainting (syncope).
  • Mechanism: Lying supine compresses the IVC, impairing blood flow back to the heart.
  • Risk Factors: More common after 20 weeks of pregnancy; overweight women may be at higher risk.
  • Management: Shift to a left lateral position or elevate the right hip to relieve pressure on the IVC.
  • Prevention: Pregnant women should avoid lying flat on their backs for prolonged periods, especially in the third trimester.
 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 64.

questions.text: At 18 weeks gestation, a pregnant G3P2 visits the clinic for genetic counseling. She has a history of having two significant thalassemic babies. Which examination would you suggest right now?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Amniocentesis
 
  • At 18 weeks of gestation, Amniocentesis is the preferred test for diagnosing genetic disorders, including thalassemia.
  • It allows for the collection of amniotic fluid, which contains fetal cells that can be tested for thalassemia mutations.
  • Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is typically done earlier in pregnancy (10-13 weeks), and cordocentesis is done later (after 18-20 weeks) but is more invasive and riskier.
  • Cordocentesis has some limited indications like in Rh negative pregnancy and not routinely used as diagnostic test.

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) can be useful for screening >10 weeks POG, but in this case, given the history of significant thalassemic babies, a diagnostic test like amniocentesis is more appropriate.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 346.

  • A second dose is repeated 72 hours after delivery.

Screening strategies for Down syndrome
First trimester screening (10 - 14 weeks):
• Maternal age 32%
• Nuchal translucency measurement (by ultrasound) 74%
• First trimester double test (PAPP-A, \(\beta\)-hCG) 63%
• First trimester combined test (nuchal translucency, PAPP-A, \(\beta\)-hCG) >86%
Second trimester screening (15 to 19 weeks):
• Maternal age 32%
• Second trimester double test (AFP, HCG) 60%
• Triple test (AFP, HCG, uE3) 68%
• Quadruple test (AFP, HCG, uE3, inhibin A) 79%
• Integrated test (first trimester: nuchal translucency, PAPP-A and \(\beta\)-hcG: second trimester: quadruple test) 95%
Prenatal diagnosis:
Amniocentesis (14-16 weeks) 100%
Chorionic villus sampling (10-12 weeks) 100%
FISH 100%

questions.text: Which of the following statements about medical abortion is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Only a person certified under MTP act can perform medical termination of pregnancy

Criteria for MTP: 

1. Opinion of one RMP for termination of pregnancy up to 20 weeks.
2. Opinion of 2 RMPs for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks.
3. Pregnancy can be terminated up to 24 weeks, only in cases of survivors of rape and severe fetal anomalies which are incompatible with life.
4. In case of failure of contraceptive in a women of her partner, MTP can be done only up to 20 weeks.
5. MTP can be done even after 24 weeks in case of substantial foetal abnormalities diagnosed by a Medical Board.
6. Ultrasound is not needed in all cases.
7.The IUCD should be removed before performing a medical abortion.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 202, 203.

questions.solution:

Classification of Hypertensive Disorders in Pregnancy
Preeclampsia to eclampsia Hypertension and proteinuria \(\geq\) 300 mg per 24 hours after 20 weeks' gestation. Eclampsia is the convulsive form of preeclampsia
Gestational hypertension Hypertension induced in pregnancy after 20 weeks' gestation without proteinuria
Chronic hypertension Blood pressure \(\geq\) 140/90 mm Hg pre-pregnancy or before 20 weeks' gestation
Preeclampsia superimposed on chronic hypertension Chronic hypertension, developing preeclampsia and presenting with proteinuria, sudden increase in blood pressure, elevated or abnormal liver function tests, thrombocytopenia or a sudden increase in blood pressure in a patient with previously controlled blood pressure

Completely safe drugs among the options are alpha methyl dopa and labetalol.

questions.text: A patient who is a woman of childbearing age is taking valproate for JME. Which medication should be substituted for valproate and is acceptable for usage in monotherapy?
questions.solution:
• Levetiracetam
  • If valproate is taken during pregnancy, up to 4 in 10 babies are at risk of developmental disorders, and approximately 1 in 10 are at risk of birth defects.
  • Birth defects seen when mothers take valproate during pregnancy include:
  1. Spina bifida (where the bones of the spine do not develop properly)
  2. Facial and skull malformations (including cleft lip and palate, where the upper lip or facial bones are split).
  3. Malformations of the limbs, heart, kidney, urinary tract and sexual organs.

Levetiracetam is safer in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which week of pregnancy has the highest cardiac output?
questions.solution:
28 weeks
Physiological changes in the
cardiovascular system during pregnancy 
• During pregnancy, there is an increase in cardiac output by increasing heart stroke volume and heart rate 
• Increasing CVS begins with 10 weeks of pregnancy and reaches a maximum of 29-36 weeks of pregnancy 
• Increasing CVS occurs due to the increase in plasma volume to to 35-47% and the volume of circulating red blood cells at
11-30%, as a result, the hematocrit decreases to 33-38% 
• Pregnancy worsens CVD and can lead to emergency conditions that require urgent measures, not only from the obstetrician but also from the therapist cardiologist surgeon.

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding Duncan placental separation?
questions.solution:
• There are two methods of separation and expulsion of the placenta.
  • Shultze Method: 80%: This is the most common method in which separation starts from the center of the placenta and with the aid of Retroplacental clot the placenta drops into the lower uterine segment or into the vagina. During delivery the fetal surface appears first at the vulva followed by the membranes. There is minimal blood loss with this method.
  • Mathews Duncan Method 20%: In this method separationstarts at the edge and slides down sideways. It comes through the vulva with the lateral border first, like a button through a button hole. The maternal surface is seen first at the vulva. There is trickling of blood throughout the third stage.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman who is pregnant with her third child delivers a healthy baby and an unharmed placenta. After giving birth, the woman experiences acute vaginal bleeding 30 minutes later. Sonogram on the table showed retained placental tissue. What kind of placenta is believed to be present?
questions.solution:
Placenta succenturiata
  
  • Membranous placenta – This is where the placenta is thin and covers a large part of the fetal membranes, but it doesn’t typically cause retained tissue.
  • Placenta fenestrae – A rare anomaly where there are areas of the placenta without villi. It does not typically lead to retained tissue.
  • Placenta accreta – This occurs when the placenta abnormally attaches too deeply into the uterine wall, but it generally causes difficulty in delivering the placenta and often requires surgical removal, rather than presenting as retained tissue seen later

questions.solution:
• Down syndrome Nuchal translucency (NT) thickness measured at 11–14 weeks’ gestation is the most effective single marker for trisomy 21.

questions.text: Which of the following levels changes the most throughout pregnancy:
questions.solution:
• Renal clearance of iodine is increased due to increased glomerular filtration. Maternal serum iodine levels fall due to increased renal loss and also due to transplacental shift to the fetus. These cause hyperplasia of the gland. Iodine intake during pregnancy should be increased from 100 !g/day to 200 !g/day (as recommended by WHO).
  • There is rise in the basal metabolic rate, which begins at about the third month, reaches a value of +25% during the last trimester. The increase in BMR is probably due to increase in net oxygen consumption of mother and fetus. There is stimulatory effect of hCG (chorionic thyrotropin) to thyroid gland mainly in the first trimester.
  • Due to this thyrotropic effect of hCG, there may be a transient phase of hyperthyroidism in some women (gestational transient thyrotoxicosis).
  • The serum protein-bound iodine is increased in pregnancy, the range being 6.2–11.2 microg% instead of the usual 4–8 microg%.
  • Thyroxin-binding globulin (TBG) increases and reaches a plateau by 20 weeks. It remains unchanged at that level until delivery. The increase in TBG is due to estrogen stimulation. Iodine and drugs used to treat hyperthyroidism cross the placenta freely.
  • Maternal total T4 and T3 are increased by 18 weeks but free T4 and T3 levels are unchanged.
  • Maternal TSH remains normal. Secretion of T4 and T3 is 20:1, but biological activity of T3 is five times more than that of T4.
  • Level of calcitonin — a thyroid hormone secreted by the parafollicular cells, increases by 20%. Calcitonin protects the maternal skeleton from excess bone loss during pregnancy and lactation.
  • Routine screening of all pregnant women for thyroid function is not recommended by ACOG. However women with high risk factors should have their serum TSH level checked in their first antenatal visit.

questions.text: What prevents milk production during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• High estrogen
  • High estrogen during pregnancy will keep the prolactin levels suppressed which prevents lactation.
  • The local effects of estrogen and progesterone in the breast prevent milk secretion during pregnancy. With their withdrawal in the postpartum period, the stimulating effect of the anterior pituitary hormone prolactin dominates and milk secretion is initiated and maintained.

  • Breast milk is the primary source of Vitamin A for the infant, so the demand for it increases during lactation to support the baby's needs.

questions.text: What should you recommend if a pregnant woman with known cardiac disease comes to you in the first trimester and has a history of warfarin embryopathy?
questions.solution:
• Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester
  • Between 6 and 12 weeks’ gestation, fetal synthesis of proteins crucial for bone and cartilage formation may be impaired by warfarin, resulting in the well-defined “warfarin embryopathy.”
  • One of the most commonly suggested regimens involves the substitution of heparin for warfarin between 6 and 12 weeks’ gestation to minimize the risk of warfarin embryopathy.

questions.text: What is the average vaginal pH value during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option 1 is correct.PH 4
  • During pregnancy, the average vaginal pH value is around 4.
  • This is considered to be slightly acidic, which helps to maintain a healthy balance of bacteria in the vagina.
  • The acidic environment is created by the production of lactic acid by lactobacilli, which are beneficial bacteria that dominate the vaginal microbiota in healthy women.
  • The acidic environment also helps to prevent the overgrowth of harmful bacteria and yeast, which can cause infections.
  • It is important to maintain a healthy vaginal pH during pregnancy to prevent complications such as preterm labor and premature rupture of membranes.

questions.text: What is softening of a lower uterine region on bimanual examination referred to as?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Hegar's Sign
 

Hegar's sign is an indication of early pregnancy characterized by softening of the lower uterine segment (the area between the cervix and the body of the uterus) that can be felt during a bimanual examination.

Other options (Signs of Pregnancy):

  1. Chadwick Sign: Refers to a bluish discoloration of the cervix, vagina, and vulva due to increased blood flow, which can be an early sign of pregnancy.
  2. Osiander's Sign: Refers to the detection of pulsations in the lateral vaginal fornices
  3. Goodell's Sign: Refers to the softening of the cervix, often occurring early in pregnancy.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 23.

questions.text: A 25 years old lady complaints of right sided lower abdominal pain and mild bleeding per vaginum for one day after a period of amenorrhoea of 6 weeks. Her general condition is satisfactory and the vitals were stable. There is tenderness in the right iliac fossa. HCG level was 1400 IU/ml. Transvaginal ultrasound scan does not reveal any adnexal mass or any intrauterine pregnancy but the uterus was bulky and trilaminar endometrium was seen. There was no fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
• The two possibilities based on the above clinical stem is either an abortion or ectopic pregnancy. 
 
  • Therefore, the next best step is to repeat b-HCG after 48 hours. 
 
  • Ectopic pregnancy should be suspected based on clinical symptoms (abdominal pain, bleeding, and positive pregnancy test with no visible intrauterine pregnancy).
  • In this case, beta-HCG is positive but lower than expected for an intrauterine pregnancy (usually >1500 IU/ml to be visible on ultrasound).
  • The next step is to repeat the beta-HCG after 48 hours to check if the levels are doubling. In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, beta-HCG should rise appropriately (typically doubling every 48 hours). In an ectopic pregnancy, the beta-HCG may rise more slowly or plateau.
  • If the beta-HCG levels fail to double or remain stable, it strongly suggests an ectopic pregnancy, and further management, including surgical intervention or medical treatment (such as methotrexate), may be needed.

Other options:
 

  1. Perform a laparoscopic examination:

    • While laparoscopic examination is a definitive diagnostic tool for ectopic pregnancy, it is invasive. A repeated beta-HCG test would provide more information about the pregnancy’s progression before opting for surgical intervention. Laparoscopy is typically reserved for cases where the diagnosis remains uncertain or if the patient is unstable.

  2. Repeat USG after a week:

    • Waiting a week without further investigation could delay the diagnosis and management of a potentially life-threatening ectopic pregnancy. The beta-HCG test is more useful for timely decision-making.

  3. Give progesterone:

    • Progesterone supplementation is not indicated in this case. If the patient had threatened abortion or luteal phase insufficiency, progesterone might be considered, but this presentation suggests a more serious condition, such as ectopic pregnancy, which needs further diagnostic workup.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 371-378.

questions.text: A lady with 12 weeks of pregnancy presented for antenatal check-up. What would be your advice regarding calorie requirements?
questions.solution:
Additional 300 kcal is recommended in second trimester. 
 
  • For a pregnant woman, an additional 300 kcal per day is generally recommended in the second trimester.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics, energy needs remain similar to non-pregnant women in the first trimester but increase by 340 kcal in the second trimester and by 452 kcal in the third trimester.
  • The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) advises an extra 300 kcal during both the second and third trimesters. Therefore, option 1 is more accurate in this context.

Pregnancy demands additional nutrients to support fetal growth and development. The National Institute of Nutrition suggests the following increases for pregnant women:

  • Protein: An extra 23 g/day compared to non-pregnant women
  • Fat: 30 g/day
  • Calcium: 1200 mg/day
  • Iron: 35 mg/day

During lactation, the ICMR recommends increasing caloric intake by 550 kcal/day for the first six months and by 400 kcal/day from 7–12 months of lactation.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 167.
National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) guidelines, URL: https://www.nin.res.in/rdabook/brief_note.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is secreted by the placenta?
questions.solution:
• Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is made almost exclusively in the placenta.
 
  • hCG hormone levels found in the mother's blood and urine rise a lot during the first trimester.

Hormones secreted by Placenta:
 
  1. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  2. Human placental lactogen (hPL)
  3. Progesterone
  4. Estrogens (primarily estriol)
  5. Relaxin
  6. Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
  7. Growth factors (e.g., epidermal growth factor)



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 53, 54.

questions.text: Which is wrong about normal Placenta?
questions.solution:
In a normal pregnancy, the placenta has two arteries and one vein, which make up the umbilical cord.

A normal placenta typically contains:

  • 2 arteries (one for carrying deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta)
  • 1 vein (which carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus)


Other options:
 
  1. Weight: The average weight of a normal placenta is about 500 grams.
  2. Diameter: The average diameter is around 20 cm.
  3. Thickness: The average thickness of a normal placenta is about 2.5 cm.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 108, 109.

questions.text:
The sign seen at 8 weeks of pregnancy are: 
(a) Goodell's sign 
(b) Osiander sign
(c) Lightening 
(d) Internal ballottment
questions.solution:
• The Goodell sign refers to a probable sign of pregnancy, characterized by softening of the cervix. A positive Goodell sign occurs due to increased blood flow noticed in the cervix during the first 4 to 8 weeks of pregnancy, which can also give the vaginal part of the cervix a bluish appearance (Chadwick sign).
 
  • Osiander’s sign is an early indication of pregnancy (at eight weeks) in which pulsation can be felt through the lateral vaginal fornix.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 61, 65.

questions.text: Which of the following constitute modified Biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 1: AFI + NST. The modified BPP includes the assessment of the amniotic fluid index (AFI) along with the non-stress test (NST). 
The largest pocket of amniotic fluid is measured in each of the four quadrants of the mother's abdomen using ultrasound. All four quadrants are added together to give the amniotic fluid index. (normal range - 5 to 25 cm)

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 121-123 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cost effective screening procedure advised for all pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, the screening procedure that is not universally advised for all pregnant women due to its cost-effectiveness is: ECHO (echocardiography)

Echocardiography is not routinely recommended for all pregnant women as a part of standard prenatal screening. It may be indicated in specific cases where there are specific risk factors or suspected fetal abnormalities. However, it is not a standard screening test that is universally performed for all pregnant women.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 330,320,324,128-129 .

questions.text: A female patient, currently pregnant, visits the hospital for a routine ANC visit. She has a history of a term twin delivery 3 years back. What is her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
The obstetric score of a pregnant woman who previously delivered twins at term would be G2P1.
The obstetric score is used to summarize the past obstetric history as follows:
  • Gravidity (G): Total number of pregnancies, irrespective of the outcome, including the present one. Thus G2 implies two pregnancies in this patient, the first one 3 years back, and the present pregnancy for which the patient is seeking ANC care. Since, this is the number of pregnancies rather than the number of children, the twin pregnancy is counted the same as a singleton pregnancy. Thus, the gravida is taken to be 2, and not 3. (option C, option D)
  • Parity (P): Denotes the total number of previous pregnancies, irrespective of the outcome that have crossed the period of viability, which is 28 weeks at most centers in India. In the Western countries, this is to be taken as 20 weeks of gestation due to better neonatal and maternal care. Central institutes such as the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at AIIMS, New Delhi take this cutoff to be 24 weeks. Since, this is the number of pregnancies rather than the number of children, the twin pregnancy is counted as a single parity. The current pregnancy is not included in the score. Thus, the parity for this patient is taken to be 1. (option B)
Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 177.

questions.text: Which of the following factors are responsible for increased blood volume during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Both increase of estrogen and aldosterone and increased fluid retention by kidney is responsible for increased blood volume during pregnancy.
This increase volume causes relative hemodilution, causing physiological anemia during pregnancy.
Increased estrogen during pregnancy directly causes fluid retention and also activates the RAAS pathway causing increased aldosterone, leading to fluid retention by the kidneys although there is a reset in the threshold for response to ADH, the levels of ADH remain unchanged.

Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No- 46, 47.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the maternal component of placenta ?
questions.solution:
The placenta has maternal and fetal components:

  • Maternal component: Decidua basalis

    • Part of the endometrium beneath the implanted embryo.

    • Forms the maternal portion of the placenta and interacts with fetal chorionic villi. 

  • Fetal component: Chorion frondosum

    • The portion of the chorion that develops villi and interdigitates with decidua basalis.

Other options — brief:
2. Decidua capsularis: Covers the embryo on the side opposite to the implantation site; does not contribute to maternal placenta.
3. Decidua parietalis: Lines the remaining uterine cavity; not part of the placenta.
4. Chorion frondosum: Fetal component, not maternal.

Key point:

Maternal placenta = Decidua basalis; fetal placenta = Chorion frondosum.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tubal pregnancy underwent transvaginal ultrasound which was inconclusive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
• The patient has a suspected tubal (ectopic) pregnancy, but transvaginal ultrasound is inconclusive, which is a common scenario early in gestation.

  • At this stage, the next best step is to check serial serum β-hCG levels. Normally, in an intrauterine pregnancy, β-hCG doubles approximately every 48 hours. In contrast, in an ectopic pregnancy, the rise is slower or plateauing, providing an important clue to the diagnosis.

  • This approach allows biochemical confirmation without immediately resorting to invasive procedures, and it guides further management safely.

  • Why not the other options: Methotrexate is only used after confirming the ectopic pregnancy and ensuring the patient is stable; diagnostic laparoscopy is reserved for cases where uncertainty persists despite β-hCG monitoring and imaging; laparotomy is reserved for hemodynamically unstable patients or those with ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

  • Key takeaway: Combining TVS and serial β-hCG is the cornerstone of diagnosing early ectopic pregnancy, minimizing unnecessary surgical intervention while ensuring timely treatment.

questions.text: The image given below shows that the pregnancy is
questions.solution: The sonographic image shows the Twin Peak or Lambda sign, confirming a dichorionic pregnancy. This sign indicates that the placenta extends between the layers of the amnion, creating a 'peak.' In dichorionic gestations, the twins are separated by membranes and an intervening chorion, resulting in a prominent Twin Peak or Lambda sign at the junction where the amnions meet the placenta. This type of twin gestation occurs if the inner cell mass divides within three days of fertilization. The chorionicity of the placenta is most accurately diagnosed by ultrasound between 10 and 13 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: What is the standard glucose load given for identifying diabetes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
According to the International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG) criteria, an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is performed in the fasting state using 75 grams of glucose to diagnose gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). The diagnosis is made if any one of the following thresholds is exceeded:

Fasting: >92 mg/dL
1 hour: >180 mg/dL
2 hours: >153 mg/dL
If any of these values are met, a diagnosis of GDM is confirmed.

questions.text: Arrange the sequence of lactation in the right order 1. Mammogenesis 2. Lactogenesis 3. Galactokinesis 4. Galactopoiesis
questions.solution:
Mammogenesis: Refers to the development and growth of the mammary glands, which occurs during puberty and pregnancy under the influence of hormones such as estrogen and progesterone.

Lactogenesis: This is the process of milk production, divided into two phases:

Lactogenesis I: Also known as colostrum secretion, it begins in late pregnancy and continues for a few days postpartum. During this time, the mammary glands produce colostrum, a nutrient-rich fluid full of antibodies.
Lactogenesis II: Also called transitional milk secretion, it starts around 2-5 days after birth, transitioning the glands to produce mature milk.

Galactokinesis: This involves the movement of milk through the mammary ducts towards the nipple. Myoepithelial cell contractions, triggered by oxytocin, facilitate this process.

Galactopoiesis: Refers to the maintenance and regulation of milk production, primarily controlled by prolactin, which stimulates milk synthesis and secretion. Frequent breastfeeding or milk removal also helps sustain milk production.

questions.text: A mother complains of cramps in her breasts while breastfeeding her child. Which hormone is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The mother’s breast cramps or a “let-down” feeling during breastfeeding are due to milk ejection, which is mediated by oxytocin.

  • Oxytocin: Released from the posterior pituitary in response to nipple stimulation. It causes contraction of myoepithelial cells around the alveoli, leading to milk ejection and the sensation of breast cramps. 

  • Prolactin: Responsible for milk production, not the ejection reflex.

  • Estrogen and Progesterone: Important during pregnancy for breast development, but do not cause milk ejection.

Key point:

Breast cramping during breastfeeding = oxytocin-mediated let-down reflex.

questions.text: In the quadruple marker test, a 33 year-old G2P1L1 at 18 weeks of gestation was found to be at a high risk of neural tube defects and low risk of trisomy 21. What is the next investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
For a female with a quadruple test showing a low risk of trisomy 21, the next investigation to be done is an anomaly scan, as part of routine antenatal care.

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page No 339.

questions.text: What is the definition of a post-term neonate?
questions.solution:
Definitions of Infants Based on Gestational Age
 

  • Preterm neonate: < 37 completed weeks

  • Term neonate: 37 – 42 weeks

  • Post-term neonate: > 42 completed weeks

  • Post-maturity syndrome: May develop in some post-term babies → dry, peeling skin, meconium staining, wasting due to placental insufficiency.

questions.text: If the division in the zygote occurs between 9-12 days after fertilization, which of the following twin is expected?
questions.solution:
Zygotic Division Timing: If division of the zygote occurs between 9 to 12 days post-fertilization, the result will be monochorionic monoamniotic twins.

Radiological Signs for Determining Chorionicity and Amnionicity in Twin Gestation:

1. Lambda Sign (Twin Peak Sign):
Observed in dichorionic twin gestations, where the twins are separated by both amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion.
This results in a thicker peak (?) formation at the junction where the amniotic membranes meet the placenta.
This sign is most prominently seen during the first trimester.

2. T Sign:
This is identified in monochorionic twin pregnancies and represents the absence of chorion between the layers of the intertwin membrane.
In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated solely by two amniotic membranes, leading to a thin T sign at the meeting point of the amniotic membranes and the placenta. This sign is best observed in the latter part of the first trimester or the early second trimester.
In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is a complete absence of dividing membranes.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of thrombocytopenia during pregnancy is gestational thrombocytopenia, which may arise from hemodilution and increased platelet consumption.

Pregnancy is considered a hypercoagulable state. The hematological changes that occur during pregnancy include:

An increase in all clotting factors (with the exception of factors 11 and 13), as well as elevated fibrinogen levels.
Both clotting time and bleeding time remain unaffected.
Blood viscosity does not increase because plasma volume expands more than red cell volume, leading to a decrease in whole blood viscosity.
The anticoagulants Protein C, Protein S, and antithrombin levels decrease during pregnancy.
Fibrinolytic activity remains suppressed for about 15 minutes post-delivery.

So, 

  • Gestational thrombocytopenia

    • Accounts for 70–80% of all cases of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy.

    • Usually mild (platelet count >70,000/µL).

    • No maternal/fetal risk, resolves spontaneously postpartum.

  • Preeclampsia/HELLP → Important causes but less common (~15–20%).

  • ITP (Immune thrombocytopenia) → Rare (~5%).

questions.text: Which of the following is the best parameter for estimation of fetal age by ultrasound in 1st trimester?
questions.solution:
Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most precise measurement for sonographic estimation of gestational age during the first trimester, with an accuracy range of ± 5 days.


 

  • Second trimester:

    • Biparietal diameter (BPD) and head circumference (HC) are more useful.

    • Accuracy: ±1 week.

  • Third trimester:

    • Abdominal circumference (AC) and femur length (FL) are used, but accuracy declines (±2–3 weeks).

questions.text: Which of the following finding is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image presented depicts Linea nigra, which is a brownish-black line that runs from the xiphisternum to the symphysis pubis in the midline. This pigmentation is believed to be influenced by melanocyte-stimulating hormone from the anterior pituitary and typically fades after delivery. Similar pigmentary changes can occur in women using oral contraceptives, possibly linked to estrogen and progesterone.



Other Options:
  • Option 1: Striae gravidarum are slightly depressed linear marks that vary in length and breadth, commonly found during pregnancy. These marks primarily appear on the abdominal wall below the umbilicus and may also be seen on the thighs and breasts, initially presenting as pinkish in color. They represent scar tissue within the deeper layers of the skin.
 
  • Option 3: Initially, striae gravidarum present as pinkish marks, but post-delivery, the scar tissue contracts and causes obliteration of the capillaries, resulting in a glistening white appearance, referred to as linea alba.
 
  • Option 4: Chloasma gravidarum, also known as the pregnancy mask, manifests as significant pigmentation around the cheeks, forehead, and eyes. This pigmentation can be either patchy or diffuse and typically resolves on its own after delivery.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 45, 46.

questions.text: What is the ideal number of recommended ANC visits during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The generally recommended ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14:
• Monthly visits up to 28 weeks
• Two weekly visits between 28-36 weeks
• Weekly visits from 36 weeks onward.
• This means a total of 12-14 visits. Ref - Dutta textbook of obstetrics 9th edition page 111

questions.text: Which is the following sign is seen in neural tube defect?
questions.solution:
Signs of neural tube defect on targeted sonography:
• Small biparietal diameter
• Ventriculomegaly
• Frontal bone scalloping or the lemon sign.
• Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna known as banana sign.
Williams Obstetrics 24th edition • Page no 285

questions.text: Which of the following Leopold Maneuvers is done to assess the lie of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Leopold 1 that is the fundal grip is used to assess the lie of the fetus.First Maneuver (Fundal Grip): Determines whether the fetal head or buttocks is in the fundus.
Second Maneuver (Umbilical Grip): Identifies the location of the fetal back and extremities.
Third Maneuver (Pawlik‘s Grip): Assesses which fetal part is at the pelvic inlet.
Fourth Maneuver (Pelvic Grip): Confirms fetal engagement and position in the pelvis. Below is the image of various Leopold grips. Ref- Williams Obstetrics 24th edition Page 437

questions.text: As per anemia mukth Bharath what is the recommended drug and its dose for prevention of neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Folic acid (Vitamin B9) is given to prevent the incidence of neural tube defects such as spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.

As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, during the period of pre-conception up to the first trimester, women are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets daily
Williams Obstetrics 25th Ed • Page no: 149

questions.text: Immediately post-delivery, the uterus corresponds to __ weeks of gestational age:
questions.solution:
Immediately after delivery, the uterus is still enlarged and corresponds roughly to the size it would be at 20 weeks of gestation. Over the next few days, it undergoes involution:

  • By 24 hours: Fundus at the level of the umbilicus (approximately 20-week size).

  • Day 7: Fundus midway between umbilicus and symphysis pubis.

  • By 2 weeks: Fundus descends into the pelvis.

  • By 6 weeks: Uterus returns to non-pregnant size (approximately 12-week size).

This postpartum uterine involution is crucial for preventing postpartum hemorrhage and monitoring maternal recovery.


Reference:Williams Obstetrics 25th edition page no 653

questions.text: In which trimester is the quadruple test performed?
questions.solution:
The quadruple test is performed in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy, usually between 15–20 weeks of gestation.

It measures four maternal serum markers:

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • Beta-hCG

  • Estriol (uE3)

  • Inhibin-A

The test is used for screening for chromosomal abnormalities (like Down syndrome) and neural tube defects.





Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 249-250,337-338

choices.text: 8. When does this parameter reach its maximum value in a normal pregnancy?

questions.text: While performing the USG assessment of a woman at 28 weeks of gestation, you note her amniotic fluid index to be 12.8. When does this parameter reach its maximum value in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The amniotic fluid index (AFI) reflects the volume of amniotic fluid, which is an important marker of fetal well-being. It varies across gestation in a predictable pattern.

Pattern of AFI Across Pregnancy:

  • Gradual increase from the first trimester.

  • Peak volume is reached around 34 weeks of gestation, averaging 800 mL to 1000 mL.

  • After 34 weeks, AFI gradually declines toward term.

  • By 40 weeks, it may decrease to about 600–800 mL.

    At 28 weeks:

  • AFI around 12.8 cm is normal.

  • AFI between 5–24 cm is considered within the normal range in the third trimester.

    Key Takeaway:

  • The maximum AFI is typically reached at 34 weeks of gestation.

  • Therefore, the correct answer is: 34 weeks (Option 1).



Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 94

questions.text: Cardiac output returns back to prepregnant levels by
questions.solution:
During pregnancy, cardiac output (CO) increases by up to 30–50% due to elevated blood volume and metabolic demands. This increase begins early in pregnancy and peaks by mid-pregnancy, remaining elevated until delivery.

After delivery, there is a sudden increase in venous return due to:

  • Relief of caval compression

  • Autotransfusion from the contracted uterus

Despite this, cardiac output starts to decline rapidly in the first few days postpartum.

  • By 2–5 days postpartum: CO decreases significantly

  • By around 10 days postpartum: Cardiac output returns to prepregnancy levels

  • Complete normalization of hemodynamics may take 6 weeks or longer


Reference:Williams Obstetrics 24th edition page no 671

questions.text: Studies have demonstrated that the timing of a caesarean section has no impact on prematurity-related problems such IUGR. When should a caesarean section be performed?
questions.solution:
39 weeks
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the National Institutes of Health recommend that nonmedically indicated elective CDs should be performed after 39 weeks’ gestation to reduce neonatal respiratory morbidity and mortality rates.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 549.

choices.text: Twin pregnancy precludes the use of oxytocin
Amniotomy decreases the need for oxytocin use
Methods of augmentation does not increase the risk of operational management
Associated with a risk of uterine hyper stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about augmentation of labor?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Methods of augmentation do not increase the risk of operational management

This statement is incorrect because augmentation of labor, especially with interventions like oxytocin or amniotomy, can increase the risk of operational delivery (such as assisted vaginal delivery or cesarean section), particularly if complications arise, such as uterine hyperstimulation or fetal distress.

Other options:

  • Option 1: Twin pregnancy precludes the use of oxytocin – This statement is generally correct as oxytocin is often used cautiously in twin pregnancies due to the increased risk of uterine overstimulation and complications.

  • Option 2: Amniotomy decreases the need for oxytocin use – This is true, as amniotomy can stimulate contractions, potentially reducing the need for additional oxytocin.

  • Option 4: Associated with a risk of uterine hyperstimulation – This is correct. Augmentation with oxytocin carries a risk of uterine hyperstimulation, which can lead to fetal distress.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 492-494.

choices.text: Manual support of perineum to maintain flexion of head
Episiotomy should be performed as a routine procedure
Warm cloth should not be applied to the perineum
Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following statements about second stage of labor management is accurate according to WHO guidelines?
questions.solution:
• Manual support of perineum to maintain flexion of head This statement reflects an accurate approach to managing the second stage of labor.
  • Providing manual support to the perineum helps to control the speed of delivery, maintain flexion of the fetal head, and reduce the risk of perineal trauma.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 115, 124, 125.

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC did per vaginal examination of a women in labor with 8 cm cervical dilation and 70% cervical effacement with the fetal head at +1 station. This +1 station implies the position of fetal head is:
questions.solution:
1 cm below the ischial spine



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 427.

choices.text: Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 90 bpm for 60 sec
Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 100 bpm for 60 sec
Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 80 bpm for 60 sec
Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 70 bpm for 60 sec

questions.text: What is accurate regarding significant variable decelerations
questions.solution:
Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 70 bpm for 60 sec



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 693.

questions.text: At a PHC, a midwife keeps track of the progression of the pregnancy and monitors the pregnancy. How much cervical dilatation should be present before beginning partograph plotting according to WHO labor care guide?
questions.solution:
As per the latest WHO labor care guidelines 2021, cervical dilatation plotting in partograph starts from 5 cm.
Previously cervical dilatation in partograph was measured from 4 cm.

WHO partograph:





Reference: WHO Labour care guide: User manual, 2021, URL: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240017566
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 490-493.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient in labor had the following fetal tocographic finding: What does it imply?
questions.solution:
Late Deceleration suggestive of utero placental insufficiency leading to fetal distress
   

Remember all the types and causes of decelerations . Frequently repeated question


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: Which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter in the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
• The obstetric conjugate is the shortest anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet.
  • It is measured from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the posterior aspect of the pubic symphysis.
  • It is important in obstetrics as it determines whether the fetal head can pass through the pelvic inlet during childbirth.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: What does modified BPP consist of?
questions.solution:
The modified BPP 
Nonstress test + evaluation of the amount of amniotic fluid (AFI)
It's considered abnormal if NST is non reactive or AFI is less than 5.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 390, 391.

questions.text: All are components of Active management of third stage of labor, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Uterine massage.
Uterine massage have now been removed from AMTSL.
Intermittent uterine tone assessment has replaced routine uterine massage.
Rest all are components of AMTSL 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 506-508.

questions.text: When are the initial markings made in the partogram?
questions.solution:
Left side of alert line
The marking of partograph starts on left side of alert line.
The WHO partograph has two diagonal lines: an alert line and an action line. The alert line goes from 4 to 10 cm and corresponds to an average dilation rate of 1 cm per hour. If the labour curve crosses to the right of this alert line, this means that the dilation is less than 1 cm per hour.




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 490-493.

questions.text: A primigravida arrived with a 6 cm cervical dilatation and a 3/10 minute contraction rate. What stage of labor is she currently in?
questions.solution:
First stage

Define Labor and its Stages
• Stages of Labor
• 1st stage - onset of labor until full cervical dilitation
• 2nd stage - from full dilitation to birth of infant
• 3rd stage - from birth of infant until delivery of placenta
• 4th stage - 2 hours after the delivery of placenta


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 424-425.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 121-123.

questions.text: A female patient in the labor ward received an opioid analgesic. Which of the following medications should be kept on hand in case of emergency?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Naloxone
 
  • Naloxone is a medicine that rapidly reverses an opioid overdose. It is an opioid antagonist. This means that it attaches to opioid receptors and reverses and blocks the effects of other opioids.
  • Naloxone can quickly restore normal breathing to a person if their breathing has slowed or stopped because of an opioid overdose.
  • Narcotics used during labor may cause newborn respiratory depression. Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system.
  • After adequate ventilation has been established, naloxone may be given to a newborn whose mother received narcotics.
  • Naloxone is contraindicated in a newborn of a narcotic-addicted mother because withdrawal symptoms may be precipitated (American Academy of Pediatrics, 2017).



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 469, 1150.

questions.text: After a typical vaginal delivery at full term, the woman experiences hypoxemia and then collapses unexpectedly. What causes this?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Amniotic fluid embolism

The sudden unexpected hypoxemia followed by collapse post-delivery suggests Amniotic Fluid Embolism
 
  • Typically, amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) happens during labor and delivery or in the first few hours following delivery via cesarean section, amniocentesis, placenta removal, or with therapeutic abortion.
 
  • The AFE diagnosis is an exclusionary clinical diagnosis. Based on the clinical presentation, it is made. When the condition first manifests, it frequently manifests as tachycardia with a right ventricular strain pattern and ST-T wave alterations on an ECG, and pulse oximetry may reveal a precipitous decline in oxygen saturation. Following this, there is a collapse of the cardiovascular system and acute respiratory distress along with extreme hypotension.





Reference: Williams Obstretics, 26th edition, Page no 743-745.

choices.text: Induce labor by artificial rupture of membranes
Sedate the patient by and give phenergan to decrease labor pains
Observe the patient and wait for increase in uterine contractions

questions.text: A primigravida who was 38 weeks pregnant arrived in the delivery room with little contractions and labour pains. The cervix is 50% effaced and 2 cm dilated on examination. The patient's blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg and heart rate is 86/min. What action is necessary now?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Observe the patient and wait for increase in uterine contractions
  • Inducing labor by artificial rupture of membranes (option 1) is not indicated at this point because the cervix is only 2 cm dilated and contractions are minimal.
  • Giving oxytocin to augment labor (option 2) is also not appropriate because labor has not progressed sufficiently.
  • Sedating the patient with phenergan (option 3) is unnecessary and may not be beneficial, as it does not address the underlying labor progression.


Labour is divided into three stages.
The first stage (stage of dilatation): From the onset of true labour until the cervix is fully dilated.
It is divided into two phases:

1. The latent phase:
- Starts from onset of labour until the cervix reaches 3 cm dilatation.
- Lasts between 3-8 hours, shorter in multiparous women.
- Contractions occurs at least twice every 10 minutes with each lasting > 20 seconds, not more than moderately strong and are quite well tolerated without analgesia.

2. The active phase:
From 3 cm-full cervical dilatation (10 cm), here the contractions becomes more frequent and stronger.
- Contractions occurs 3 times every 10 minutes, with each lasting > 40 seconds.
- The cervix should dilate at a rate of 1 cm/hour of faster.
Last between 2-6 hours.
- The duration of the 1st stage of labour in promipara patient range from 6-18 hours (average = 12 hours).
- In multiparous women about 2-10 hours (average 5 hours)



Reference: Williams Obstretics, 26th edition, Page no 424-429.

choices.text: Alert and action lines are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Partograph recording should be started at a cervical dilation of 10 cm
Send the patient to first referral unit if the labor progression line crosses the alert line

questions.text: The partograph illustrates the numerous time-related stages of work. Every partograph fact is accurate, with the exception of which one:
questions.solution:
• Partograph recording begins at end of latent phase and when active phase begins which is at cervical dilation of 4 or 5 cm. 
  • Partograph is a composite graphical record of key data (maternal and fetal) during labor, entered against time on a single sheet of paper.
  • In cervicograph (Philpott & Caste 1972), the alert line starts at 4 cm (Now 5 cm according to WHO Labour care guide) of cervical dilatation and ends at 10 cm dilatation (at the rate of 1 cm/hr).
  • The action line is drawn 4 hours to the right and parallel to the alert line. In a normal labor, the cervicograph (cervical dilatation) should be either on the alert line or to the left of it.
  • When it falls on Zone 2, it is abnormal and need to be critically assessed. When it falls in Zone 3 case should be reassessed by a senior person. Decision is to be made either for termination of labor (cesarean section) or for augmentation of labor (amniotomy and or oxytocin).
Hence, statement (3) is incorrect.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 606, 607.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be administered to treat acute hypertension during labor?
questions.solution:
IV nitroprusside is generally NOT used to treat acute hypertensive crisis during labor

Several drugs can be used to treat severe hypertension in pregnancy viz.:
  1. Oral/sublingual nifedipine
  2. IV/oral labetalol
  3. Oral methyldopa
  4. IV hydralazine etc.
Sodium nitroprusside has been used to alter blood pressure in severe hypertensive disease of pregnancy or in Refractory cases; however, concern exists in regard to potential lethal complications from cyanide toxicity in both mother and fetus.



Reference: Williams Obstretics, 26th edition, Page no 713, 723.

choices.text: According to ACOG it is till 3-4 cm cervical dilation but they are planning to increase it to 5 cm
Begins at the end of active phase and is a part of 2nd stage of labour
Patient may present with false labour due to mild cramps

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning the latent phase of labour is false?
questions.solution:
The latent phase of labor is the time between the beginning of labor symptoms and the onset of the active phase. Hence, Statement 2 is a wrong statement.

First Stage of labor It consists of two phases:
• Latent Phase- Cervical effacement and early dilatation occurs
• Active Phase- It begins when the cervix is 2-4 cm dilated in the presence of regular uterine contractions. More rapid cervical dilatation occurs
 
  • The onset of latent labor, as defined by Friedman (1972), is the point at which the mother perceives regular contractions. For most women, this phase ends once cervical dilation of 4 cm is achieved.
  • This threshold may be clinically useful, for it defines dilation limits beyond which active labor can be expected.
  • More recently, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (2019c) has redefined active labor to begin at 6 cm.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 424, 425.

questions.text: At what level is the sensory block for lower segment caesarian sections given?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. T4
 
  • Because afferent nerves supplying abdominal and pelvic organs accompany sympathetic fibers that travel in the sympathetic trunk (T5 to L1), a sensory block that extends from the sacral dermatomes to T4 is needed for cesarean delivery.
  • A level of sensory blockade extending to the T4 dermatome is desired for cesarean delivery.
  • A dose of 10 to 12 mg of bupivacaine in a hyperbaric solution is administered. The addition of 20 to 25 μg of fentanyl improves the quality and prolongs the duration of the spinal block, reduces shivering, and minimizes referred pain.
  • In addition, 0.1 to 0.2 mg of intrathecal morphine can be added for pain control postoperatively.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 472.

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 1 cm dilated and 30% effaced. The vertex is at –1 station and the cervix is soft and posterior. What will be the Bishop score for this lady?
questions.solution:

TOTAL SCORE 5

questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Immediate clamping cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Pick the immediate posterior structure injured when episiotomy is extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. External anal sphincter
 
  • When an episiotomy is extended, it can inadvertently cut or tear through the external anal sphincter and other structures along the posterior wall of the perineum.
  • The external anal sphincter is particularly vulnerable because it is a thin, circular muscle located near the opening of the anus, and it is particularly susceptible to damage during a surgical procedure.
  • Additionally, trauma to the external anal sphincter can cause permanent dysfunction and affect the ability of the patient to control her bowel movements and reduce the quality of life.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 399, 400.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who gave birth at home two weeks ago now has a total perineal tear. What is the management's next course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. repair after 3 months
 
  • Recent tear (<24 hours) should be repaired immediately following the delivery of the placenta. This reduces the chance of infection and minimizes the blood loss.
 
  • In cases of delay beyond 24 hours, the repair is to be withheld. Antibiotics should be started to prevent infection. The complete tear should be repaired after 3 months if delayed beyond 24 hours.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 490.

questions.solution:
• Immediate C section
  • In case of twins with first breech , cesarean section is the mode of choice for delivery. This patient is having preeclampsia and needs immediate termination as she has already reached term Hence , Immediate C section should be done.

questions.text: Interpret the partogram given in the picture.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Cephalopelvic disproportion.
 
  • As seen in the graph, the contractions are adequate but the cervical dilatation is not progressing.
  • There is also molding of fetal head along with meconium stained amniotic fluid, suggestive of fetal distress.
  • Molding+ Non-progress of labor together suggest that there is some sort of cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD)
 
  • To describe ineffective labors, two commonly used terms are cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) and failure to progress. CPD describes obstructed labor resulting from disparity between the fetal head size and maternal pelvis

choices.text: Multiparous without Previous C/S, Singleton spontaneous labour

questions.text: Group 1 of the modified Robson classification comprises of:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Nulliparous singleton spontaneous labour

Robson classification is given below:
 
Groups  Clinical characteristics
1 Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, \(\geq 37\) weeks, spontaneous labor
2 Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, \(\geq 37\) weeks, induced labor or cesarean section before labor
3 Multiparous without previous cesarean section, singleton, cephalic, \(\geq 37\) weeks, spontaneous labor
4 Multiparous without previous cesarean section, singleton, cephalic,   \(\geq 37\) weeks, induced labor or caesarean section before labor 
5 Multiparous with prior cesarean section, singleton, cephalic,   \(\geq 37\) weeks
6 All nulliparous breeches 
7 All multiparous breeches (including previous cesarean section)
8 All multiple pregnancies (including previous cesarean section)
9 All pregnancies with transverse or oblique lie (including those previous cesarean section)
10 Singleton, cephalic, \(\leq 36\) weeks (including previous cesarean section)



Reference: Pravina, Pammy et al. “Cesarean Audit Using Robson Classification at a Tertiary Care Center in Bihar: A Retrospective Study.” Cureus vol. 14,3 e23133. 13 Mar. 2022, doi:10.7759/cureus.23133

choices.text: Continuous Electronic FHR monitoring is required for Breech during labour

Breech diagnosed for the First time in Labour is contraindicated for Vaginal delivery
Vaginal breech delivery should be attempted in settings where trained person present

questions.text: All are true about Breech presentation in Labour except:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Breech diagnosed for the First time in Labour is contraindicated for Vaginal delivery

Trial for vaginal delivery can be given to breech in labor provided facilities for emergency cesarean section are present.

Unfavourable for vaginal breech birth :

• other contraindications to vaginal birth (e.g. placenta, previa, compromised fetal condition)
• clinically inadequate pelvis 
• footling or kneeling breech presentation 
• large baby (usually defined as larger than 3800 g)
• growth-restricted baby (usually defined as smaller than 2000 g)
• Hyperextented fetal neck in labour (diagnosed with ultrasound or X-ray where ultrasound is not available )
• lack of presence of a clinician trained in vaginal breech delivery 
• previous caesarean section

questions.text: Determine the patient's bishop score based on the following information: posterior location, soft consistency, cervix at station -1, 1 cm dilated, 30% effaced.
questions.solution:
Bishop’s scoring system is used as a pre - labour scoring system to assist in predicting whether induction of labour will required.

According to Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition: If score >= 9 : Cervix is favourable & induction is successful. 
If <= 6 : Cervix is not favourable, induction is unlikely to be succesful, ripening of cervix is needed.
According to NICE guidelines: A score of >= 6 is considered favourable

For station of -1, score is 2.

For 1-2 cm dilation, score is 1.

For 0-30% effacement, score is 0.

Posterior position, score is 0.

Soft cervical consistency also equals to a score of 2.

Total score— 5.

Bishop's score:
Score
0 1 2 3
Position Posterior Middle Anterior --
Consistency Firm Medium Soft --
Effacement 0-30% 40-50% 60-70% 80%+
Dilation Closed 1-2 cm 3-4 cm 5+cm
Station -3 -2 -1/0 +1/+2

Addition factors: +1 point for each previous vaginal birth, -1 point for first time birth givers
Add the score for each factor.
Scores lower than 5 suggest labour will not begin without induction.
Scores 9 and higher indicate labour will likely begin spontaneously.
Scores 3 and lower may indicate that an induction would not be successful.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 488.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 486.

choices.text: Manual support to perineum to maintain deflexed head

questions.text: Which of the following should be done in the management of the second stage of labour, according to the most recent WHO guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Hot compress to prevent perineal tear

WHO Guidelines for 2nd stage of labour :

They are practiced to reduce perineal tears during delivery of child. They include: 

1. No routine episiotomy (Option 3)

2. Modified Ritgen's maneuver :

Manual support to perineum with right hand while delivering the head of foetus, flexing head of foetus with left hand.

3. Hot compress to the perineum 

Other options: 
Option 1: It is recommended any position that is comfortable to mother, including upright position.
Option 4: Head is delivered by maintaining Flexion, NOT Deflexion




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 429.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 129.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old first-time mother is in labour. She frequently feels the urge to urinate and bears down prematurely.
Upon examination, the foetal heart can be heard on the lateral side and there is infra umbilical fattening.
What presentation or position is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Occipito-posterior

DIAGNOSIS
• Abdominal examination 
• Inspection: The abdomen looks flat, below the umbilicus 
• Umbilical grip: The findings are: 
   • The fetal limbs are more easily felt near the midline on either side 
   • The fetal back is felt far away from the midline on the flank and often difficult to outline clearly 
   • The anterior shoulder lies far away from the midline
• Pelvic grips: The findings are: 
   • The head is not engaged 
   • The cephalic prominence (sinciput) is not felt so prominent as found in well flexed occipito-anterior.
      In direct occipito-posterior, the small sinciput is confused with breech. 




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 343, 344, 351, 367.

questions.text: Which structure does an episiotomy not cut?
questions.solution:
Obturator nerve and muscles are not cut during Episiotomy.

STRUCTURES CUT ARE:
(1) Posterior vaginal wall
(2) Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
(3) Fascia covering those muscles
(4) Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
(5) Subcutaneous tissue and skin.

questions.text: The aftercoming head of the baby in a breech delivery can be arrested by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Placenta previa
Vaginal delivery is contraindicated in Placenta previa.
Rest all can trap aftercoming head of breech
.
  • Extended head, Hydrocephalus, incompletely dilated cervix or cephalopelvic disproportion can entrap the head. At this point, a true emergency exists because significant cord compression must be assumed.
  • An incompletely dilated cervix can constrict around the neck, especially with a small preterm fetus.
Management of Head entrapment: 
  • With gentle traction on the fetal body, the cervix at times may be manually slipped over the occiput. If unsuccessful, Dührssen incisions may be needed.
  • In cases with cephalopelvic disproportion and arrest of aftercoming head, the Zavanelli maneuver or symphysiotomy are options.

questions.text: An expectant woman who was 32 weeks pregnant arrived with labour symptoms and little vaginal discharge; fibronectin was found in the cervicovaginal discharge upon analysis. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Preterm labour

Fetal Fibronectin:
  • A "glue like" protein produced by fetal cells at the interface between the chorion and decidua 
  • Present in vaginal secretions before 22 weeks and at end of pregnancy 
  • Generally not detectable between 22-34 weeks
  • Positive test at this time suggests risk of PTB, however false positive results are common 
  • Negative test: low likelihood of delivery within 7d
