questions.text: In an emergency, a pregnant woman is battling with a protracted labour. She is transported for a caesarean delivery. What should the nurse do to maintain the patient on the OT table in the proper position?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Supine with wedge under right hip

To prevent compression of IVC , a wedge is applied under right hip. The wedge under the right hip creates a left lateral inclination, which helps to increase venous return and avoid hypotension by making the gravid uterus shift to left side. 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 550.

choices.text: Fact of knowing that previous cesarean section was due to CPD

questions.text: A woman who has had a previous caesarean section arrives in labour. In which conditions are trials of conventional vaginal delivery not advised?
questions.solution:
Trial of labour after cesarean section (TOLAC) or Vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) is contraindicated in 3. Previous classical cesarean section

When there has been a previous traditional or inverted-T shaped uterine incision caesarean section, the attempt at a normal vaginal delivery is prohibited due to high chances of uterine rupture. 

Contraindications to TOLAC/VBAC:
1. Prior classic or T-shaped incision or other transmural uterine surgery
2. Contracted pelvis
3. Medical or obstetric complication that precludes vaginal delivery
4. Patient refusal
5. Inability to immediately perform emergency cesarean because of unavailable surgeon or anesthesia personnel, inadequate staff or facility


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 573.

choices.text: History of previous cesarean section due to CPD
History of previous cesarean section due to malpresentation

questions.text: In which circumstances are normal labour trials not advised?

Contraindications to VBAC:
1. Prior classic or T-shaped incision or other transmural uterine surgery
2. Contracted pelvis
3. Medical or obstetric complication that precludes vaginal delivery
4. Patient refusal
5. Inability to immediately perform emergency cesarean because of unavailable surgeon or anesthesia personnel, inadequate staff or facility

questions.text: How do we define a prolonged 1st stage of labour?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Latent phase >20 hours in nulliipara

                                     1. FIRST STAGE OF LABOR:
1. Latent phase:-
•Latent phase is preparatory phase of the cervix before the actual onset of labor.
•Normal latent phase is about 8 hours in primigravidae or 4 hours multigravida.
•The prolonged latent phase exceeds 20 hours in primigravida and 14 hours in multigravida is abnormal.

(b) Active phase:-

questions.text: Which of the following makes induction of labour less likely to be successful?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 4. Primipara woman
  • Several factors are considered as predictors of induction failure such as:
  • Bishop’s score <6, nulliparity, gestational age < 41 weeks, maternal age > 30 years, pregnancy complicated by preeclampsia, premature rupture of membranes (PROM), isolated oligohydramnios, gestational diabetes, and hypertension.
  • Primiparous women are those who are giving birth for the first time. In such women, the cervix is usually less favorable for induction of labor, as it is less likely to be effaced and dilated.
  • Therefore, induction of labor in primiparous women is associated with a higher risk of failure and increased likelihood of requiring a cesarean section.

Lochia: Early in the puerperium, sloughing of decidual tissue results in a vaginal discharge of variable quantity. The discharge is termed lochia and contains erythrocytes, shredded decidua, epithelial cells, and bacteria.
Color Duration

SEROSA Pinkish brown 4 - 10 days
ALBA Whitish yellow 10 - 28 days

choices.text: The head was engaged at the time of the presentation

questions.text: At term, a female G3P1A1 is allowed into the delivery room. Cervical dilation of 4 cm, membranes intact, and head 3/5 per abdomen palpable. When the examination is repeated 4 hours later, the cervix is still 4 cm dilated, the station is unaltered, and the cervicograph is located on the right side of the action line. Which of the following claims regarding the development of labor is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. The cervicograph status suggests that intervention is likely to be required. This is because the plotting is located on the right side of the action line which necessitates some intervention.

Other options: 
Option 1: Head was palpable 3/5 per abdomen. Hence has not entered pelvis nor enagaged.
Option 2 : Normal cervical dilatation should be 1 cm/hr. But there has been no change in the cervical dilatation over last 4 hours. So, cervicograph progress is NOT satisfactory and it implies that intervention is likely to be required.
Option 4: The graph is already on the right side of action line. Therefore, it will not touch the alert line again.

questions.text: Which of the following occiput-posterior positions is the most common?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Right Occipito-posterior 
  • Right occipito-posterior is five times more common than the left occipito-posterior.
  • Dextrorotation of the uterus and the presence of the sigmoid colon on the left disfavor LOP position.
  • In a vertex presentation where the occiput is placed posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum, it is called an occiput-posterior position. When the occiput is placed over the right sacroiliac joint, the position is called right occipitoposterior (ROP), traditionally called third position of the vertex and when placed over the left sacroiliac joint, is called left occipitoposterior (LOP), traditionally called fourth position of the vertex.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 424.

choices.text: Arrange blood and deliver placenta by Crede's method

questions.text: While performing the procedure shown in the figure below, the umbilical cord got torn. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Brant-Andrews maneuver which is controlled cord traction for delivery of placenta.
  • The next step in management is manual removal of placenta to remove the source of hemorrhage.

The Brant-Andrews method of controlled cord traction is a technique used to assist in the delivery of the placenta during the third stage of labor, aimed at minimizing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) and ensuring the safe expulsion of the placenta.

Steps:

  1. Wait for placental separation: Signs like lengthening of the umbilical cord and uterine rise indicate the placenta is ready to be delivered.
  2. Apply controlled cord traction: Gently pull on the umbilical cord while simultaneously applying counter-pressure on the uterus to prevent inversion.
  3. Monitor uterine contraction: The uterus should contract to help expel the placenta.
  4. Ensure placental integrity: Avoid excessive traction to prevent cord rupture or uterine injury.

Benefits:
 
  • Reduces the risk of uterine inversion and bleeding.
  • Facilitates safe and timely placental expulsion.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 526, 527, 758, 759.

choices.text: Wait and watch for normal vaginal delivery

questions.text: A primigravida pregnant lady was in labor with a fetus in right occipital-posterior presentation. Uterine contractions are good. Next step in the management of such a patient:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of right occipito-posterior position with adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery. Therefore the correct answer to this question will be option 2. 
 

  • Occipital-posterior (OP) presentation means that the baby's head is positioned with the occiput (back of the head) facing the mother's back. This is a less favorable position for vaginal delivery, as it can lead to a longer labor, increased pain, and a higher likelihood of interventions. However, in most cases, good uterine contractions and a primigravida status (first pregnancy) allow the possibility of a normal vaginal delivery with supportive care and monitoring.

  • Spontaneous rotation: Many fetuses in OP position will rotate to the occipital-anterior (OA) position during labor, which is more favorable for vaginal delivery. Waiting and watching is appropriate in this case as the labor progresses.



Other options:

  1. Cesarean section: This is usually indicated for failure to progress, non-reassuring fetal heart rate, or other obstetric complications. In the absence of such issues, waiting for a vaginal delivery is preferred.

  2. Start oxytocin drip: Oxytocin is used to augment labor if contractions are inadequate. However, in this case, the contractions are already good, so there's no immediate need for augmentation.

  3. Forceps delivery: This is an instrumental delivery used when the fetus is in a difficult position or if there's failure to progress, but the OP presentation itself does not necessarily require forceps delivery unless there's fetal distress or prolonged labor.

Thus, waiting and monitoring the progress of labor is the best approach for this patient with a fetus in OP presentation. 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 424-433.

questions.text: On 7th day of a normal vaginal delivery, a lady was brought to the emergency department at midnight with the complaints of loss of appetite, depression, difficulty in sleeping and occasional crying. General examination and pelvic examination were normal. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Postpartum blues is the most likely diagnosis in a postpartum woman with above clinical features from day 7.
 
  • They develop 3-5 days after delivery and resolve spontaneously within 10-14 days. 
 
  • Management involves reassurance, education and support.  

POSTPARTUM MOOD DISORDERS





Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 512.

questions.text: A primigravida with full term pregnancy and in labor presented with sign and symptoms, of dehydration. Her heart was 105 beats/minute, BP of 130/90 mm of Hg. Per abdominal examination showed a fundal height of 32 weeks, and the fetus was having right occipito transverse position. Fetal heart sounds were feeble and mild uterine contractions were felt. Per vaginal examination revealed a fully dilated cervix, head is at the level of ischial spine, caput was present and moulding was also present. Pelvis was found to be inadequate. What will be the most appropriate management of such a case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical feature is diagnostic of cephalo-pelvic disproportion. The management in this scenario would be option 2. 
 
  • Inadequate pelvis with fetal distress (feeble fetal heart sounds) and moulding of the fetal head suggest that labor is not progressing adequately. Moulding is a sign of obstructed labor, which can occur when the fetal head cannot pass through the birth canal due to cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD).
  • The right occipito-transverse position is a malposition, and while it can sometimes rotate during labor, the presence of moulding and caput suggests that the fetus is struggling to navigate the pelvic canal.
  • Fetal heart rate abnormalities and feeble fetal heart sounds are concerning for fetal distress, and this may worsen if labor continues without appropriate intervention.
  • Cesarean section is indicated when there is a failure of labor progress, mechanical obstruction (inadequate pelvis), or fetal distress, as continuing with vaginal delivery could compromise the safety of both the mother and fetus,

Other options:
 

  1. Injection oxytocin:

    • Oxytocin is used to augment or induce labor when contractions are inadequate. However, in this case, mild uterine contractions are present, and the problem appears to be mechanical (due to the inadequate pelvis and fetal distress), not one of insufficient contraction strength. Giving oxytocin could worsen the fetal distress or further obstruct the labor.

  2. Ventouse delivery:

    • Vacuum-assisted delivery (ventouse) is indicated in situations where the head is low enough in the birth canal (station 0 or +1) and there is fetal distress or a need for assistance in the second stage of labor. However, in this case, the fetal head is at the level of the ischial spine and there is inadequate pelvis, which makes a vacuum delivery potentially dangerous due to the risk of injury to both the mother and fetus.

  3. Forceps applications:

    • Forceps delivery is generally performed when the fetal head is well engaged and at or below the ischial spines. While forceps could be considered if labor is obstructed and the fetus is not in distress, in this case, the inadequate pelvis and fetal distress make forceps a less safe option. Furthermore, the head is still at the level of the ischial spine, and there is a concern about cephalopelvic disproportion.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 91, 97, 98, 424-427, 670.

questions.text: What will be the position of the uterus on 2nd postpartum day?
questions.solution:
On second day post delivery, the uterus lies two finger breadth below the umbilicus. 
 
  • After delivery, the uterus gradually involutes (shrinks and returns to its pre-pregnancy size).
  • On the first postpartum day, the uterus is usually at the level of the umbilicus.
 
  • By the second postpartum day, it typically descends slightly and can be felt about 2 finger breadths below the umbilicus.
  • The uterus continues to shrink over the next few days, and by the end of the first week postpartum, it is usually about half its size compared to before delivery and can be felt around the symphysis pubis.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 169,170.

Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 635.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence, the steps in 3rd stage of management of labour? 
(a) Check for 2nd baby 
(b) Oxytocin 10 units 
(c) Controlled cord traction 
(d) Uterine message
questions.solution:
AMTSL(Active management of third stage of labour):
Done in all females in Labour and is the best method to prevent PPH.

Components:
  1. Injecting utero tonic to mother after delivery of baby (Most Imp. step)
  2. Delayed cord clamping
  3. Deliver placenta by controlled cord traction: Modified Brandt Andrew's technique
  4. Intermittent assessment of uterine tone.
Uterine Massage is a part of treatment PPH.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 507.

questions.text:
What is the right sequence of events of labour? 
(i) Engagement 
(ii) Restitution 
(iii) External Rotation 
(iv) Crowning
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events during labor is as follows:

1. Engagement: This is the first stage of labor where the fetal head descends into the pelvic cavity and gets fixed in the maternal pelvis.
2. Crowning: This is the second stage of labor where the widest part of the fetal head distends the vulva just before delivery.
3. Restitution: This is the third stage of labor where the fetal head rotates back to its original position in line with the fetal body.
4. External Rotation: This is the final stage of labor where the fetal shoulders rotate to the anteroposterior position and the baby is delivered.






Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 420.

choices.text: 8 contractions in 60 mins with cervical changes

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for Preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Criteria for preterm labor (Herron's)
Regular uterine contraction (>4contractions in 20 minutes or 8 contractions in 60 mins) and Gestational age 20-37 weeks with one of the following 
1.  More than 80% effaced cervix 
2. Cervical dilation > 1cm
3. Progressive cervical changes
 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 294,295 .

questions.text: A multipara ANC patient at 36+6 weeks PoG has a fetus with transverse lie, not in labor. The patient is otherwise asymptomatic and the liquor is adequate. What is the next line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
• There is no mechanism of labor in transverse lie and an average size baby fails to pass through an average size pelvis.
  • When the diagnosis of a singleton fetus in transverse lie is made before the onset of labor and in the absence of contraindications to a vaginal birth, we perform external version (ECV) to cephalic presentation at 37+0 to 37+6 weeks of gestation, as amniotic fluid volume is maximal and uterine tone and fetal weight are less than later in gestation, which likely improves success rates.
  • Abundant amniotic fluid (as in this patient) improves the success of ECV.
  • Patient counseling includes a discussion regarding small but real risks for placental abruption, preterm labor, and fetal compromise. Bradycardia is common during or following ECV, but emergent cesarean rates are ≤0.5 percent. Uterine rupture, fetomaternal hemorrhage, alloimmunization, amnionic fluid embolism, and maternal or fetal deaths are rare. Overall, compared with expectant management, perinatal morbidity and mortality rates are not greater with ECV.
  • Even alter successful ECV, several reports suggest that the cesarean delivery rate does not completely revert to the baseline or vertex presentations. Specially, dystocia, malpresentation, and non-reassuring fetal heart patterns may be more common in these fetuses who have undergone successful ECV.

Fig: External cephalic version. With an attempted forward roll, clockwise pressure is exerted against the fetal poles.


Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 528.

choices.text: Rupture of membranes and confirm cord prolapse

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a low-risk pregnancy presents at 39 weeks for a normal health check. Her vitals are stable. On PV, her cervix is 4 cm dilated. A repeat PV after 4 hours shows that her cervix is 6 cm dilated. The fetal head is at +2 station and membranes are absent. Liquor is clear and uterine contractions are good. Fetal heart rate is 150 BPM and reassuring. What is the appropriate course of management?
questions.solution:
• The appropriate course of management for this 28-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks with a low-risk pregnancy, currently 6 cm dilated, fetal head at +2 station, absent membranes, clear liquor, good uterine contractions, and a reassuring fetal heart rate of 150 BPM, is to wait and watch.
 
  • The patient is low-risk, stable, and in active labor, with cervical dilation progressing from 4 cm to 6 cm over 4 hours, indicating that labor is advancing normally. The fetal head is at +2 station, showing descent into the birth canal, a positive indicator of labor progression. The absence of membranes suggests spontaneous rupture (SROM), which is typical during labor.
 
  • Clear liquor and a reassuring fetal heart rate (150 BPM) indicate fetal well-being, while effective uterine contractions support continued labor progress.
 
  • Given these favorable clinical signs, and no immediate need for intervention such as abnormal fetal heart rate patterns or maternal distress, the best approach is to monitor labor closely. This allows for natural labor progression while maintaining vigilance over maternal and fetal health through periodic assessments. If labor dystocia or fetal distress develops, appropriate interventions can be initiated at that time.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 425.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 373-375.

questions.text: A 30 year old multigravida at 35 weeks of gestation came to the Opd for regular checkup. In this patient, which of the following Leopold's maneuvers is done to assess the lie of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and the attitude of the fetal head are assessed using Leopold's maneuvers. These maneuvers consist of four obstetric grips:

1. Leopold's 1 (Fundal grip): This maneuver evaluates the uterine fundus, helping to identify the fetal lie and determine whether the fetal pole is cephalic (head down) or podalic (buttocks down). A breech presentation typically feels like a large, nodular mass, while the head presents as a hard, round, and more mobile structure.

2. Leopold's 2 (Lateral grip): This grip assesses the fetal orientation. The examiner places their palms on either side of the maternal abdomen, applying gentle but deep pressure. On one side, a hard, resistant structure (the back) is felt, while the other side reveals numerous small, irregular, and mobile parts (the fetal extremities). The position of the back—whether anterior, transverse, or posterior—helps determine the fetal orientation.

3. Leopold's 3 (Pawlik's grip/1st pelvic grip): This maneuver assesses the presenting part of the fetus. The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen, just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass, usually the head, will be palpated.

4. Leopold's 4 (2nd pelvic grip): This grip evaluates the engagement and attitude of the fetal head. The examiner positions themselves at the mother's feet, placing the fingertips of both hands on either side of the presenting part. They apply inward pressure and then slide their fingers along the axis of the pelvic inlet to assess the engagement of the fetal head.

questions.text: A 28-year-old term primigravida was admitted with complaints of draining per vaginum. She delivered a male baby by assisted vaginal delivery as face to pubis. What is the most probable type of pelvis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In an anthropoid pelvis, the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet is longer than the transverse diameter. This favors engagement of the fetal head in the occipitoposterior position. During labor, as internal rotation occurs, the occiput may rotate posteriorly, leading to a face-to-pubis delivery — where the baby’s face emerges beneath the symphysis pubis.

A face-to-pubis delivery is characteristic of the anthropoid pelvis because the fetal occiput remains posterior throughout the mechanism of labor.

Other options:

  • Gynecoid pelvis: Most common and ideal type for vaginal delivery; usually results in occipitoanterior positions.

  • Android pelvis: Has a heart-shaped inlet with narrow anterior segment; associated with deep transverse arrest and malrotation.

  • Platypelloid pelvis: Flat pelvis with a short anteroposterior diameter; engagement is difficult, and transverse lie is common.

questions.text: Which of these steps is followed first for the management of shoulder dystocia after McRoberts maneuver?
questions.solution:
In shoulder dystocia, after attempting the McRoberts maneuver (flexing maternal hips and legs over the abdomen), the next immediate step is usually:

  • Apply gentle suprapubic pressure

    • The pressure is directed just above the pubic bone, aimed at dislodging the anterior shoulder from behind the pubic symphysis.

    • Helps reduce the bisacromial diameter and facilitates delivery of the fetal shoulder. 

Other options — brief:

  1. Immediate cesarean section: Not feasible in acute shoulder dystocia; usually done only if vaginal maneuvers fail before labor progresses.

  2. Rotate posterior shoulder to 90 degrees: Done if suprapubic pressure fails (Woods or Rubin maneuver).

  3. Flex the legs over the abdomen: This is the McRoberts maneuver, usually attempted first to widen the pelvic outlet.

questions.text: The Ischieal spine corresponds to which Vertebral level in Normal Anatomical position
questions.solution:
• The Ischial spine corresponds to the S5 Vertebral level.
  • The closest option is The Coccyx, hence it is the correct answer.
  • The Ischial spine forms a part of plane of least pelvic dimension which comprises of Lower border of Symphysis Pubis, Tip of Ischial spine and 5th Sacral vertebra.
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 82.

questions.text: A 28y old female at 40 weeks of Gestation is in the Second stage of labor for the last two hours.PV- Head is at +3 station and adequate contractions. The suture is in AP diameter and Caput is present. which is thr most appropriate mode of delivery?
questions.solution:
• In the given scenario , Outlet forceps would be the best treatment as the fetus is at +3 station and suture in AP diameter and has caput.
  • Indications for using outlet forceps -
  1. Scalp visible at Introitus ,
  2. Fetal skull has reached Pelvic floor,
  3. Saggital suture in AP direction but rotation <45 degrees,
  4. Fetal head is at or on the perineum.
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 533.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is ventouse delivery contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ventouse delivery is not recommended for preterm infants as it heightens the risk of scalp avulsion or sub-aponeurotic hemorrhage.

Contraindications for vacuum delivery include:

Any presentation other than vertex (such as face or breech)
Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks of gestation)
Suspected fetal coagulation disorders
Fetal macrosomia (estimated weight greater than 4 kg)
A vacuum extractor is a tool utilized in operative vaginal delivery that creates suction between the device and the fetal scalp.

The instrument comprises:

A suction cup
A vacuum generator
A traction tubing device
The suction cup is positioned on the fetal head at a location near the occiput known as the flexion point. This is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, approximately 6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is the drug Oxytocin contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin is contraindicated in cases of fetal malpresentation.

Uses of Oxytocin:
1.To accelerate abortion and manage bleeding following uterine evacuation.
2.To induce labor by ripening the cervix prior to induction.
3.For augmentation of labor.
4. Active management of the third stage of labor to minimise blood loss and control postpartum hemorrhage.

Contraindications of Oxytocin:
1. Hypersensitivity to oxytocin
2. In cases where vaginal delivery is contraindicated, such as invasive cervical carcinoma, active herpes genitalis, total placenta previa, vasa previa, and cord presentation or prolapse of the cord
3. Significant cephalopelvic disproportion
4. Unfavorable fetal positions or presentations, such as transverse lies.

questions.text: What is the level of the uterus immediately after delivery?
questions.solution:
After delivery, the uterus is positioned below the umbilicus.



The involution of the uterus can be clinically evaluated by observing the height of the fundus in relation to the symphysis pubis.

To assess this, the uterus should be centralized, and the fundal height is measured above the symphysis pubis using a measuring tape. Immediately after delivery, the fundus is approximately 13.5 cm above the symphysis pubis, which can also be described as being below the umbilicus.

In the first 24 hours post-delivery, the fundal height remains relatively constant. Following this period, there is a consistent reduction in height, decreasing by 1.25 cm every 24 hours. By the end of the second week, the uterus typically descends into the pelvic cavity.

The rate of involution continues to decelerate until about 6 weeks postpartum, at which point the uterus nearly returns to its normal size.

questions.text: In a primigravida what is a satisfactory dilation rate?
questions.solution:
• In normal labor progress, the rate of cervical dilatation is different for primigravida and multigravida.

Friedman’s curve (classic teaching):

  • Primigravida: 1.2 cm/hr

  • Multigravida: 1.5 cm/hr

WHO/modern guidelines:

  • Progress may be slower as per Zhang curve.

So, in a primigravida, a satisfactory dilation rate = 1.2 cm/hr.

questions.text: Identify the type of pelvis in the given image.
questions.solution:
A round-shaped pelvic inlet is characteristic of the gynecoid pelvis.



The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on its shape was established by Caldwell and Moloy.

The greatest transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet divides the pelvis into anterior and posterior segments. The shapes of these segments are used to classify the pelvis into the following types:

Gynecoid: Round-shaped inlet, typical for childbirth.
Anthropoid: Oval-shaped inlet, wider in the anteroposterior dimension.
Android: Heart-shaped inlet, typically found in males.
Platypelloid: Flat-shaped inlet, with a wider transverse diameter relative to the anteroposterior dimension.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium?
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of vaginal discharge during the puerperium is Lochia rubra > Lochia serosa > Lochia alba.

Lochia refers to the vaginal discharge that occurs during the first fortnight of the puerperium, originating from the uterine body, cervix, and vagina.

Types of Lochia Based on Color Variation:
1. Lochia Rubra:

Timing: Occurs from 1 to 4 days post-delivery.
Color: Red.
Composition: Contains blood, fragments of fetal membranes and decidua, vernix caseosa, lanugo, and meconium.
2. Lochia Serosa:

Timing: Observed from 5 to 9 days post-delivery.
Color: Yellowish, pink, or pale brown.
Composition: Primarily made up of leukocytes, wound exudate, mucus from the cervix, and microorganisms (such as anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci). The presence of bacteria is not necessarily indicative of infection unless accompanied by clinical signs of sepsis.
3. Lochia Alba:

Timing: Seen from 10 to 15 days post-delivery.
Color: Pale white.
Composition: Rich in decidual cells, leukocytes, mucus, cholesterol crystals, and granular epithelial cells, along with microorganisms.

questions.text: During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following may cause this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression. In late deceleration the fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contractions. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia. Causes of late decelerations:
• Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
• Excessive uterine contractions
• Excessive use of oxytocin
• Epidural anesthesia
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition • Page no 569

questions.text: When is cord clamping ideally done?
questions.solution: As per AMTSL guidelines cord clamping is done within 1-3 min of delivery of the Fetus. AMTSL guidelines by WHO- Immediate administration of Utertonics, controlled cord traction , delayed cord clamping and postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment. Ref - Williams obstetrics 26th edition Page 506

questions.text: In which of the following situations can outlet Forceps be used?
questions.solution:
Outlet forceps can be used when the head of the fetus is
At the perineum.

Criteria for outlet forceps delivery:
• Scalp at introitus without separating labia
• Skull at the pelvic floor
• Sagittal suture in anterioposterior diameter, right or left occiput anterior, occiput anterior
• Fetal head on the perineum
• Rotation less than 45 degrees Ref Dutta textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page -532

questions.text: In which of the following situations is Ventouse Delivery Contraindicated?
questions.solution: It is contraindicated in Preterm babies as it increases the risk of scalp avulsion or sub- aponeurotic haemorrhage. Other Contraindication - Any presentation other than vertex, Suspected fetal coagulation disorder, Fetal Macrosomia. Ref- Dutta textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page 660-664

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for early cord clamping?
questions.solution:
Early cord clamping is indicated in
• Birth asphyxia
• Rh isoimmunisation
• Diabetic mother.
According to AlIMS Protocols in Neonatology, in uncomplicated preterm birth delayed cord clamping should be attempted. Benefits of delayed cord clamping for up to 60 seconds is an increase in total body iron stores, expanded blood volume and a decrease in anemia incidence in the neonate.
Williams Obstetrics 24th edition • Page no : 539

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
• Ritgen's maneuver is used during vaginal delivery to control the delivery of the fetal head and reduce the risk of perineal tears.

  • Technique: The perineum is supported with one hand, while the other hand applies pressure on the fetal chin through the perineum to control head flexion and slow its delivery.

  • Other maneuvers:

    • Pinard's maneuver: Used to rotate a malpositioned fetal head (occiput posterior) to anterior position.

    • Zavanelli maneuver: Replacing a prolapsed or impacted fetal head back into the uterus for cesarean delivery.

    • Lovset's maneuver: Used to deliver the fetal shoulders in a transverse lie.

Key point: Ritgen’s maneuver specifically controls the head during crowning to prevent perineal trauma.


Reference:DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page no 160,447-448

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of inducing labor?
questions.solution:
• Placenta previa (placenta covering the cervical os) is a contraindication to labor induction because vaginal delivery can lead to massive maternal hemorrhage. Cesarean section is the mode of delivery in such cases.

Indications for labor induction include:

Oligohydramnios – low amniotic fluid increases risk of cord compression and fetal compromise.

Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) – induction reduces the risk of infection after prolonged rupture.

Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (e.g., preeclampsia) – induction may be necessary if maternal or fetal condition is worsening.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics 25th edition page no 503,568,1113

questions.text: What level of proteinuria is required to identify severe preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
300 mg

Criteria for the diagnosis of preeclampsia
  • Systolic blood pressure \(\geq\) 140 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure \(\geq\) 90 mm Hg on two occasions at least four hours apart after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive patient and
  • Proteinuria \(\geq\) 0.3 grams in a 24-hour urine specimen or protein (mg/dL) creatinine (mg/dL) ratio \(\geq\)0.3
  • Dipstick 1+ if a quantitative measurement is unavailable.
In patients with new-onset hypertension without proteinuria, the new onset of any of the following is diagnosis of preeclampsia:
  • Platelet count <100,000/microliter
  • Serum creatinine > 1.1 mg/dL or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease
  • Liver transaminases at least twice the normal concentrations
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Cerebral or visual symptoms

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 689.

questions.text: What dose of dexamethasone is given to the woman in preparation for a premature birth?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

Antenatal Corticosteroids Dosing:
• Two 12 mg doses Betamethosone IM 24 h apart
• Four 6-mg doses Dexamethasone IM q12h

Because treatment for less than 24 hours may be beneficial and reduce neonatal morbidity and mortality rates, a first dose of antenatal corticosteroids is administered regardless of the ability to complete additional doses before delivery (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 2020a).

*No benefit with accelerated dosing, even if delivery appears imminent

Steroid dosage Memorizing Trick-
Dexamethasone- Dexa similar to Hexa- 6- 6 mg every 12 hours 4 injections
Betamethasone- B- 2nd letter of albhabet- 2 dosage twice the dose of Dexa and gap- 12 mg 2 injections 24 hours apart



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 802.

questions.text: What carbetocin dosage is used for PPH?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. 100 microgram IV
 
  • Carbetocin (long acting oxytocin) is typically administered as a single 100 microgram intravenous (IV) dose immediately after the delivery of the baby to help prevent PPH.
  • Carbetocin 100 µg intravenously is recommended for elective cesarean section for the prevention of PPH and for the reduction of additional uterotonics in the 2018 Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada guideline



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 477.
Chao YS, McCormack S. Carbetocin for the Prevention of Post-Partum Hemorrhage: A Review of Clinical Effectiveness, Cost-Effectiveness, and Guidelines [Internet]. Ottawa (ON): Canadian Agency for Drugs and Technologies in Health; 2019 Jul 29. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546425/

questions.text: Which medication is under Category B (sufficient research in pregnant women has that not established a prenatal risk)?
questions.solution:
Brimonidine is classified as a category B drug.
Timolol/Latanoprost/Dorzolamide all are category C drugs. 

  • The only antiglaucoma medication categorized in Category B is Brimonidine, and all others are in Category C.
  • Most evidence on glaucoma medications in pregnancy comes from single case reports or animal studies with the limitations that these impose.
  • Theoretically, glaucoma medications may damage the fetus; however, they may not have substantial clinical significance with routine dosages and no topical antiglaucoma agents have strong evidence of safety to the fetus based on the human studies
 






Reference: Razeghinejad, M Reza. “Glaucoma medications in pregnancy.” Oman journal of ophthalmology vol. 11,3 (2018): 195-199. doi:10.4103/ojo.OJO_212_2017, URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6219332/

questions.text: A patient with Placenta grade 3, 35+3 weeks pregnancy, AFI=5 and absent end diastolic flow in Doppler; What is the next step in management?

questions.text: What is the postpartum haemorrhage treatment device known as a Bakri balloon's maximum capacity?
questions.solution:
Its maximum capacity is usually 500ml.

Bakri balloon is inserted into the uterine cavity and the balloon is inflated with normal saline (200–500 mL). It is kept for 4–6 hours. But maximum capacity is 500 ml.
It is successful in atonic PPH. This can avoid hysterectomy in 78% cases. It is considered the first line surgical intervention for most women with atonic PPH.

questions.text: A 20-week-pregnant woman complains of vaginal bleeding. On speculum examination, the OS is open, but no products have emerged. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Inevitable abortion  

DEFINITION: It is the clinical type of abortion where the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.
CLINICAL FEATURES: The patient, having the features of threatened miscarriage, develops the following manifestations: (1) Increased vaginal bleeding. (2) Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature. (3) Internal examination reveals dilated internal os of the cervix through which the products of conception are felt. On occasion, the features may develop quickly without prior clinical evidence of threatened miscarriage. In the second trimester, however, it may start with rupture of the membranes or intermittent lower abdominal pain (mini labor).
MANAGEMENT is aimed: (a) to accelerate the process of expulsion. (b) to maintain strict asepsis. General measures: Excessive bleeding should be promptly controlled by administering Methergine 0.2 mg if the cervix is dilated and the size of the uterus is less than 12 weeks. The blood loss is corrected by intravenous (IV) fluid therapy and blood transfusion.
Active Treatment
  • Before 12 weeks: (1) Dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage of the uterine cavity by blunt curette using analgesia or under general anesthesia. (2) Alternatively, suction evacuation followed by curettage is done.
  • After 12 weeks: (1) !e uterine contraction is accelerated by oxytocin drip (10 units in 500 mL of normal saline) 40–60 drops per minute. If the fetus is expelled and the placenta is retained, it is removed by ovum forceps, if lying separated. If the placenta is not separated, digital separation followed by its evacuation is to be done under general anesthesia.
Other options- 
  • Incomplete abortion- will have history of Product of conception coming out 
  • Complete abortion- initial bleeding and POC came out now bleeding stopped and OS is closed.
  • Missed abortion- history of brown discharge now OS closed. 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 189.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the active management of the third stage of labor ?
questions.solution:
Delayed cord clamping is advised, not immediate cord clamping

Components of AMTSL:
  1. Administration of a uterotonic drug within 1 minute of birth of the baby (oxytocin 10 IU IM is the uterotonic of choice; in its absence, use 0.2 mg ergometrine IM or 1 mL syntometrine IM or 600 mcg misoprostol).
  2. Delayed cord clamping.
  3. Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction- Modified Brandt Andrews technique.
  4. Intermittent assessment of uterine Note: Earlier, uterine massage was the recommended 4th step in AMTSL. However, it is now a part of the treatment of PPH. The step which was never included in AMTSL was early cord clamping.

questions.text: How is shoulder dystocia treated?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Supra pubic pressure 
  • The McRoberts maneuver is often selected first. With it, legs are lifted from stirrups, hips are sharply flexed up onto the abdomen, and knees remain flexed. 
  • During McRoberts maneuver, an assistant can apply downward and laterally directed suprapubic pressure.
  • Head and neck should be grasped and taken posteriorly while suprapubic pressure is applied by an assistant slightly toward the side of fetal chest.
  • This will reduce the bisacromial diameter and rotate the anterior shoulder toward the oblique diameter. This maneuver is simple as well as effective. It needs only one assistant.

Management of Shoulder Dystocia (HELPERR Mnemonic)

  1. H – Help: Call for assistance.
  2. E – Evaluate for Episiotomy: Not always needed but may help.
  3. L – Legs (McRoberts Maneuver): Sharp flexion of maternal hips to the abdomen to widen the pelvic outlet (Option 1).
  4. P – Pressure (Suprapubic Pressure): Manual pressure applied above the pubic symphysis to push the fetal shoulder downward and dislodge it (Correct answer - Option 2).
  5. E – Enter (Internal Rotation Maneuvers - Rubin/Woods Screw Maneuver): Rotate the fetus’s shoulder by 90 degrees (related to Option 3 but not for the posterior shoulder).
  6. R – Remove Posterior Arm: Deliver the posterior shoulder first to reduce the shoulder width.
  7. R – Roll the patient (Gaskin Maneuver): Turn the mother to all fours to facilitate delivery.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 501-504.

questions.text:
Which of the following is done in atonic PPH ?
a. Uterine massage is given. 
b. Ergometrine IV is administered to all
c. B-Lynch suture, if medical management fails
d. Suction of uterus
questions.solution:
• Uterine massage is given in atonic PPH. However, it is not the first step, first step is medical management.
  • Ergometrine is given IM not IV

STEPS OF MANAGEMENT

Medical Management:
Uterotonic medications are provided after an atonic PPH diagnosis in order to raise uterine tone.
Misoprostol (PGEI), methyl ergometrine and oxytocin infusion given quickly:
Mechanical Method: If the medical approach fails, try the mechanical approach.
Bimanual compression and/or massage: Bimanual uterine compression must begin right away to control atonic postpartum haemorrhage and may need to last for 20 to 30 minutes or longer.
Uterine packing:
Balloon Tamponade: Condom catheter, Sengstaken-Blakemore esophageal catheter, or Bakri balloon catheter are all options for balloon tamponade.
Surgical Techniques: If the aforementioned management techniques don't work, think about surgery.
B-Lynch suture.
Uterine artery ligation: 90% of the blood flow to the uterus during pregnancy comes from the uterine arteries, which are tied off. In 75–90% of cases, direct ligation of these conveniently located vessles can successfully reduce haemorrhage.
Internal iliac artery ligation.
Radiographic embolization of pelvic vessels
Hysterectomy: definite method.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 777-779.

questions.text: When a midwife was checking on a pregnant woman who was in labour, she unexpectedly discovered a cord prolapse. What will be the next step?

Cord should not be handled to prevent vasospasm.

questions.text:
For polyhydramnios, a 25-year-old pregnant woman is taking indomethacin (25 mg TDS) till 35 weeks.
What kind of anomaly may the foetus have if she went into labour right away?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

 
  • Prostaglandins (PGE1) is responsible for keeping the ductus arteriosus patent.
  • Indomethacin inhibits prostaglandin production.
  • So, there is increased risk of neonatal complications including oligohydramnios, renal failure, necrotizing enterocolitis, intraventricular hemorrhage, and closure of the patent ductus arteriosus have been reported with the use of Indomethacin.

questions.text: What criteria is used to diagnose an abdominal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Studdiford's Criteria is used to diagnose Primary Abdominal Pregnancy.

Abdominal pregnancy
• Criteria for diagnosis - Studdiford's Criteria
   1. Presence of normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy
   2. No evidence of uteroplacental fistula
   3. The presence of a pregnancy related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary
       implantation after primary tubal abortion

Rubins criteria- Cervical Pregnancy
Spielberg's criteria - Ovarian pregnancy

questions.text: A pregnant woman with high blood pressure presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and foetal movement loss. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Abruption. A pregnant woman with high BP, abdominal pain and abrupt fetal loss can be due to Placental abruption.
 
  • Separation of the placenta—either partially or totally—from its implantation site before delivery is called placental abruption or abruptio placentae.
  • The signs and symptoms of placental abruption can vary considerably. Classically, affected women have a sudden onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.
  • High BP is usually the predisposing factor for abruption of placenta. 
  • Bleeding typically insinuates itself between the membranes and uterine wall, ultimately escaping through the cervix to cause external hemorrhage.
  • Placental abruption can also be associated with fetal compromise.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 749, 750, 753.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 237.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Vulval Hematoma
The picture is self explanatory and depicts a Vulval Hematoma.
 
  • A tense, tender swelling of varying size rapidly develops, encroaches on the vaginal lumen, and causes overlying skin or epithelium to become ecchymotic. However, symptoms of pelvic pressure, pain, or inability to void should prompt evaluation.
  • Vulvovaginal hematomas are managed according to their size, location, duration since delivery, and expansion. If bleeding ceases, then small- to moderate-sized hematomas may be treated expectantly until absorbed. Cool packs and analgesics are supportive care, and an inability to void merits catheter drainage. But, if pain is severe or if the hematoma continues to enlarge, surgical exploration is preferable.
  • For repair, an incision is made at the point of maximal distention, blood and clots are evacuated, and bleeding points ligated.


Bartholin gland cysts  are cysts of the Bartholin gland, found in the posterolateral inferior third of the vagina and are associated with the labia majora.

questions.text: You are presented with a G3P2L0 pregnant woman who is nine weeks along in her pregnancy. She had conization a year ago, but there hasn't been a recurrence according to a PAP smear. Additionally, during her past two pregnancies, at 30 and 32 weeks, she experienced preterm births. What will you do to manage this patient going forward?
questions.solution:
Next step should be USG to see cervical length
First a transvaginal sonography is done to see if the cervical length is less than 2.5 cm
 
  • Women with a history of one or more spontaneous mid-trimester losses or preterm births who are undergoing transvaginal sonographic surveillance of cervical length should be offered an ultrasound- indicated cerclage if the cervix is 25 mm or less and before 24 weeks of gestation.
  • TVS is used to determine if cerclage is needed. In those with any prior spontaneous preterm birth, the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (2016) recommends transvaginal cervical length screening. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2021) also recommends this screening.
  • Surveillance extends between 16 and 24 weeks’ gestation, and examinations, are performed every 1 to 4 weeks. In those without prior preterm birth or in those with multifetal gestation, cervical length is not specifically measured. The cervix should be viewed during the sonographic anatomical anatomy examination at 18 to 22 weeks’ gestation. 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 205, 206.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 160, 161.

questions.text: A lady presented with 7 weeks amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. CRL was 5 mm with well formed gestational sac with calculated GA of 5.6 weeks on TVS. Next line of management:
questions.solution:
Next step is Wait for another 1 week and repeat TVS
Since the CRL is less than 7 weeks, we should wait for one more week for the cardiac activity to come.

RCOG has given definite criteria for diagnosis of missed abortion:
  • If the crown rump length (CRL) is > 7 mm and there is no embryonic cardiac activity, this is defined as a missed miscarriage.
  • If the mean gestational sac diameter (MSD) is >25 mm and there is no yolk sac or embryonic pole, this is defined as an empty sac miscarriage.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 202.

questions.text: A female patient has had lower abdominal pain and amenorrhea for the past eight weeks. A lateral adnexa with a lump and thick endometrium was discovered on USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Possible diagnosis in a female with 8 weeks of amenorrhea, pain in the left lower abdomen, and thick endometrium with a mass in the lateral adnexa on an ultrasound is ectopic pregnancy.

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.
 
  • The classic triad is amenorrhea that is followed by pain and vaginal bleeding.
  • With tubal rupture, lower abdominal and pelvic pain is usually severe and frequently described as sharp, stabbing, or tearing. Some degree of vaginal spotting or bleeding is reported by most women with tubal pregnancy.

Endometrial findings in TVS:
  1. With ectopic pregnancy, a trilaminar endometrial pattern is characteristic.
  2. First, a pseudosac is a fluid collection between the endometrial layers and conforms to the cavity shape. If a pseudosac is noted, the risk of ectopic pregnancy is increased.
  3. Second, a decidual cyst is identified as an anechoic area lying within the endometrium but remote from the canal and often at the endometrial–myometrial border. Tis may represent early decidual breakdown that precedes cast formation.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 221-223.

questions.text: A female patient diagnosed with amenorrhea two months ago complained of sudden abdominal pain with an adnexal mass and a positive urine pregnancy test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis is ectopic pregnancy.

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.
 
  • The classic triad is amenorrhea that is followed by pain and vaginal bleeding.
  • With tubal rupture, lower abdominal and pelvic pain is usually severe and frequently described as sharp, stabbing, or tearing. Some degree of vaginal spotting or bleeding is reported by most women with tubal pregnancy.
  • An initial urine β-hCG assay, urinalysis, and measure of hemoglobin or hematocrit are routine. A complete blood count (CBC) to assess the white blood cell count may be preferred if serious inection is a possible diagnosis. A positive urine pregnancy test result should prompt a serum β-hCG assay for those with pain or bleeding. In ectopic pregnancy, increase in serum beta-hCG after 48 hours is less than 66%.

Endometrial findings in TVS:
  1. With ectopic pregnancy, a trilaminar endometrial pattern is characteristic.
  2. First, a pseudosac is a fluid collection between the endometrial layers and conforms to the cavity shape. If a pseudosac is noted, the risk of ectopic pregnancy is increased.
  3. Second, a decidual cyst is identified as an anechoic area lying within the endometrium but remote from the canal and often at the endometrial–myometrial border. This may represent early decidual breakdown that precedes cast formation.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 221-223.

questions.text: Which of the following has the greatest likelihood of succeeding in an external cephalic version during a breech presentation?

  • 1. Oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid) reduces the chances of success for external cephalic version (ECV) because the lack of fluid limits the ability to rotate the baby.

  • 2. Breech with extended legs (frank breech) is more challenging for ECV because the baby’s legs are extended and "locked" near the head, making rotation more difficult.

Tocolysis

questions.text: Incidence of breech presentation at term is about:
questions.solution:
Breech presentation occurs in 3–4% of term deliveries and is more common in preterm deliveries and nulliparous women.
 
  • Epidemiology of Breech presentation: Breech presentation occurs in 3% to 4% of all term pregnancies. A higher percentage of breech presentations occurs with less advanced gestational age. At 32 weeks, 7% of fetuses are breech, and 25% are breech at 28 weeks or less.
 
  • Specifically, following 1 breech delivery, the recurrence rate for the second pregnancy was nearly 10%, and for a subsequent third pregnancy, it was 27%. Some have also described prior cesarean delivery as increasing the incidence of breech presentation twofold.
 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 434.
Gray CJ, Shanahan MM. Breech Presentation. [Updated 2022 Nov 6]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448063/

questions.text: What happens to the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
In preeclampsia, both GFR and renal plasma flow decrease by 30% to 40% compared with normal pregnancy of the same duration.

During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) rise appreciably. With preeclampsia, several reversible physiological changes ensue. Of clinical importance, renal perfusion and GFR are slightly reduced. Most of the decrement in GFR is from increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance.

End organ damage occurs in Pre-eclampsia. 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 697.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by hyperemesis gravidarum's metabolic changes?
questions.solution:
• Correct option 1:Hyperthyroidism
  • alpha-subunit of hCG is structurally similar to TSH.
  • So excess hCG in Hyperemesis gravidarum stimulates TSH-receptors in Thyroid gland which causes increase release of thyroid hormones. hCG influences thyroid function early in pregnancy when its levels are high.
  • Excessive hCG secretion may cause hyperthyroidism in patients with hyperemesis gravidarum or trophoblastic tumors.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 186, 191, 239, 851.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of breech presentation?
questions.solution:
At 28 weeks 25% breech presentation is seen but at time of delivery 3% breech is seen.

Causes of breech presentation
1. Prematurity ( at 30 wks. 25% breech )
2. Uterine abnormalities
3. Fetal factors prevent spontaneous version
4. Placenta previa
5. fibroids
6. Hydrocephaly
7. unknown

The following are the known factors responsible for breech presentation: 
  1. Prematurity: It is the most common cause of breech presentation.
  2. Factors preventing spontaneous version: (a) Breech with extended legs (b) Twins (c) Oligohydramnios (d) Congenital malformation of the uterus such as septate or bicornuate uterus, (e) Short cord, relative or absolute, (f) Intrauterine death of the fetus.
  3. Favorable adaptation: (a) Hydrocephalus—big head can be well accommodated in the wide fundus, (b) Placenta previa, (c) Contracted pelvis, (d) Cornu-fundal attachment of the placenta—minimizes the space of the fundus where the smaller head can be placed comfortably.
  4. Undue mobility of the fetus: (a) Hydramnios, (b) Multiparae with lax abdominal wall.
  5. Fetal abnormality: Trisomies 13, 18, 21, anencephaly and myotonic dystrophy due to alteration of fetal muscular tone and mobility.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 435.

questions.text: What is the most common procedure indicative of a posterior cleft?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Drainage of Pelvic Abscess

A posterior cleft refers to a disruption or defect in the rectovaginal septum, often as a result of infection or trauma.
The most common sign of a posterior cleft is the drainage of a pelvic abscess, especially when there is a localized infection that leads to the formation of an abscess in the pelvic region.

Pelvic abscess is a life-threatening collection of infected fluid in the pouch of Douglas, fallopian tube, ovary, or parametric tissue. Usually, a pelvic abscess occurs as a complication after operative procedures. It starts as pelvic cellulitis or hematoma spreads to parametrial tissue.
A pelvic abscess produces a fluctuating tender swelling in the POD, bulging into the posterior fornix.

TREATMENT of Pelvic Abscess: 
 
  • General: Systemic antibiotics should cover anaerobic as well as aerobic microorganisms (broad spectrum): Cefoxitin 1–2 g IV every 6–8 hours and gentamicin 2 mg/ kg IV per 24 hours and metronidazole 500 mg IV 8 hourly are started. Antibiotic regimen may have to be changed depending upon the sensitivity report.
  • Surgery: Posterior colpotomy is the definitive surgery to drain the pus through posterior fornix. The loculi should be broken with finger.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 143.
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 341.

The risk of uterine scar rupture in women with a prior lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is generally around 1-2% during a trial of labor

questions.text: What does the phrase "couvelaire uterus" refer to?
questions.solution:
Uteroplacental apoplexy is a rare but nonfatal complication of severe forms of placental abruption. It occurs when vascular damage within the placenta causes hemorrhaging that progresses to and infiltrates the wall of the uterus. It is a syndrome that can only be diagnosed by direct visualization or biopsy (or both). It has gun powdered appearance. 
 
  • At the time of cesarean delivery, it is common to and widespread extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature and beneath the serosa. This phenomenon is named after Couvelaire, who in the early 1900s termed it as uteroplacental apoplexy.
  • These myometrial hemorrhages may incite uterine atony. Effusions of blood may collect beneath the tubal serosa, between the leaves of the broad ligaments, in the ovaries, or in the peritoneal cavity.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 753.

choices.text: Perform an elective cesarean section at 39 weeks of pregnancy
Perform an external cephalic version at 36 weeks of pregnancy
Induction of labor, if not delivered till 40 weeks

questions.text: A 26 years old primipara with normal BMI attended the antenatal clinic. She is having amenorrhoea of 35 weeks and a single live fetus in breech presentation. USG demonstrated complete breech presentation and adequate liquor volume. There was no other abnormality on USG scan. Her pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated. What should be done next:
questions.solution:
• The next step is to perform an external cephalic version at 36 weeks of pregnancy to convert into cephalic presentation for normal vaginal delivery.
  • Primigravida with breech is relative contraindication to C-Section
 
  • External Cephalic Version (ECV) is a procedure in which the fetus is manually turned from the breech position to a head-down (vertex) position. It is typically done between 36 to 37 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Breech presentation at term (around 37 weeks onwards) increases the risk of complications during labor, including cord prolapse, fetal distress, and birth trauma. Therefore, efforts are often made to turn the baby to a cephalic (head-down) position before labor begins.
  • ECV has a success rate of around 50-60% and is generally safe for uncomplicated breech pregnancies in women who have a normal BMI, and no contraindications to the procedure.
  • If the ECV is successful, the patient can proceed with vaginal delivery. If it is unsuccessful, the delivery will likely proceed by cesarean section.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 539, 542, 543, 549.

questions.text: A lady with 22 weeks of pregnancy presented with painless severe vaginal bleeding. Most likely site of implantation is:
questions.solution:
The most likely site of implantation in this case is the cervix.

Painless severe vaginal bleeding in the second trimester is highly suggestive of placenta previa. In placenta previa, the placenta implants abnormally over the cervix, leading to bleeding as the lower uterine segment stretches. The bleeding is typically painless because it originates from the placenta unlike placental abruption, which causes painful bleeding due to uterine detachment.

Clinical Features of Placenta Previa:

  1. Painless Vaginal Bleeding: The hallmark symptom is bright red, painless vaginal bleeding, typically occurring in the second or third trimester (after 20 weeks of pregnancy).

  2. Abnormal Fetal Position: Due to the placenta covering the cervical os, the fetus may be in a breech or transverse lie.

  3. Uterine Contractions: Mild uterine contractions may accompany bleeding, but they are usually not as severe as in other conditions like abruptio placentae.

  4. Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH): -There is a high risk of massive postpartum hemorrhage due to the placenta obstructing the cervical os during delivery. 

Other options
- The fallopian tube is the most common site for ectopic pregnancy, which usually presents with first-trimester pain and rupture rather than painless bleeding at 22 weeks.
- The ovary and abdomen are rare sites of ectopic pregnancy, which do not typically progress to the second trimester.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 755-757.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for first-trimester termination of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Misoprostol and mifepristone are used for medical termination of pregnancy in first 9 weeks of gestation. 
 
  • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. 
  • Misoprostol 800 mcg is administered on day 3 by vaginal, sublingual or buccal route. 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 203, 204.

questions.text: All of the following seen in abruptio placenta except?
questions.solution:
Painless bleeding in seen in Placenta Previa.
 

Abruptio placenta (placental abruption) typically presents with the following characteristics:

  1. Uterine tenderness: Common due to the placental separation causing uterine irritation.
  2. Increased uterine tone: Often seen because of uterine contractions that accompany placental separation.
  3. Abdominal pain: A hallmark of placental abruption, as it leads to significant uterine contractions and pain.

However, painless bleeding is not a characteristic of abruptio placenta. Painless bleeding is more commonly seen in placenta previa, where the placenta is located over the cervix. Abruptio placenta is typically associated with painful bleeding due to the abrupt separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 749-753, 755.

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated in 1st trimester MTP/Abortion?
questions.solution:
The use of extra-amniotic ethacridine lactate provides an effective and safe treatment method for second trimester legal abortion.
  • Abortion methods in first trimester:
  1. Medical Abortion (Mifepristone + Misoprostol)
  2. Suction & Evacuation
  3. MVA.


Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 209-214.

Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis, hemorrhage, and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia

There is a decrease in TXA2 and an increase in PGI2: TXA2 ratio in preeclampsia.

months before the onset of symptoms of preeclampsia.
