questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding post-partum hemorrhage
questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding postpartum hemorrhage is:

  1. Initial fluid replacement is by colloids, 4 times the amount of blood lost.

As per WHO Guidelines

"The use of isotonic crystalloids is recommended in preference to the use of colloids for the initial intravenous fluid resuscitation of women with PPH". Crystalloid solutions such as normal saline or lactated Ringer's solution are commonly used for initial fluid resuscitation in cases of postpartum hemorrhage. 

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 474-476 .

questions.text: 30y old female GA - 38+6 days came with labor pains. She was vitally stable. The resident Doctor did PV and found that Fetal head at -3 and membranes are felt as bag of worms beneath the head. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Bag of worms on palpation suggestive of cord presentation. The best course of action in patient with Cord presentation is emergency C section.
While preparing for C section patient maybe placed in Exaggerated Sim's position to avoid cord compression.

Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page. No- 373, 374.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of bleeding PV and abdominal pain. She has drenched her clothes and has experienced decreased fetal movements. On examination, her cervix was 6cm dilated and 50% effaced. Her BP was 150/100mmHg, PR - 98 beats/min. Her abdomen corresponded to 34 weeks and she had a tense and tender uterus with regular contractions and no fetal heart sounds were heard. Her urine protein is 2+ and there is no active bleeding. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
This Clinical Scenario of Painful antepartum hemorrhage associated with Preeclampsia (HTV + Proteinuria) and fetal death i ssuggestive of Grade 2 Abruptio Placentae.
Next Line of Management is Antihypertensives and deliver the fetus vaginally.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page. No- 242.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels will serve as an alternate source of blood supply to prevent uterine ischaemia after ligation of primary artery involved?
questions.solution:
The blood flow from ovarian artery compensates for ischemia if primary vessel is ligated.
Order of Ligation to arrest bleeding in Atonic PPH Uterine>Ovarian>Internal Iliac.
The primary artery ligated is the uterine artery.

Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No- 390, 391.

choices.text: Reposition the uterus without removing the placenta

questions.text: A 32y old Multi Gravida female comes to the ER following inversion of Uterus following her delivery at home. On examination - Bp- 120/80 HR -84bpm.What should be the next management?
questions.solution:
Uterine Inversion in vitally stable patient- Manual reposition of uterus without removing the placenta.
Risk Factors- Atony uterus, Adherent placenta, Fundal attachment of placenta.

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No: 737.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a fetal cause of Polyhydramnios?
questions.solution:
Polyhydramnios is an excess of amniotic fluid in pregnancy. Causes are classified as maternal, fetal, or idiopathic.

Fetal causes of polyhydramnios:

  • Neurological/structural disorders → impaired swallowing:

    • Open spina bifida

    • Anencephaly

  • Hydrops fetalis → fluid accumulation due to heart failure or anemia

  • Multiple gestation complications → twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)

Renal agenesis:

  • Leads to oligohydramnios, not polyhydramnios, because fetal urine contributes majorly to amniotic fluid in the second and third trimesters.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravidae at 38 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of faintness on lying down for the past one week. She feels better when she turns to a side and while in sitting position. What is the reason for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The patient is a term primigravida (38 weeks) experiencing faintness when lying supine, which improves on turning to a side or sitting.

  • This is a classic presentation of supine hypotensive syndrome, caused by compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus.

  • IVC compression reduces venous return to the heart, leading to decreased cardiac output and hypotension, which manifests as dizziness, faintness, and sometimes tachycardia.

  • Relief on lying on the left lateral side occurs because the uterus shifts off the IVC, restoring venous return.

  • Other options are less relevant: increased abdominal pressure does not selectively cause hypotension; increased intracranial pressure or “abdominal aorta syndrome” are not typical in this context.

High-yield point: Always advise left lateral tilt or wedge under the right hip for symptomatic relief in late pregnancy.

questions.text: A G2P1, 38 weeks of gestation age, presented for delivery. Her last pregnancy was uncomplicated, and she underwent a cesarean section. Now, she wants to have a vaginal birth. The clinician decided to perform a TOLAC (trial of labor after cesarean). Which of the following has the least risk for this procedure?
questions.solution:
A low segment transverse uterine incision from a previous cesarean is the safest for TOLAC, as it has the lowest risk of uterine rupture (≈0.2–0.9%).

Other options:

Classical C-section: High risk of uterine rupture; TOLAC is generally contraindicated.

Breech presentation: Malpresentation increases labor complications; not ideal for TOLAC.

Pre-eclampsia: Maternal-fetal risks are higher; TOLAC is usually avoided.

Key point: Among previous cesarean types, a low segment transverse scar carries the least risk during TOLAC.

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman presented with abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is a hypertensive pregnant woman presenting with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and loss of fetal movements.

  • These features are classic for abruptio placenta, which is the premature separation of a normally implanted placenta.

  • Risk factors: Maternal hypertension, trauma, smoking, or previous abruption.

  • Clinical features:

    • Painful vaginal bleeding (usually dark red)

    • Abdominal tenderness and uterine rigidity

    • Fetal distress or intrauterine fetal demise

  • Other options:

    • Placenta previa: Presents with painless bright red vaginal bleeding, no abdominal tenderness, fetal movements usually preserved.

    • Hydramnios: Excess amniotic fluid → may cause abdominal distension, dyspnea, preterm labor, but not bleeding or fetal demise.

    • Preterm labour: Uterine contractions and cervical changes, may have pain but not typically associated with sudden fetal demise or hypertension-related abruption.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of methylergotamine
questions.solution:
• Methylergometrine is an ergot derivative, which acts directly on the myometrium.
  • It causes uterine contractions with increasing intensity and frequency such that the uterus passes into a state of spasm without any relaxation in between.
  • Hence, it should only be used either in the late second stage of labor after the delivery of the anterior shoulder) or following the delivery of the baby.
Indications :
Prophylactic - Active management of the third stage of labor.

Therapeutic - To stop the atonic uterine bleeding, following delivery, abortion or expulsion of hydatidiform mole.

Contraindications :
Multiple pregnancy - If given accidentally with the delivery of the first baby, the second baby is compromised by the tetanic contractions of the uterus.
Heart disease - Results in sudden squeezing of blood from the uterine* circulation into the systemic circulation causing overloading of the right heart and failure.
Hypertensive disorders, pre-eclampsia and eclampsia
Rh-negative mother - More risk of fetomaternal microtransfusion.
Vascular disease

Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 390,468.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations is not possible in case of twin pregnancies
questions.solution:
• Dichorionic monoamniotic (DCMA) combination is not possible in twin pregnancies.
 


Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page No 839-842.

questions.text: A young female presented with complaints of pain in the abdomen and bleeding PV for the last 2 days. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks back. On examination, she has hypotension, tachycardia and cervical motion tenderness. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows free fluid in the pouch of Douglas and paracolic gutters. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario with a triad of abdominal pain, amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding, along with the ultrasound findings of free fluid, is suggestive of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • An ectopic pregnancy is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity, with the Fallopian tubes being the most common site.
  • The outcomes of such a pregnancy are varied with tubal rupture and massive intraperitoneal hemorrhage being one of them.
  • Treatment- Resuscitation and Laparotomy
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 171.

choices.text: Injection labetalol and magnesium sulphate and expedite the delivery
Injection labetolol , antenatal steroids, and immediate termination of pregnancy
Injection labetalol and magnesium sulphate and deliver at 37 weeks
Injection labetalol to control her blood pressure

questions.text: A 34 year old primigravida with chronic hypertension came to the hospital at 37 weeks of gestation with headache and blurring vision. Her BP is 180110 mm Hg. Urine analysis reveals urine albumin 3+. What is the next step to be done?
questions.solution:
In case of chronic hypertension with superimposed severe pre-eclampsia, the next step of management is to give injection labatelol and magnesium sulphate and expedite the delivery irrespective of the duration of gestation.

Criteria for diagnosis of superimposed pre-eclampsia are.

-Aggravation of hypertension
-Development of HELLP syndrome. -New onset proteinuria.
-Development of headache, scotoma, and epigastric pain.

Conditions where pregnancy is terminated regardless of the period of gestation:
Uncontrolled severe hypertension
Eclampsia
Pulmonary edema
HELLP Syndrome
Renal dysfunction
Coagulopathy (disseminated intravascular coagulation)
Abruption
Fetal compromise

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page No 690,716.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is not a criteria to Diagnose IUGR?
questions.solution:
• The Estimated Fetal weight <10th percentilefor GA and abdominal girth <10 percentile for GA is suggestive of IUGR.
  • Clinical Criteria for IUGR-
  1. Symphysis Fundal height with lag of >3cm,
  2. Falling maternal weight,
  3. Stationary abdominal girth.
  • USG doppler criteria to diagnose IUGR-
  1. S/D ratio >2SD indicate reduced diastolic velocities and increased placental vascular resistance.
  2. Absent or Reversed End diastolic velocity in Umbilcal artery.
  3. Increased diastolic velocity in Middle cerebral artery.
Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page No 825.

questions.text: In which of the scenario given below will you administer Post Partum Anti D prophylaxis in woman whose Blood group is O negative and Husband's blood group is B positive?
questions.solution:
• Post Partum prophylaxis is given if Baby is O positive and DCT negative.
  • Anti D immunoglbulin should be administered within 72 hours.
  • This reduces alloimmunisation by 90%.
  • The mode of action is antibody mediated Immune suppression.
  • Anti D is futile if Baby is Rh negative- there is no risk of alloimmunisation or if DCT is positive- alloimmunisation has already taken place.
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 314.

questions.text: Which of the following is the antenatal dose of steroids for lung maturity?
questions.solution:
• Maternal administration of corticosteroids is indicated when the pregnancy is less than 34 weeks.
  • Either betamethasone 12 mg IM 24 hours apart for two doses or
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IM every 12 hours for 4 doses is given.
  • This is beneficial when the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose. The benefit persists as long as 18 days.
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 296.

questions.text: Which of the following is the process of breaking the clavicle during delivery?
questions.solution:
Cleidotomy is a surgical procedure that involves fracturing the clavicle with an instrument to facilitate the delivery of the anterior shoulder, typically in cases involving a dead fetus. This technique is specifically utilized for managing shoulder dystocia, which occurs when either the anterior or, less commonly, the posterior fetal shoulder becomes impacted against the maternal symphysis or sacral promontory.

Management of Labor in Cases of Shoulder Dystocia:
1. First Line:
McRoberts Maneuver: Involves flexing and abducting the mother's thighs to reposition the pelvis.
2. Second Line:
Woods Corkscrew Maneuver: This maneuver entails rotating the posterior shoulder 180° in a corkscrew fashion to free the impacted shoulder.
3. Third Line:
Zavanelli Maneuver: This technique involves replacing the fetal head back into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.
Cleidotomy: As previously mentioned, this procedure helps in releasing the shoulder by fracturing the clavicle.
Symphysiotomy: Involves cutting the symphyseal cartilage and ligaments to widen the symphysis pubis, facilitating delivery.
These interventions are critical in managing shoulder dystocia effectively and ensuring the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: Identify the given image of the placenta previa.
questions.solution:
Type of Placenta Previa: The image presented depicts marginal placenta previa.

Overview of Placenta Previa:
Placenta previa refers to a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower segment of the uterus. It is characterized by painless bleeding occurring towards the end of the second trimester or later, often occurring unexpectedly and may resolve spontaneously, only to recur.

Classification of Placenta Previa:
There are four types based on the extent of placental coverage of the internal os:

1. Type I: Low-lying - The lower margin of the placenta reaches the lower uterine segment but does not cover the internal os. (Option D)

2. Type II: Marginal - The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.

3. Type III: Incomplete or Partial Central - The placenta covers the closed internal os but does not cover it when fully dilated. (Option A)

4. Type IV: Complete or Central - The placenta covers the internal os even when fully dilated. (Option B)

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 26 weeks gestation, presented with a BP of 150/90 mm Hg. Which test should be done next?
questions.solution:
• At 26 weeks, BP ≥140/90 mmHg in a primigravida raises suspicion of preeclampsia.

  • The next essential step is to check for proteinuria.

  • Urine dipstick test (bedside, rapid) is the initial screening test.

  • If positive → confirm with 24-hour urine protein or protein/creatinine ratio.

  • Other tests (uric acid, LFT, CBC) are useful for severity assessment once proteinuria is confirmed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for cesarean section?
questions.solution:
A previous history of macrosomia is not an indication for a cesarean section (CS).

A cesarean delivery is necessary in cases of a dead fetus when vaginal delivery is not feasible.

Absolute Indications for Cesarean Section:
Central placenta previa (Option A)
Contracted pelvis or cephalopelvic disproportion (absolute) (Option D)
Pelvic mass causing obstruction (e.g., cervical or broad ligament fibroid)
Advanced cervical carcinoma (Option B)
Vaginal atresia or stenosis
Relative Indications for Cesarean Section:
These are situations where vaginal delivery may still be possible, but the risks to the mother and/or baby are high:

Nonreassuring fetal heart rate (FHR)
Dystocia: May result from a relatively large fetus (passenger), a small pelvis (passage), or inefficient uterine contractions (power)
Antepartum hemorrhage: Conditions like placenta previa and abruptio placenta
Malpresentation: Breech, shoulder (transverse lie), or brow presentation
Previous cesarean delivery:
a) When the primary cesarean was due to a recurrent indication (e.g., contracted pelvis)
b) If there were two previous cesarean deliveries
c) Presence of features indicating scar dehiscence
d) Previous classical cesarean section
Cephalopelvic disproportion (relative)
Failure to progress in labor
Hypertensive disorders: Severe pre-eclampsia or eclampsia with uncontrolled seizures, even with antiseizure therapy

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• The most common site of implantation in an ectopic pregnancy is the tubal ampulla, labeled as A in the image.
 
  • Approximately 95% of ectopic pregnancies occur within the fallopian tube, with the ampulla being the most frequently affected site, accounting for 70% of cases. Other sites within the tube include the isthmus (12%), fimbria (11%), and interstitial tube (2%).
 
  • Ectopic pregnancies can also implant in locations such as the ovary (Option 1), peritoneal cavity, cervix (Option 2), or within a prior cesarean scar (Option 3).
 
  • Patients typically present with a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, characterized by a triad of symptoms: a delayed menstrual cycle, abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding.
 
  • On examination, findings may include abdominal tenderness, cervical motion pain, a bulging posterior vaginal fornix, and a boggy mass adjacent to the uterus. Vaginal bleeding or spotting may also be present. A ruptured ectopic pregnancy can lead to intra-abdominal hemorrhage, resulting in changes in vital signs.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 220-222.

questions.text: All of the following are true about audit in obstetrics except:
questions.solution:
A clinical audit is conducted to determine whether healthcare services are being delivered according to established standards. It informs both care providers and patients about areas of excellence and those needing improvement.

Typically, clinical audits are performed after data analysis and topic selection for quality enhancement rather than before analyzing outcomes.

In audits or quality improvement initiatives, gathering data related to patient care and outcomes (such as fetal death rates) can facilitate improvements in treatment practices.

This is achieved by implementing changes to hospital administration and current practices based on the findings.

questions.text: According to the MTP Act, termination of pregnancy due to rape can be done up to what period of gestation?
questions.solution:
"Upper limit of MTP:
• Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
• Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure
• At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board
Opinion of doctors:
• Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
• 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
• For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of an obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state. Ref- Online Source- https://loksabhadocs.nic.in/Refinput/New_Reference_Notes/English/12032020_122410_102120474.pdf"

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G3P2L2 patient at 17 weeks of gestation on a routine antenatal check up was found to have blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg. A repeat blood pressure after 6 hours measures 148/92 mm Hg.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chronic hypertension is diagnosed when the patient is a known hypertensive (or) BP > 140/90 mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation.
Chronic hypertension with superimposed pre-eclampsia or eclampsia is diagnosed with the following presentation: aggravation of hypertension, new onset of proteinuria after 20 weeks, development of headache, scotoma, epigastric pain, and HELLP syndrome.
Gestational hypertension: BP? 140/90 mm of hg for the first time in pregnancy after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman without proteinuria.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics - 8th edition • Page no: 255

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of magnesium toxicity
questions.solution:
Signs of magnesium toxicity include • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
• Urine output (<30 ml/h)
• Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute)
• Chest pain, heart block.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics - 8th edition • Page no 273

choices.text: Medical management is likely to be successful if ectopic mass is >6 cm
Following medical/surgical management beta HCG levels should be monitored monthly
Drug used for medical management is Methotrexate 75mg/m2

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding ectopic pregnancy
questions.solution:
The marker used in the monitoring of ectopic pregnancy is β-hCG. Medical management is indicated when the patient is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. Methotrexate (50 mg/m2, single dose intramuscularly)is used for medical management.
Medical management is likely to be successful when
• Initial serum hCG level is <3,000 IU/L.
• Ectopic mass is less than 4 cm.
• Fetal cardiac activity is absent.
• Intra-abdominal hemorrhage is absent.
Williams Obstetrics 26th Edition • Page no: 226, 227

questions.text:
A 30 year-old woman is in labour, and during delivery, the baby's head is delivered, but the shoulders get stuck.
The baby's head is at the introitus.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a 30-year-old woman in labour with the baby's head at the introitus and the shoulders being stuck is suggestive of shoulder dystocia.
Shoulder dystocia, defined as a head-to-body delivery time >60 seconds, occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory respectively. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum.
Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, post-dated pregnancy, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc. Wood's corkscrew maneuver is used to deliver the impacted shoulder in this condition.
Woods corkscrew maneuver: Progressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a corkscrew fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder.Ref - Williams Obstetrics 6th edition Page 502

questions.text: A woman with a non recurring indication of a previous LSCS now presents with an occipitoposterior fetal position. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: In a woman with non recurring indication for LSCS who presents with Occipitoposterior fetal position, the next best step would be to attempt a vaginal delivery. Occipitoposterior is an abnormal position of the vertex and can undergo normal labor in favorable circumstances. Indication for C section in Occipitoposterio position- Arrest of labor , inadequate uterine contraction, fetal distress. Ref- Dutta textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition Page 343-348

questions.text: A female undergoes a methylene blue 3 swab test and the middle swab is stained with blue. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The Methylene Blue three-swab test is used to differentiate the type of urogenital fistula:

  • Procedure: Three swabs are placed in the vagina – upper, middle, and lower. Methylene blue dye is instilled into the bladder.

Interpretation:

  • Lower swab stained: Vesicovaginal fistula (bladder communicates directly with the vagina).

  • Middle swab stained: Vesicouterine fistula (bladder communicates with the uterus, which then drains via the cervix into the vagina).

  • Upper swab only or none: Ureterovaginal fistula (urine bypasses bladder and may be unilateral).

Key point:

  • Vesicouterine fistula often presents with menouria (cyclical hematuria) and amenorrhea.

So, staining of the middle swab indicates vesicouterine fistula.





Reference: Williams gynaecology 3rd edition Page no 578-579

questions.text: You are performing a cardiotocograph on a woman in labor, and your findings are shown below. What could be the possible cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
You are seeing variable decelerations on the cardiotocograph (CTG). Key points about variable decelerations:

  • Shape: Abrupt decrease in FHR (≥15 bpm, lasting ≥15 seconds, <2 minutes).

  • Timing: Can occur anytime relative to uterine contractions.

  • Cause: Usually umbilical cord compression → transient cord obstruction → brief fetal hypoxia and vagal response.

  • Clinical significance: Often benign if occasional and rapidly returning to baseline, but persistent or deep decelerations may need intrauterine resuscitation.

Other options:

  • Uteroplacental insufficiency → late decelerations (gradual decline after contraction peak).

  • Fetal head compression → early decelerations (gradual decline with contraction).

  • Fetal hypoxia → can cause late decelerations or prolonged decelerations, but variable decels are specifically associated with cord issues.



Reference:DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition page no 694-695

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Timing: Postpartum blues typically occurs within the first week after delivery, most commonly 2–5 days postpartum. The symptoms are usually self-limiting and resolve within 2 weeks.

  • Symptoms:

    • Tearfulness

    • Mood swings

    • Irritability

    • Anxiety

    • Mild insomnia

  • Differentiation from other conditions:

    • Postpartum depression: Onset is usually after 2 weeks, lasts longer than 2 weeks, and is more severe, with persistent low mood, anhedonia, and possible suicidal thoughts.

    • Postpartum psychosis: Rare, acute onset within the first 2 weeks, severe symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, confusion, agitation—medical emergency.

    • Postpartum anxiety: Can occur anytime postpartum, but usually without the classic tearfulness/mood swings pattern seen in blues.

Key point: Postpartum blues is common (up to 70% of women) and generally self-limiting, requiring mainly reassurance and support.




Reference
DSM-5 (R) Guidebook: The Essential Companion to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition - Page no: 68, 112

questions.text: A female patient with post partum hemorrhage has been given ergometrine and oxytocin. The bleeding still continues. Which prostaglandin derivative can be given in this situation?
questions.solution:
In a case of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) not responding to oxytocin and ergometrine, the prostaglandin derivative of choice is Carboprost.

Explanation:

  • Carboprost tromethamine is a PGF2α analog. It acts by causing uterine contraction, which helps control hemorrhage when first-line agents like oxytocin or ergometrine fail.

  • Dosage: 250 µg intramuscularly, can be repeated every 15–90 minutes up to a maximum of 2 mg.

  • Other options:

    • Dinoprostone (PGE2): Mainly used for cervical ripening and labor induction.

    • Misoprostol (PGE1 analog): Can be used in PPH, especially where injectables aren’t available, but slower onset.

    • Latanoprost: Used in ophthalmology for glaucoma; not for PPH.

      Drugs for PPH 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th Edition Page no 735-736

questions.text: A genital examination is being performed on a patient with perineal laceration post-vaginal delivery. The tear extends into the fascia and the musculature of the perineal body but the anal sphincter muscles remain intact. Which of the following grades of perineal laceration does this correspond to?
questions.solution:
The described perineal tear extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body but spares the anal sphincter.

This corresponds to a second-degree perineal laceration.

Explanation:

  • First-degree: Involves only the vaginal mucosa and perineal skin.

  • Second-degree: Extends into the perineal muscles and fascia but does not involve the anal sphincter.

  • Third-degree: Involves the anal sphincter complex (subdivided into 3a, 3b, 3c based on extent).

  • Fourth-degree: Involves the rectal mucosa in addition to the anal sphincter.



Reference:DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page no 489-490

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with HMG. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The USG results and the provided clinical situation point to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Multiple ovarian follicular cysts and enhanced capillary permeability are hallmarks of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. It seldom occurs in a pregnancy that is otherwise normal, but it usually occurs as a side effect of ovulation-induction medication for infertility. Pregnancy with a partial molar has also been documented. It is believed that hCG stimulates the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) in granulosalutein cells, which is part of its etiopathogenesis.

A drug called human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG) is made up of both FSH and LH. For women who do not ovulate on their own, it is used to induce the release of eggs. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome may result from it.
 

Definition:
OHSS is an exaggerated systemic response to ovarian stimulation, usually occurring after ovulation induction with fertility treatments such as clomiphene citrate or gonadotropins. It results in ovarian enlargement and fluid shift from the intravascular to the third space, causing serious complications.

Pathophysiology

  • Triggered by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) administration (exogenous or endogenous in early pregnancy).

  • Causes increased vascular permeability mediated by vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

  • Leads to fluid leakage into peritoneal, pleural, and sometimes pericardial spaces.

  • Results in hemoconcentration, hypovolemia, and electrolyte imbalances.

    Clinical Features

  • Mild OHSS: Abdominal discomfort, ovarian enlargement, mild ascites

  • Moderate OHSS: Abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting, moderate ascites, ultrasound evidence of ovarian enlargement

  • Severe OHSS: Severe abdominal pain, tense ascites, pleural effusion, dyspnea, oliguria, hemoconcentration, electrolyte imbalance, thromboembolism risk

    Diagnosis

  • Clinical presentation + history of ovarian stimulation

  • Ultrasound showing enlarged ovaries (>5 cm) with multiple cysts and ascites

  • Laboratory findings: hemoconcentration (elevated hematocrit), leukocytosis, electrolyte disturbances, elevated creatinine in severe cases
     


Reference: Williams Obstetrics 25th edition page no 1199

questions.text: Serial monitoring of serum beta hCG is required for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Serial monitoring of serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-hCG) is primarily required in molar pregnancy (also called hydatidiform mole) for diagnosis, treatment monitoring, and early detection of persistent gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) or choriocarcinoma.

Why Serial Beta-hCG Monitoring in Molar Pregnancy?

  • Hydatidiform mole is characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation, which produces excessive amounts of beta-hCG.

  • After evacuation of the mole (by suction curettage), serial beta-hCG levels are monitored weekly to ensure they decline appropriately.

  • Persistently elevated or rising beta-hCG levels after treatment suggest persistent trophoblastic disease, which may require chemotherapy.

  • Monitoring continues until beta-hCG normalizes, followed by monthly monitoring for 6 months to 1 year to detect recurrence.

    Why Not the Other Options?

  1. Pregnancy associated with Neural Tube Defects (NTDs):

    • Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and ultrasound are used for screening, not beta-hCG serial monitoring.

  2. Rh-negative Pregnancy:

    • Management includes administration of anti-D immunoglobulin; serial beta-hCG is not used here.

  3. Down Syndrome Screening:

    • Beta-hCG is measured once as part of the first or second trimester screening but not serially.

    • Typically combined with other markers like PAPP-A (pregnancy-associated plasma protein A) or nuchal translucency measurement.

      Summary

Serial beta-hCG measurement is a key diagnostic and follow-up tool in molar pregnancy to monitor treatment response and detect persistent disease early. It is not routinely used for neural tube defects, Rh-negative pregnancies, or Down syndrome screening.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 240

questions.text: The CTG tracing of a woman in labor at 38 weeks gestation is shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Late decelerations are a type of fetal heart rate (FHR) deceleration characterized by a gradual decrease in FHR that begins after the onset of a uterine contraction, reaches its nadir after the peak of the contraction, and returns to baseline only after the contraction ends. This timing differentiates late decelerations from early decelerations (which coincide with the contraction) and variable decelerations (which are abrupt and variable in timing).

Pathophysiology

Late decelerations primarily indicate uteroplacental insufficiency and prenatal hypoxia. During a uterine contraction, blood flow to the placenta is temporarily reduced. In a normal pregnancy, the fetus can tolerate this brief hypoxic episode due to adequate placental reserve. However, in compromised placentas or in conditions affecting maternal-fetal oxygen exchange, the fetus experiences insufficient oxygenation during contractions, leading to hypoxia.

This fetal hypoxia stimulates chemoreceptors that trigger a reflexive vagal response, causing a delayed decrease in fetal heart rate—manifesting as late decelerations.

Common Causes of Late Decelerations

  1. Placental Disorders

    • Placental insufficiency: Poor placental perfusion or function reduces oxygen delivery.

    • Placental abruption: Premature separation of the placenta disrupts fetal oxygen supply.

    • Placenta previa or infarction can also impair placental function.

    • Maternal conditions that impair placental blood flow such as hypertension, preeclampsia, or diabetes mellitus cause vascular changes reducing oxygen delivery.

  2. Prolonged or Excessive Uterine Contractions

    • When contractions are too frequent (tachysystole) or excessively strong, the interval for placental reperfusion is insufficient.

    • Prolonged contractions reduce oxygen supply to the fetus during the contraction and impair recovery between contractions.

  3. Use of Uterotonic Drugs (e.g., Oxytocin)

    • High doses or inappropriate administration of oxytocin can cause uterine tachysystole.

    • This leads to decreased uteroplacental perfusion and hypoxia, manifesting as late decelerations.

  4. Anesthesia Effects

    • Epidural anesthesia can cause maternal hypotension by sympathetic blockade, reducing uterine blood flow.

    • Reduced maternal blood pressure leads to decreased placental perfusion and can induce late deceleration


Reference:DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page no 695

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for an antenatal check-up and Is currently on lithium for her bipolar disorder. This drug must be stopped, due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Since lithium can result in an Ebstein abnormality in the infant, it should be stopped.

Ebstein anomaly is defined by the tricuspid valve's downward displacement into the right ventricle, which causes the tricuspid leaflets to adhere abnormally, resulting in a thin-walled, low-pressure, "atrialized" portion of the right ventricle.

Macrocephaly is another teratogenic consequence of lithium.

The fetus develops an Ebstein defect when lithium is used in the early stages of pregnancy. Neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and heart murmur are all linked to fetal lithium exposure.

Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 812

questions.text: A G6+0+0 lady with h/o recurrent missed abortions at 14–16 weeks comes to you with a missed abortion at 12 weeks. Which of the following tests is not warranted?
questions.solution:
Though VDRL is a simple test, mostly performed in initial work up of all cases of multiple abortions, in this case all abortions are by 16th week while in syphilis, usually there is an improvement in the duration of pregnancy (Kassowitz Law).
 
  • Most common cause of isolated abortion is Chromosomal aberrations (Aneuploidy). So, we need to perform fetal Karyotype for diagnosis of trisomy, monosomy etc.
  • One of the important causes of recurrent 2nd trimester abortion is Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). 
Laboratory Criteria for diagnosis of APS/APLA: 
  1. Presence of lupus anticoagulant according to guidelines of the International Society on Thrombosis and Hemostasis (OR)
  2. Medium or high serum levels of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin antibodies (OR)
  3. Anti-β2 glycoprotein-I IgG or IgM antibody

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 204, 205.

choices.text: Give IV fluids, keep NPO and observe for 4—5 days

questions.text: A young woman with six weeks of amenorrhea experienced acute abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting. Her blood pressure was 100/80 mm Hg. A 5 x 5 cm adnexal tumor was discovered during the examination. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
• An ectopic pregnancy is suspected based on the clinical presentation. It is crucial to measure the beta-hCG levels in order to support the diagnosis.
  • Further therapy can be decided upon if the beta-hCG levels show an ectopic pregnancy. Depending on the patient's stability and other clinical criteria, this may need either surgical intervention or medical management with methotrexate


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 221, 222.

choices.text: Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum depending on the baby blood group
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum irrespective of baby blood group
No need of additional dose since she is ICT negative

questions.text: Anti-D was given to a Rh-negative mother who had a negative Indirect Coombs Test (ICT) at 28 weeks of pregnancy. Which of the following is the best option?
questions.solution:
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum depending on the baby blood group
In RAADP ( Routine antenatal Anti D Prophylaxis) , anti D is administered at 28 weeks and then within 72 hours post partum if the baby is Rh positive.
 
  • Fetomaternal hemorrhage at delivery accounts for as many as 90 percent of alloimmunization cases.
  • Routine postpartum administration of anti-D immune globulin to at-risk pregnancies within 72 hours of delivery lowers the alloimmunization rate by 90 percent. Additionally, provision of anti-D immune globulin at 28 weeks gestation reduces the third-trimester alloimmunization rate.
  • Whenever there is doubt whether to give anti-D immune globulin, it should be given.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 356, 357.

questions.text: Which is the preferred medication for pregnancy-induced hypertension?
questions.solution:
Alpha-methyldopa is commonly recommended for the treatment of hypertension during pregnancy due to its safety profile and effectiveness in reducing blood pressure without negatively affecting fetal development.
Other medications like Atenolol, Nitroprusside, and Enalapril are generally contraindicated or less preferred during pregnancy due to potential adverse effects on the fetus.
 
  • Atenolol is not recommended because of its link with fetal-growth restriction. (Option 1)
  • Labetalol is an α/β-adrenergic blocker that is considered sae. Clonidine and α-methyldopa act centrally by reducing sympathetic outflow to effect a generalized decreased vascular tone. Drugs in this class most frequently used in pregnancy are methyldopa and labetalol (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 2018a).
  • ACE-inhibitors (Enalapril) can cause severe fetal malformations when given in the second and third trimesters. These include oligohydramnios, hypocalvaria, and renal dysfunction. (Option 4)


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 949.

questions.text: What misoprostol dosage is recommended for the urgent treatment of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Misoprostol is commonly administered orally or sublingually at a dose of 600 mcg to manage postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic effects, which help to reduce bleeding after childbirth.
 
  • Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue.
  • If Misoprostol is used to treat atony, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2019a) recommends a dose of 600 to 1000 μg rectally, orally, or sublingually.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 736.

questions.text: When should a woman with gestational diabetes who is under control with insulin therapy terminate her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
NICE recommends that diabetes controlled on insulin should be terminated at 38 weeks.
 
  • However, The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2020c, 2021) suggests initiating such testing at 32 to 34 weeks’ gestation. With reassuring testing and no other complications, delivery is anticipated between 39 and 39+6 weeks.
  • Better answer should be 39 weeks. Since, 39 is not there in options, next best answer should be 38 weeks.
 
 Delivery:
• Timing of delivery depends on control
• If on insulin, the pregnancy is best terminated by 39>38 weeks
• If diet control is adequate then the pregnancy may be prolonged to term
• Mode of delivery depends on clinical judgement
• Diabetes itself is not an indication for caesarean
• Factors favoring an elective CS are
– Macrosomia
– Suspicion of cephalopelvic disproportion
– Malpresentation
– polyhydramnios



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1078.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for a vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Cystoscopy is considered the IOC for vesicovaginal fistula. 





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 383.
Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 577.

questions.text: Pregnant women who have the following symptoms are said to have systemic hypertension if :
questions.solution:
Women with documented blood pressure readings greater than or equal to 140/90 mm Hg before pregnancy, before 20 weeks gestation, or both, are diagnosed with chronic underlying hypertension or systemic hypertension.





Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 689.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 207, 213.

questions.text: Which test should be done on a young lady who has a history of recurrent abortions?
questions.solution:
• Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, or APS, is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system produces antibodies that mistakenly attack certain proteins in the body, including proteins found in the blood clotting system.
  • Recurrent abortions is one of the most common manifestations of APS. The most relevant investigation to identify APS is the Dilute Russell Viper Venom Test (DRVVT).
  • This involves measuring the time it takes for blood to clot with the aid of a specific mixture of venom and other factors. Any abnormally prolonged clotting time could indicate the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, which are indicative of APS.

Laboratory criteria for APS needs presence of any one of the following antibodies: 
  1. β2 glycoprotein-I
  2. Lupus anticoagulant (LAC)
  3. Anticardiolipin antibodies (ACAs)
Lupus anticoagulant (LAC) is a heterogeneous group of antibodies directed against phospholipid-binding proteins. This antibody group induces prolongation in vitro of the prothrombin, partial thromboplastin, and Russell viper venom times. Thus, paradoxically, this so-called anticoagulant is actually powerfully thrombotic in vivo. This is the only APA that has been consistently associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes.
Thus, the DRVVT can be used as a diagnostic tool for APS and the recurrent abortions that may occur as a result.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1114.

questions.text: Which test is used to differentiate maternal and fetal blood cells?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Apt test

The Apt test (also known as alkaline phosphatase test) and the Kleihauer-Betke test (also known as acid phosphatase test) are both laboratory tests used to detect the presence of fetal blood in a sample.
 
  • The Apt test works by measuring the alkaline phosphatase activity in the sample, which is higher in the presence of fetal blood. The Kleihauer-Betke test works by measuring the amount of acid phosphatase present in the sample, which is also higher in the presence of fetal blood. In both cases, if fetal blood is present in the sample, the tests will detect it.
  • However, the Apt test is the preferred test for distinguishing between maternal and fetal blood within the same sample. This is because the activity of alkaline phosphatase is typically much higher in fetal cells than in maternal cells, so the Apt test is more sensitive in detecting fetal cells.
  • The Kleihauer-Betke test, on the other hand, is not as accurate in determining the source of the blood due to the fact that the activity of acid phosphatase is similar in both maternal and fetal cells.




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 301.
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 358.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not fall within the HELLP syndrome?
questions.solution:
Laboratory Diagnostic Signs of HELLP syndrome
H- Hemolysis 
EL- Elevated Liver enzymes 
LP- Low Platelet
Hemolysis • Abnormal misshapen erythrocytes in peripheral smear
• Increased indirect serum bilirubin
• Increased lactic dehydrogenase
• Low serum haptoglobin
• Microangiopathic anemia
Elevated liver enzymes • Alanine aminotransferase
• Aspartate aminotransferase
Low platelets • <100,000/mcL (no clear cutoff value)



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 699.

questions.text: The previous pregnancy ended in a caesarean section. Which of the following is not an indication for an elective caesarean section?
questions.solution:
Rest all are indications for repeated cesarean section .

Indication for Caesarean section
1. Absolute:
• Vaginal Atresia
• Advanced carcinoma of cervix
• Cervical or broad of contracted pelvis
• Severe degree of contracted pelvis

2. Relatives:
• Cephalopelvic disproportion
• Previous uterine scare
• Fetal distress
• Malpresentations
• Antepartum hemorrhage
• Elderly primigravidae
• Chronic hypertension
• Diabetes
• Pelvis atresia


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 548.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 670.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is present only in pregnancy with  heart disease  and not in normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Distended neck veins are seen in pregnancy with heart disease, but not seen in normal pregnancy.

Because of heart disease mainly right sided heart failure increased jugular venous pressure upto + 5cm is seen due to high cardiac output causing neck vein distension.

Supine hypotension is a condition that develops in late pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the I.V.C when the patient is supine.As a result, hypotension is generated. 

Exertional dyspnea :-Pregnancy causes a state of hyperventilation,which is most likely caused by progesterone's effects on the respiratory center and the center's increased sensitivity to carbon dioxide. The woman feels her breath getting shorter. 

Pedal edema also seen due to decreased colloidal osmotic tension due to hemodilution.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 60.

questions.text: All of the following complications is more common in ventouse-assisted delivery than forceps EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Fetal asphyxia is more common in forceps assisted delivery and NOT in ventouse assisted delivery.
Subgaleal hemorrhage, cephalhematoma and intracranial hemorrhage are more common in ventouse assisted delivery.

Complications of Forceps Operation:

Maternal:
  • vaginal laceration
  • sulcus tear
  • cervical tear
  • complete perineal tear
  • Nerve injury: Femoral (L2, 3, 4), lumbosacral trunk with mid forceps delivery
  • Post-partum hemorrhage
  • Anesthetic complications: Puerperal sepsis and maternal morbidity

Fetal:
  • Asphyxia
  • facial bruising

Complications of ventouse operation:

Maternal: injuries are not common

Fetal:
  • Superficial scalp abrasion
  • Sloughing of the scalp
  • Cephalhematoma
  • Subgaleal hemorrhage
  • Intracranial hemorrhage (rare)
  • Retinal hemorrhage


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 661, 663.

questions.text: A 26-year-old healthy girl became pregnant for the first time, and LSCS was performed to treat foetal distress. During pregnancy, she had mild hypertension. She developed headaches and seizures two days after delivery, but no proteinuria was found. A CT scan reveals a 2×3 cm parasagittal hematoma. Diagnosis will be:
questions.solution:
• A 26 year old healthy female got pregnant for Ist time and LSCS was done for fetal distress. Mild hypertension was present during pregnancy. Two days after delivery she had a headache and seizures but proteinuria was not seen. CT scan shows 2× 3 cm parasagittal hematoma. Diagnosis is sagittal sinus thrombosis.
 
  • A side effect of oral contraceptive use, pregnancy and the postpartum period, inflammatory bowel disease, intracranial infections (meningitis), and dehydration is venous sinus thrombosis of the lateral and sagittal small cerebral veins (cortical vein thrombosis). 
 
  • Patients typically arrive with headaches along with a variety of neurological symptoms, particularly paresthesias and seizures. However, venous sinus blockage is easily visible utilizing MR-or CT-venography or traditional x-ray angiography. Often, CT imaging is normal unless an intracranial venous hemorrhage has occurred.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 474.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 319.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has a history of repeated abortions and history of calf pain. Congenital deficiencies of which of these is present in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Protein C
 
  • Protein C is a vitamin K-dependent glycoprotein synthesized by  liver that inactivates factors Va and VIlla. It is an anticoagulant and it's deficiency causes hypercoagulable state. Protein C deficiency is also an autosomal dominant genetic disorder that affects 3.2% of patients with venous thromboembolism.
 
  • Clinical signs and symptoms of Protein C deficiency vary and can range from mild to severe. Symptoms may include easy bruising and/or bleeding, superficial blood vessels that are visible on the skin, recurrent DVT ("deep vein thrombosis"), pulmonary embolism, recurrent miscarriages, stroke, or heart attack.
 
  • In infants, Protein C deficiency can cause a condition known as "purpura fulminans" which is characterized by severe abdominal pain, shock, and death within a few days of birth.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 976, 977.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 319, 376.

choices.text: Terminate pregnancy because of high risk of infections
Continue pregnancy with use of antibiotics throughout pregnancy

questions.text: A G3P2 who is 30 years old and has amenorrhea for 10 weeks has an intrauterine pregnancy with an intrauterine contraceptive device in place. The IUCD string was discernible at the cervical os during a pelvic exam. The patient wants to carry out the pregnancy. How will you proceed?
questions.solution:
• If a woman becomes pregnant with an IUD in place, the IUD should be removed if strings are visible or if the IUD is within the cervix. For women who choose pregnancy termination, the IUD can be removed at the time of surgical abortion and before medication abortion. 
  • If the strings of IUCD not visible and women wants to continue pregnancy then leave it in situ. 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 666, 667.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 619.

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital anomaly found in infant of Diabetic Mother?
questions.solution:
VSD is the most common anomaly in diabetes and neural tube defects are the most specific anomaly.

Congenital anomalies in Infants of Diabetic mothers:




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 330.

questions.text: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy is most commonly seen during?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 3rd trimester

Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP):

• Rare fatal complication of pregnancy (3rd trimester).
• Patho: microvesicular fatty infiltration → encephalopathy & hepatic failure with up to 10 % mortality.
• Etiology: Enzyme mutation Fetal LCHAD (long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase) deficiency (mitochondria fatty acid oxidation)
Clinical Features- Nausea, vomitting, tiredness, jaundice, pain abdomen. 
• 20% of babies for mothers with AFLP are +ve for the enzyme.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1031-1035.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a reason for secondary postpartum bleeding?
questions.solution:
Placenta previa causes antepartum hemorrhage, NOT PPH.
The causes of post partum hemorrhage can be remembered as 4Ts- Tone ,Trauma, Tissue and Thrombosis.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 733, 735-740.

questions.text: What treatment is advised for a woman who has antiphospholipid antibodies and a history of stillbirths or abortions?
questions.solution:
Aspirin + low molecular weight heparin
The management of APLA include starting Asprin pre-conceptionally and Low molecular weight heparin on the day of positive pregnancy test and to continue throughout pregnancy.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 979, 1114-1116..
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 162, 321, 412.

questions.text: Pregnancy-related intrahepatic cholestasis is best treated by:
questions.solution:
Ursodeoxycholic acid acts by inhibiting cholesterol absorption in intestine and inhibiting cholesterol synthesis in intestine. 





Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1032.

questions.text: The following is not a cardiac contraindication to pregnancy.
questions.solution:
• WPW Syndrome is not a contraindication for pregnancy.
  • Patients with Eisenmenger's syndrome would also have pulmonary hypertension which is a contraindication. Severe LV dysfunction will have reduced ejection fraction.
Heart Diseases included in Clarke's class III (Pregnancy contraindicated)-

questions.text: The most preferred anaesthesia for a pregnant patient with severe pre-eclampsia undergoing caesarean section is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Epidural
 
  • Continuous epidural anesthesia is typically preferred for most patients with preeclampsia during labor, vaginal delivery, and cesarean sections.
  • Patients with preeclampsia are at risk of severe airway edema, which complicates intubation. Therefore, continuous epidural anesthesia is beneficial as it eliminates the need for intubation. Additionally, it can enhance uteroplacental perfusion and reduce catecholamine release.
  • However, a key requirement for regional anesthesia in preeclamptic patients is having a normal platelet count and normal coagulation. Coagulopathy is a contraindication for regional anesthesia. The minimum platelet count for regional anesthesia is generally 100,000/µL, though some cases may be managed with a count as low as 70,000/µL.
  • General anesthesia is recommended for patients with coagulopathy or severe preeclampsia with complications. Spinal anesthesia may be used in cases of mild preeclampsia, but its application is limited in moderate to severe preeclampsia due to the risk of hypotension associated with spinal anesthesia.
However, this is a controversial question. Preferred answer is Epidural> Spinal.


Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 866.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in management of hypertension during pregnancy?

Table 2. Medications for Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy
Drug Dose Effects
Methyldopa 250 mg PO BID up to 1,000 mg PO every 8 hours (3,000 mg total daily dose) Agent with greatest available data in pregnancy and followup of offspring; limited by maternal dizziness, fatigue.
Labetalol 100 mg PO BID up to 800 mg PO every 8 hours, 10-80 mg IV for BP \(\geq\)160/110 (2,400 mg total daily dose) First line for acute hypertensive crisis; uteroplacental flow mostly unaffected; no fetal growth impairment in contrast to atenolol, propranolol.
Nifedipine  Short-acting: 10 mg PO every 8 hrs.; extended release: 30-90 mg PO qd (120 mg total daily dose) Short-acting use preferable; rapid vasodilation/hypotension; pregnancy data limited.
Hydralazine  10 mg PO every 6 hours up to 50 mg PO every 60 hours, 2.5-10 mg IV for BP>=160/110 (200 mg total daily dose) Consider for acute hypertensive crisis; note delayed onset, reflex tachycardia, flushing, headache. 
ACE inhibitors/ Angiotensin Receptor Blockers Any dosage Contraindicated, adverse fetal effects in later gestation.

questions.text: What is the best test in the modern, advanced era of obstetrics to monitor an Rh-ve mother?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Middle cerebral artery doppler wave forms
 
  • MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is utilized to monitor fetuses in Rh-negative sensitized mothers. The middle cerebral artery is preferred because other fetal vessels require a larger insonation angle, leading to significant measurement errors.
 
  • MCA PSV increases due to heightened cardiac output and reduced viscosity of fetal blood, enabling the reliable, noninvasive detection of fetal anemia in blood-group alloimmunization cases.
 
  • If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is under 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has become the preferred method for detecting anemia, replacing amniocentesis.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 262, 263.

questions.text: The exception to the administration of Anti D prophylaxis from the following conditions is-
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Intra uterine transfusion at 28 weeks
 
  • The anti-D vaccine is not administered during intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks of pregnancy. Intrauterine transfusion is performed in alloimmunized pregnancies, where the maternal immune system (Rh negative) has been exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood.
 
  • The purpose of the anti-D vaccine is to prevent the formation of maternal antibodies against fetal red blood cells, which is already happening in alloimmunized pregnancies. Thus, anti-D vaccine administration is only appropriate for ICT-negative, non-isoimmunized pregnancies.
 
  • Intrauterine transfusion is considered when the peak systolic velocity of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) >1.5 MoM, when hydrops develops, or when fetal hematocrit levels are critically low. In these cases, the mother already has antibodies against the fetal red blood cells, making anti-D vaccination unnecessary.

Indications for administering anti-D include:

- Pregnancy loss: spontaneous or elective abortion, and ectopic pregnancy.
- Fetal death: at any stage of pregnancy.
- Procedures: such as amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling, fetal blood sampling, and molar pregnancy evacuation.
- Other situations: antepartum bleeding (including threatened abortion), delivery (vaginal or cesarean), external cephalic version, placental abruption, manual removal of the placenta, and abdominal trauma during pregnancy.

All Rh D-negative women should receive a single dose of 300 mcg of anti-D at 28 weeks of pregnancy, provided that the ICT is negative.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 354-357.

questions.text:
Which of the following diagnostic techniques is used to identify placenta accreta?
(i) USG
(ii) MRI
(iii) CT scan
(iv) Angiography
questions.solution:
• Some features of placenta accreta on ultrasound are loss of normal hypoechoic plane in the myometrium beneath the placental bed, presence of multiple placental lacunae, loss of normal hyperchoic line separating the urinary bladder wall from the uterus, thinning of the myoemtrum to less than 1 mm, buldging of the placenta into surrounding organs adjacent to the uterus, causing a mass like lesion protuding out from the uterine wall
  • The demonstration of uterine bulging and loss of normal uterine contour on MRI suggests Accrete
  • On T2 weighted MR images, the mass is hyperintense and may be heterogeneous
  • Also, T2 weighted MR images are useful in the assessment of focal thinning of the myometrium and interruption of the junctional zone
Other options-
  • CT scan gives x ray exposure moreover it is not good for diagnosing placenta accreta.
  • Angiography has no use in diagnosing placenta accreta.

questions.text:
A 24 year old Primigravida woman with a 3-year history of infertility shows up with amenorrhea lasting six weeks.
She has sporadic PV and slight stomach pain. Her UPT is marginally optimistic. She is hemodynamically stable upon assessment.
There is a left-sided adnexal lesion measuring 3 × 2.5 cm. B HCG : 2800 A left-sided tubal gestational sac is visible on ultrasound, but there is no heart activity. Which is the most effective management strategy?
questions.solution:
• The size of G sac is less than 3.5 cm and there is no cardiac activity.
  • Hence , the patient is a candidate for medical management of ectopic.
  • Methotrexate IM injection is an appropriate and effective treatment option, particularly when the ectopic pregnancy is detected early, the patient is stable, and there are no contraindications to the drug.
  • Salpingectomy (removal of the fallopian tube) is usually reserved for more advanced cases or when the tube is ruptured or severely damaged.
  • Milking the tube is not recommended, as it can lead to increased risk of tubal damage and recurrence.
  • Expectant management is not suitable here due to the persistent ectopic pregnancy with significant β-hCG levels and visible ectopic gestation.
 
Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 225, 226.
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 237-239.

questions.text: A P0A3 arrives and has had three abortions in the past. First at 8 weeks, second at 11 weeks, and third at 24 weeks, all having a history of preeclampsia with early onset. Which of the following explains her abortions the most likely?
questions.solution:
The patient has history of recurrent pregnancy loss with h/o pre Eclampsia which is seen in Anti phospholipid antibodies syndrome.
Modified Sapro criteria is used for its diagnosis
Clinical criteria 
1. Vascular thrombosis: \( \geq 1\) arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis 
2. Pregnancy morbidity 
a. \( \geq 1\) fetal death (at or beyond the 10th week of gestation)
b. \( \geq 1\) premature birth before the 34th week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency 
c. \( \geq 3\) consecutive (pre) embryonic losses (before the 10th week of gestation)  
Laboratory criteria 
1. Lupus  anticoagulant positivity on \( \geq 2\) occasions at least 12 weeks  apart. 
2. Anticardiolipin antibody (IgG and/ or IgM) in medium or high titer (i.e., >40, or above the 99th percentile), on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart 
3. Anti-\(\beta2\)-glycoprotein-I antibody (IgG and/or IgM) in medium or higher titer (i.e., above the 99th percentile)on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.

Definite APS is present if at least one of the clinical certeria and one of the laboratory criteria are met. 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 204-206.
Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 145-148.

questions.text: What is the specific problem with monochorionic twins?
questions.solution:
1. TWIN TWIN TRANSFUSION SYNDROME- 

Vein-to-vein, artery-to-artery, or artery-to-vein anastomosis are possible between twins (VV). 

The receiver twin receives blood transfusions from the donor twin, which could eventually cause anemia and limit the donor's ability to grow. On the other hand, the recipient develops polycythemia and could experience circulatory overload that looks like hydrops. Recipient twin has a better prognosis compared to donor twin.  

It is always present in monochorionic placentas. 

Contrary to monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy, M/C occurs in monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following does not indicate fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
A majority of more than fifty percent of orange colored cells in the Nile blue test could indicate that the pulmonary maturity of the fetus is present, not the presence of blue cells specifically.

The Nile Blue Test is a test developed to identify fats and oils in biological samples. It is based on the principle that all fatty acid amides and esters will, when treated with alcohol and acid, give off a characteristic blue colour. This test offers a convenient way of telling apart different fats and oils without having to resort to more complicated tests such as gas chromatography and infrared spectroscopy.

The Nile Blue Test is still used today, particularly in forensic investigations, but is usually supplemented with other tests to provide additional certainty.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not occur in a healthy pregnancy but is present in a patient with heart disease?
questions.solution:
Distended neck veins are seen in pregnancy with heart disease.

Distended neck veins are seen in pregnancy with heart disease, but not seen in normal pregnancy.

Because of heart disease mainly right sided heart failure increased jugular venous pressure upto + 5cm is seen due to high cardiac output causing neck vein distension.

Supine hypotension is a condition that develops in late pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the I.V.C when the patient is supine.As a result, hypotension is generated. 

Exertional dyspnea :-Pregnancy causes a state of hyperventilation,which is most likely caused by progesterone's effects on the respiratory center and the center's increased sensitivity to carbon dioxide. The woman feels her breath getting shorter. 

Pedal edema also seen due to decreased colloidal osmotic tension due to hemodilution.


Clinical indicators of heart disease during pregnancy are:

Cyanosis
clubbing of fingers
Persistent neck vein distention
Systolic murmur grade 3/6 or greater
Diastolic murmur
Cardiomegaly
Persistent arrhythmia


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 60.

The treatment of choice is Termination of Pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30y old lady with history of two LSCS now came with history of painless bleeding PV at 34 weeks of gestation. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Most likely diagnosis in this case is placenta previa ( History of Painless bleeding PV).
  • Because the history of previous C-section or  the presence of any scar on uterus is a predisposing factor for placenta previa.
 
  • Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta is located close to or covering the cervix, which can lead to painless vaginal bleeding in the third trimester. This condition is more common in women with a history of cesarean sections (LSCS) and often presents around the gestational age described here (34 weeks).

Other options: 

  1. Oligohydramnios refers to low amniotic fluid levels and does not typically cause painless bleeding.
  2. Pelvic tumor and
  3. Uterine anomalies might cause complications but are less likely to cause painless bleeding at this gestational age.

Placenta previa should be ruled out or confirmed via ultrasound in cases of third-trimester bleeding, especially with a history of previous C-sections.


 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 285, 288.

questions.text: When is the vertical transmission of HIV from mother to child maximum?
questions.solution:
Option (1) is correct. As the exposure is maximum during normal vaginal delivery,
Hence, the risk of transmission is also the highest among the given options.



From the above table - it can be seen that the maximum risk of vertical transmission is during normal vaginal compared to during pregnancy or breastfeeding.
Risk also depends on the viral load in the mother, the status/duration of ART.

questions.text: At the 36th week of her pregnancy, a multipara lady is experiencing a low platelet count, elevated serum transaminases, and mild hemolysis. What course of action should be taken next?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 3:Delivery of the baby
  • The symptoms described in the question - low platelet count, elevated serum transaminases, and mild hemolysis - are indicative of a serious medical condition called HELLP syndrome, which is a variant of preeclampsia.
  • This condition can be life-threatening for both the mother and the baby.
  • The only definitive treatment for HELLP syndrome is delivery of the baby, which is why option 3, "Delivery of the baby," is the correct course of action.
  • Intravenous corticosteroids (option 1) may be used to manage some of the symptoms of HELLP syndrome, but they are not a definitive treatment and do not address the underlying condition.
  • Wait and watch (option 2) is not a safe option as HELLP syndrome can progress rapidly and cause serious complications.
  • Intra-amniotic corticosteroids (option 4) are not recommended for the treatment of HELLP syndrome.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 699.

Theca lutein cysts are common in complete mole

choices.text: Total cell number is normal in asymmetric IUGR
Symmetric IUGR is due to extrinsic cause

questions.text: Which of these is true for intrauterine growth retardation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 2 :Total cell number is normal in asymmetric IUGR
  • Asymmetric IUGR is a type of growth restriction where the fetus has a smaller than normal abdominal circumference, but the head circumference is relatively normal.
  • This type of growth restriction is usually due to chronic placental insufficiency, which means that the placenta is not providing enough nutrients and oxygen to the fetus.
  • As a result, the fetus redistributes blood flow to the brain and heart at the expense of other organs, resulting in a smaller abdomen.
  • In asymmetric IUGR, the head circumference is relatively normal because the brain is prioritized for growth and development.
  • However, the body is relatively smaller due to the lack of nutrients and oxygen. Therefore, the total cell number is normal in asymmetric IUGR.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because it states that the head becomes smaller in asymmetric IUGR, which is not true. The head circumference is relatively normal in asymmetric IUGR.
  • Option 3 is also incorrect because symmetric IUGR is not due to an extrinsic cause. Symmetric IUGR is a type of growth restriction where the fetus has a proportionally small head and body. This type of growth restriction is usually due to intrinsic factors such as chromosomal abnormalities or congenital infections.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 534-536.

questions.text: What is the term for a twin's maceration-related death during the second trimester?
questions.solution:
The term fetus papyraceous is used when intrauterine fetal demise of a twin occurs early in pregnancy, with retention of the fetus for a minimum of 10 weeks resulting in mechanical compression of the small fetus and loss of fluid such that it resembles parchment paper.

Other options-
  • Vanishing twin is when one of the fetus after death goes autolysis
  • Acardiac twin is a twin without a heart
  • TTTS is seen if vascular channel in between the twins exist in case of MCMA twins. 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 852.

Contraindications of TOLAC-

choices.text: First twin has higher risk of birth asphyxia
Second twin has higher risk of Hyaline Membrane disease
First twin has higher risk of mortality
Second twin has higher risk of Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following statements about twin vaginal preterm delivery is correct?
questions.solution:
• Twin vaginal preterm delivery refers to the delivery of two babies before the completion of 37 weeks of gestation through the vaginal route. In such cases, the second twin has a higher risk of developing respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) or hyaline membrane disease (HMD) than the first twin.
  • This is because during a vaginal delivery, the first twin compresses the placenta and umbilical cord, which can cause a decrease in blood flow and oxygen supply to the second twin.
  • As a result, the second twin may develop respiratory distress syndrome due to inadequate surfactant production, which is essential for lung function.
  • On the other hand, the first twin has a higher risk of birth asphyxia due to the prolonged labor, which can cause a decrease in blood flow and oxygen supply to the baby.
  • However, the risk of mortality is not necessarily higher in the first twin as compared to the second twin. Similarly, the risk of intracranial hemorrhage is not necessarily higher in the second twin as compared to the first twin.
  • Therefore, option 2 is correct, which states that the second twin has a higher risk of developing hyaline membrane disease.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 853, 854.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about mother-to-child transmission of HIV?
questions.solution:
Option (1) is an incorrect statement. The maximum transmission occurs during labor and delivery and not in the first trimester.



Option(2) is a correct statement - as seen in the above table - the risk of transmission varies from 15-25% with no breastfeeding and 20-35 % with breastfeeding but the majority i.e. 60-70% infants are not affected even without intervention. 

Option(3) is a correct statement. As seen in the above table- The maximum transmission occurs during labor and delivery(10-15%) and elective LSCS can reduce the same. 

Option(4) is a correct statement. Risk is related to the status of infection in the mother especially the viral load in the mother and the status/duration of ART in the mother. A higher viral load translates into a higher rate of vertical transmission. 



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 397.
