choices.text: Incomplete invasion of extra-villous cytotrophoblast into uterine artery
Incomplete invasion of extra-villous cytotrophoblast into radial artery
Incomplete invasion of extra-villous cytotrophoblast into basal artery
Incomplete invasion of extra-villous cytotrophoblast into spiral artery

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 32 weeks pregnancy develops hypertension and edema. Urine examination shows presence of protein. Treating doctor suspected it to be a case of preeclampsia. Which of the following theory defines it:
questions.solution:
The pathophysiology of pre-eclampsia revolves around incomplete invasion of extra villous cytotrophoblast into spiral artery. 

  • During normal pregnancy, extra-villous cytotrophoblasts invade the spiral arteries (which are part of the maternal uterine blood supply to the placenta) to remodel them.
  • This remodeling process transforms the spiral arteries from high-resistance vessels to low-resistance vessels that allow sufficient blood flow to the placenta.
  • In preeclampsia, this process of invasion and remodeling is incomplete or defective. As a result, the spiral arteries remain narrower and high-resistance, leading to poor placental perfusion and ischemia.
  • The placental ischemia releases various factors into the maternal circulation, including soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1) and endoglin, which can impair the endothelial function, causing the hallmark features of preeclampsia: hypertension, proteinuria, and edema.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 257, 263, 265, 266.

questions.text: A lady with pre-eclampsia presented to the Emergency department with absent patellar reflexes and bilateral plantar reflexes. She was having a respiratory rate of 11 breaths/minute and decreased urinary output. On auscultation, lung fields were clear. Her random blood sugar value was 210 mg/dl. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of magnesium sulphate toxicity. 
 
  • Its therapeutic levels are 4-7 mEq/L.
 
  • Signs of Magnesium toxicity include- loss of deep tendon reflexes, decreased RR < 12/min, decreased urine output < 30 ml/hour and visual changes, drowsiness. 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 268, 273.

questions.text: A 24 years old primigravida had postpartum hemorrhage, hypotension, shock and disseminated intravascular coagulation following normal vaginal delivery of a fully-term healthy infant. Uterus is well contracted and hard. Fetus is normal. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of DIC post delivery goes in favor of amniotic fluid embolism. 




Other options:
 

  • Ruptured uterus:

    • A ruptured uterus would typically present with severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and loss of fetal heart tones during labor. The uterus is usually soft and tender to palpation, and a rupture often leads to fetal distress or fetal death. Since the fetus is described as healthy and the uterus is well contracted, uterine rupture is less likely.

  • Vaginal laceration:

    • Vaginal lacerations can cause postpartum hemorrhage but usually result in localized bleeding from the vaginal or perineal area. They are less likely to cause the systemic shock, DIC, and severe hypotension seen in this case. Additionally, vaginal lacerations would not explain the well-contracted uterus.

  • Uterine atony:

    • Uterine atony is one of the most common causes of postpartum hemorrhage, but it typically presents with a soft, boggy uterus that does not contract properly. Since the uterus is described as well-contracted and hard in this case, uterine atony is unlikely.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 756, 785, 786.

questions.text: A known case of cervical incompetence with previous abortion presented at 12 weeks of pregnancy. Doctor planned her for cerclage operation. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for cervical cerclage operation?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, rupture of membranes is an absolute contraindication to perform cervical cerclage. 

Contraindications for cervical cerclage are-
  1. Ruptured membranes
  2. Intrauterine infection
  3. Uterine contractions
  4. Vaginal bleeding 
  5. Cervix > 4 cm dilated


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 197-201, 367.

questions.text: A 14 weeks pregnant lady was subjected to Color Doppler studies of Uterine artery. By doing so, which of the following can be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
• A uterine artery doppler will detect early onset pre-eclampsia. 
  • It will show presence of a diastolic notch and resistance to flow in uterine artery. 
 
  • Color Doppler of the uterine artery is primarily used to assess placental perfusion by examining the blood flow through the uterine arteries. This can give valuable information regarding maternal vascular health and potential pregnancy complications.
  • Early onset pre-eclampsia (which typically develops before 34 weeks of gestation) is associated with abnormal uterine artery Doppler findings, such as:
    • Increased resistance to blood flow (higher pulsatility index).
    • Notching of the uterine artery waveform.
  • These abnormal Doppler findings reflect impaired trophoblastic invasion and poor placental perfusion, which can contribute to the development of early-onset pre-eclampsia.

Other options:
 

  1. Late onset pre-eclampsia:

    • Late onset pre-eclampsia (occurring after 34 weeks) is less likely to be predicted by early Doppler studies, as it is often associated with less severe placental dysfunction compared to early onset. Doppler abnormalities tend to be more predictive for early onset pre-eclampsia, where placental pathology plays a more significant role.

  2. Growth retardation (Fetal growth restriction):

    • Fetal growth restriction (FGR) can be associated with abnormal Doppler findings in the uterine artery, but it is typically diagnosed later in pregnancy (often after 20 weeks or later) when fetal growth begins to deviate from expected norms. While early signs may be present, Doppler studies at 14 weeks are more specific to assessing pre-eclampsia risk rather than diagnosing growth retardation directly.

  3. Placenta accreta:

    • Placenta accreta involves abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall, which is more likely to be diagnosed through ultrasound imaging with color Doppler of the placenta in later stages of pregnancy (typically after 20 weeks). Doppler studies of the uterine artery at 14 weeks are not helpful in diagnosing placenta accreta.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 214, 340, 712, 713, 777, 778.

questions.text: Blood test reports of a 24 weeks pregnant lady revealed AST and ALT>70 IU/l, bilirubin >1.2 mg/dl and platelet counts 90,000/mm3. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings of elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin along with low platelet count indicates diagnosis of HELLP syndrome. 

Tennesse criteria is used to diagnose HELLP syndrome. It includes-
  1. Platelet count <1 lac/mm3
  2. AST>70 IU/L
  3. LDH>600 
  4. Hemolysis




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 258, 259.

choices.text: Starts with or after contraction but ends always after contraction
Nadir of deceleration and peak of contraction do not coincide

questions.text: All are true about late deceleration except?
questions.solution:
Late decelerations are typically uniform in shape and duration, lasting longer than 30 seconds and returning to baseline after the contraction has ended.
  • Variable decelerations, on the other hand, are variable in shape, duration, and timing, and are usually caused by umbilical cord compression.

Late decelerations in cardiotocography (CTG) are characterized by: (Options)

  1. Starts with or after the contraction and ends after the contraction: True. Late decelerations occur after the onset of uterine contraction and resolve after the contraction ends.
  2. Occurs due to utero-placental insufficiency: True. They are caused by impaired oxygen transfer from the placenta to the fetus.
  3. Nadir of deceleration and peak of contraction do not coincide: True. The nadir (lowest point) of the deceleration occurs after the peak of the contraction.
  4. It is usually variable & short: False. Late decelerations are uniform and have a gradual onset and offset, typically lasting longer than variable decelerations.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 451, 452.

choices.text: IV iron sucrose only for non-compliance with oral tablets
Manage with increased iron content in diet

questions.text: As per Anemia Mukt Bharat, how is mild-moderate anemia treated in a pregnant woman of less than 34 weeks gestational age?
questions.solution:
Parental iron (IV Iron Sucrose or FCM) may be considered as the first line of management in pregnant women who are detected to be anemic late in pregnancy or in whom compliance is likely to be low (high chance of lost to follow-up).
  • According to operational guidelines of Anemia Mukt Bharat, mild to moderate cases of anemia in pregnant women are initially treated with 2 tablets of IFA.
  • If there is no response, IV iron sucrose is to given.



Reference: Anaemia Mukt Bharat scheme, National Health Mission, GoI guidelines (2018). URL: https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1448&lid=797

questions.text: Which is not a component of the biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Biophysical score Aka Hanning score. It is done with help of USG Done over 30 mins.

It has 5 components:
  1. Fetal tone = In 30 mins, 1 episode of fetal extension - flexion
  2. Fetal breathing movement ( 1 breathing movement x 30 secs)
  3. Gross body movements of fetus =3 body movements
  4. Single largest vertical Pocket of amniotic fluid 2cm
  5. NST: Reactive.
 
  • Each parameter is given a score of either 0/2
  • If total score= 8 or 10/10: Healthy pt.
  • Score 6 /10 or less = Reassessment after 2 weeks
  • <6/10 on reassessment= Fetal hypoxia.




Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 389, 390.

questions.text: A woman who presented with seizures at 30 weeks of pregnancy was started on MgSO4 therapy. What would be the first sign of MgSO4 toxicity seen in this patient?

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of events in Dilatation & Curettage (D&C) ? 
(i) Uterine sound 
(ii) Serial dilatations 
(iii) Curettage
(iv) Determining the size of the uterus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events for Dilation and Curettage (D&C) procedure is: (iv)-(i)-(ii)-(iii)
  1. Determining the size of the uterus: This is usually done by performing a pelvic examination or an ultrasound.
  2. Uterine sound: Once the size of the uterus is determined, a uterine sound is used to measure the depth of the uterus. The sound is a long, thin, and flexible rod that is inserted into the uterus through the cervix.
  3. Serial dilatations: After measuring the depth of the uterus, serial dilatations are performed to widen the cervix. This is done by inserting progressively larger dilators into the cervix until it is wide enough to allow the curette to pass through.
  4. Curettage: Once the cervix is dilated, a curette is inserted into the uterus to remove the lining of the uterus.



Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 210, 211, 239.

questions.text: Which of the following is meaning of the term Vagitus uterinus?
questions.solution:
• Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a fetus within the uterus, which can sometimes be heard in cases of fetal distress.

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Kassowitz's law states that the risk of vertical transmission of syphilis from an infected, untreated mother decreases as the maternal disease progresses. It is associated hence with congenital syphilis.

questions.text:
Which of the following is incorrect regarding MgSO4 in preeclampsia? 
1. MgSO4 should be given till 24 hours after delivery or 24 hours after the last convulsion, which is later
2. In renal failure, a loading dose can be given but a maintenance dose is adjusted based on renal function
3. MgSO4 covers seizures and hypertension simultaneously 
4. MgSO4 is a neuroprotective drug
questions.solution:
• Magnesium sulfate is not a primary antihypertensive agent.
  • While magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is commonly used for seizure prophylaxis in preeclampsia, it is important to note that it primarily targets the prevention and control of seizures rather than directly treating hypertension.
  • Hydralazine, labetalol, and nifedipine are the recommended first-line treatments for severe hypertension in pregnancy.
 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 719 .

choices.text: Elective cesarean section has no effect in reducing incidence of brachial plexus injury

Regular insulin is given by IV infusion pump

questions.text: Regarding the management of a diabetic woman in labour which is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• GDM patients should not be given a morning dose of insulin at the time of induction.
  • Because during the latent phase of labor, the metabolic demands are stable but during active labor there is increased metabolic demand and decreased insulin requirement.

questions.text: A 36 weeks pregnant lady presents with difficulty breathing and back pain. Her BP is 124/85. On examination, the symphysial fundal height is 41 cm, and the abdomen is tense, non-tender. Fetal parts were difficult to palpate. There is no bleeding p/v. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is a 36 week pregnant female experiencing dyspnea and back pain. There is a significant discordance (> 3 weeks) between her PoG and SFH.
In the normotensive patient, with a non-tender abdomen with difficulty in palpation of fetal parts and absence of any bleeding PV, this is likely to be due to polyhydramnios.
  • Abnormally increased amnionic fluid volume complicates 1 to 2 percent of singleton pregnancies.
  • Hydramnios may be categorized as mild is the AFI is 25 to 29.9 cm; moderate, is 30 to 34.9 cm; and severe, is ≥35 cm.
  • Using a single deepest pocket of amnionic fluid, as is done in multifetal gestations, mild hydramnios is defined as 8 to 9.9 cm, moderate as 10 to 11.9 cm, and severe hydramnios as ≥12 cm.
  • Mild hydramnios accounts for approximately two thirds of cases and is frequently idiopathic and benign.
By comparison, severe hydramnios is far more likely to have an underlying etiology and to have consequences or the pregnancy.


Fig: Amnionic fluid index (AFI) according to gestational age–specific and threshold values.


Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 257, 258.

questions.text: A female presents with 6 weeks amenorrhea with complaints of spotting and pain. An adnexal mass is felt and the USG shows uterine cavity with no fetus. The hCG levels are 2800 IU/L. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This female with secondary amenorrhea for 6 weeks has spotting with pain and presence of an adnexal mass, which on ultrasound reveals a uterine cavity without a living fetus and elevated hCG levels are findings that point towards a diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy.
  • The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea in a woman of childbearing age is pregnancy.
  • Hemodynamic instability or sudden onset of severe symptoms usually suggests a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • This patient is likely to have an unruptured ectopic pregnancy.
Medical management can be preferred in patients with the following:
  1. Hemodynamic stability
  2. Sac size
    1. In the absence of cardiac activity: <4 cm
    2. In the presence of cardiac activity: <3.5 cm
  3. hCG levels < 3000 IU/ L
  4. No other contraindications to methotrexate therapy
  • In this patient, it is not indicated specifically if any of the above criteria are not met, thus the preferred management would be a Methotrexate single-dose protocol where the calculated dose is administered as a single intramuscular injection is the treatment of choice.
  • Multi-dose protocol where the dose of methotrexate is given for 4 days on alternate days with leucovorin rescue in the intervening days is currently not used due to higher risk of toxicity. The single-dose protocol is less expensive, requires less intensive monitoring, and does not require leucovorin rescue. (option A)
  • Oral methotrexate is not used due to low success rate. (option B)
  • Definitive indications for surgical management include hemodynamically unstable patients, as in ruptured ectopic pregnancies. Salpingostomy or salpingectomy may be performed. (option D)

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 221,225.

questions.text: A pregnant female has complaints of light-headedness and dizziness on lying down. This is relieved when the patient lies in the left lateral position. What is the cause of the light-headedness?
questions.solution:
This scenario represents postural hypotension which is well-described as supine hypotension.
When the patient lies supine during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus has a compressive effect on the inferior vena cava and resultant decrease in venous return leading to described clinical features of syncope.

Reference: DC DUTTA's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th Edition, Page. No- 61.

questions.text: A patient is in labor and the following image shows the trace of her partogram. What is the next management action in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given graph represents the modified WHO partograph of a patient in labor which is a graphical representation of the progress of labor in which cervical dilatation and descent of fetal head is plotted against the time, as well as maternal and fetal vital parameters.
Summary of the partograph findings, as seen in this patient are summarized below:
  1. This a multiparous female (G2) with the fetus showing signs of fetal distress(bradycardia and meconium-stained liquor).
  2. 3+ molding i.e., fixed overlapping of bones is present
  3. Slow progression of labor (overall the rate of dilation has been 6 cm in 8 hours which is less than 1 cm/ hr.
  4. The contractions are seen to be adequate.
Thus, in a pregnant female with adequate contractions in the presence of molding and slow progress of labor with signs of fetal distress, the  diagnosis is likely to be cephalopelvic disproportion.
Due to the presence of fetal distress, the patient should be managed by an immediate cesarean section.

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 548.

questions.text: A pregnant female of 8 weeks POG came to the PHC with pallor. Her Hb is found to be Hb = 9 gm/dl. Which of  the following suggestions will you give to the mother?
questions.solution:
The scenario presents a female at 8 weeks gestation (first trimester) who has moderate anemia, defined as Hb ranging between 7 and 9.9.
As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat guidelines, this female requires treatment of anemia, and thus, will be treated as per the management protocol.
  • At all levels of care, the first level of treatment consists of double the prophylactic dose, that is, two tablets daily to be taken orally.
  • Thus, for this patient, this treatment should be initiated at the PHC visit itself at 8 weeks of gestation.
  • The female is followed up after 2 months and referred to FRU/ DH if no improvement after the first level of treatment.
Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 1048.

questions.text: A patient underwent hysteroscopic removal of a fibroid. A fluid deficit of 2000 mL is reported. What is the most common immediate complication?
questions.solution:
In the context of hysteroscopic procedures, the term fluid deficit refers to the difference between the volume of distension fluid introduced into the uterine cavity and the volume of fluid that is removed or accounted for during the procedure.
A large fluid deficit (given here 2000ml)  indicates that a significant amount of the distension fluid has been absorbed into the patient's bloodstream.
This may lead to fluid overload resulting in pulmonary edema.

Depending upon the type of fluid used and the health status of the patient, when the fluid deficit reaches 500 mL, the surgical team should pause and assess patient status.
Criteria for termination of the procedure (and evaluating the patient for hyponatremia) are:
  • Electrolyte-deficient media (hypoosmolar): 1000 mL
  • Electrolyte-rich media (iso osmolar): 2500 mL for young patients with no comorbidities. May need to be individualized as per patient risk factors.
Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 1054.

questions.text: Lady with 28 weeks of gestation presents with fever, acute pain abdomen, and mild leucocytosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, a 28-week pregnant woman presenting with fever, acute abdominal pain, and mild leukocytosis is most likely experiencing red degeneration of a fibroid. Red degeneration, a common complication of fibroids during pregnancy, occurs due to ischemia and subsequent breakdown of the fibroid. Key features of this condition include:

- Low-grade fever
- Tenderness of the uterus on palpation
- Elevated leukocyte count
- Elevated ESR

An ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis. Management typically involves non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and the condition is generally self-limiting.

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 159-161 .

choices.text: Preterm Premature rupture of membranes is a risk factor
The process of abortion can be halted by progesterone
IV oxytocin is used in cases where POG is >12 weeks

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman, G2A1, presents with heavy vaginal bleeding with cramp-like abdominal pain at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterine size corresponds to the period of gestation and active vaginal bleeding is noted with an open internal os. USG reveals absent fetal cardiac activity.
Which of the following statement is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of inevitable abortion
Inevitable abortion is a type of abortion where the abortive process has progressed to a state where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.
Risk factors:
• Preterm premature rupture of membranes
• Amniocentesis
• Prior second-trimester delivery
• Tobacco use
• Fetal surgery.
Management:
• IV Methergine is indicated if there is excessive bleeding when the cervix is dilated and uterine size is. <12 weeks.
• Before 12 weeks:
• Dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage
• Alternatively, suction and evacuation.
• After 12 weeks:
• Oxytocin drip, 10 units in 500mL of NS at 40-60 drips per minute.
The separated placenta is removed by ovum forceps and digital separation is indicated if the placenta is not separated.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition • Page 153-159

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Puerperal Pyrexia is true
questions.solution:
Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of >100.4 °F (38 °C or higher) on 2 separate occasions at 24 hours apart (excluding the first 24 hours) within the first 10 days following delivery.
In the first 24 hours, a slight rise in temperature is not uncommon and hence the first 24 hours are excluded to define puerperal pyrexia. Ref - William obstetrics 24th edition Page 682

choices.text: Measure beta HCG levels on day 4 and 7

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding per vagina and slight abdominal pain. A diagnosis of unruptured ectopic pregnancy was made. Baseline beta HCG was measured and medical management with 50mg/m2 of methotrexate was started (Day 1). The serum beta HCG level measured on Day 2 was more than the baseline beta HCG level. What is the appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
The patient has a small, unruptured ectopic pregnancy and was started on single-dose methotrexate (50 mg/m²).

Key points in medical management of ectopic pregnancy:

  • Single-dose methotrexate protocol:

    • Administer 50 mg/m² intramuscularly (Day 1).

    • Check beta-HCG on Day 4 and Day 7.

    • A ≥15% decline between Day 4 and Day 7 indicates likely resolution.

Important considerations:

  • Day 2 beta-HCG rise is not alarming. The single-dose protocol recommends checking on Day 4 and Day 7, not Day 2. Early rise may occur due to methotrexate effect.

  • Surgical intervention is only needed if:

    • Rupture occurs

    • Patient is hemodynamically unstable

    • Beta-HCG fails to decline adequately after methotrexate

  • Repeat methotrexate or alternative regimen (KCl, multi-dose) is considered after monitoring Day 4 and 7 beta-HCG if the response is inadequate.



Reference:Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 225-226

questions.text: A primigravida woman gives birth to a baby with the following defect. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
• Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect characterized by both anencephaly (absence of the cranial vault) and contiguous open spine (spina bifida) along the entire length of the neural tube.

  • In the image, there is exposed brain tissue with a defect extending down the spine, which differentiates it from:

    • Myelomeningoencephalocele: Herniation of meninges + neural tissue through a skull defect, usually localized.

    • Rachischisis: Open spinal defect without cranial involvement.

    • Meningoencephalocele: Herniation of meninges + brain tissue through a localized cranial defect.

Key point: Craniorachischisis represents the most severe form of neural tube defects, involving both cranial and spinal components.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 759

questions.text: A young primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted since her BP was 150/90 mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. On examination, she has pedal edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with hypertension (BP ≥140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks gestation), proteinuria (2+ on dipstick), and pedal edema at 32 weeks. These features are classical for preeclampsia.

Key points:

  • Timing: After 20 weeks of gestation.

  • Clinical features: Hypertension, proteinuria, edema, and sometimes headache, visual disturbances, or epigastric pain.

  • Differential diagnoses:

    • Placenta previa: Presents with painless vaginal bleeding, not hypertension.

    • Placental abruption: Painful vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, possible fetal distress.

    • Spontaneous abortion: Usually occurs before 20 weeks with bleeding and cramping.

Early diagnosis and management are important to prevent maternal and fetal complications such as eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, and intrauterine growth restriction.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 689-690

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she presented with seizures, aphasia, and hemiparesis. Which of the following investigations is useful to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents postpartum (day 3) with seizures, aphasia, and hemiparesis. This raises suspicion for cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST), which is a recognized postpartum complication, especially within the first week.

Key points:

  • Presentation: Seizures, focal neurological deficits (hemiparesis, aphasia), headache.

  • Best diagnostic test: MR venography (MRV) – it can directly visualize venous sinus occlusion.

  • Other options:

    • Lumbar puncture → not diagnostic; may be contraindicated if raised intracranial pressure.

    • X-ray head → normal in most CVST cases.

    • CSF culture → used for infections, not thrombosis.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 1132

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death?
questions.solution:
The direct causes of maternal death are those that result from obstetric complications of the pregnant state itself, including pregnancy, labor, and the postpartum period.

  • Eclampsia is a classic direct obstetric cause—it results from pregnancy-induced hypertension leading to seizures, and can directly cause maternal death.

  • Malaria, anemia, and heart disease are considered indirect causes, as they are pre-existing or concurrent conditions that complicate pregnancy but are not caused by pregnancy itself.


Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 610-611

questions.text: The screening method for GDM recommended in India is done between:
questions.solution:
• Recommended period: 24–28 weeks of gestation

    • This timing is chosen because insulin resistance increases in the second trimester due to placental hormones like human placental lactogen, progesterone, cortisol, and prolactin.

    • Screening earlier (<24 weeks) is less sensitive because glucose intolerance may not have manifested yet.

  • High-risk women:

    • Women with obesity, prior GDM, strong family history of diabetes, or polycystic ovarian syndrome may be screened earlier (in the first trimester).

      Recommended Screening Method (India, as per Ministry of Health & WHO/IDF guidelines)

  • Single-step 75 g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT):

    1. Administer 75 g oral glucose in the morning (fasting not mandatory in some Indian protocols).

    2. Measure plasma glucose 2 hours after glucose intake.

  • Interpretation (WHO/India criteria):

    • 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L) → Gestational diabetes diagnosed.

      Advantages of 24–28 Weeks Screening

  1. Most cases of GDM appear after mid-pregnancy; earlier screening could miss cases.

  2. Early diagnosis allows timely dietary, lifestyle, and medical management to reduce complications like macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and preeclampsia.



Reference:DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition page no 263-266

questions.text: A 24-year-old Rh-negative G2P1 mother was delivered by cesarean section at 37 weeks gestation. The baby is found to be Rh-positive. To access fetomaternal transfusion a Kleihaeur Betke test was done which detected 20 ml of fetal RBCs. What is the dose of anti-D that should be administered to the mother? (Assume fetal hematocrit to be 50 percent)
questions.solution:
Anti-D dose (µg) = (Volume of fetal RBCs ÷ Fetal hematocrit) ÷ 30 × 300

  • Volume of fetal RBCs = from Kleihauer-Betke test (mL)

  • Fetal hematocrit = as a decimal (e.g., 50% = 0.5)

  • 1 vial (300 µg) protects against 30 mL of fetal whole blood

Example: (20 ÷ 0.5) ÷ 30 × 300 = 400 µg


Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 358-359

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation, presented with severe abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements. On examination, her uterus Is tender. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is abruptio placenta.

  • Clinical features pointing toward abruptio placenta:

    • Severe abdominal pain – sudden and continuous, unlike the painless bleeding of placenta previa.

    • Vaginal bleeding – may be visible or concealed behind the placenta.

    • Loss of fetal movements / fetal distress – due to compromised placental perfusion.

    • Uterine tenderness and hypertonicity – hallmark of placental abruption.

  • Differentiation from placenta previa:

    • Placenta previa usually presents with painless, bright red vaginal bleeding.

    • Uterus is soft, and fetal movements are usually preserved until labor.

  • Polyhydramnios presents mainly with abdominal distension, not acute pain and bleeding.

  • Preterm labor presents with regular uterine contractions and cervical changes; bleeding is not always present.


Reference:DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page no 297,283

questions.text: The ultrasound finding of a 24-year-old primi with 3 months of amenorrhoea is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The key clue in this question is the reference to “snowstorm appearance” on ultrasound, which is classically seen in a hydatidiform mole.

Hydatidiform Mole – Classic Ultrasound Features:

  • “Snowstorm” or “cluster of grapes” appearance due to swollen chorionic villi and absence of a viable fetus.

  • No fetal parts visible.

  • Increased echogenicity of the uterus filled with vesicular material.

  • Typically presents in the first trimester with:

    • Painless vaginal bleeding

    • Uterus larger than gestational age

    • Extremely elevated β-hCG

    • Hyperemesis gravidarum

    • Theca lutein cysts in ovaries (in some cases)

      Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • 2. Oligohydramnios – Refers to decreased amniotic fluid volume, seen in later pregnancy; not associated with a snowstorm appearance.

  • 3. Multiple renal cysts in the fetus – Seen in fetal kidneys, not as diffuse uterine contents, and usually diagnosed later in gestation.

  • 4. Ectopic pregnancy – Typically lacks intrauterine gestational sac; not associated with snowstorm appearance.

    Summary:

A "snowstorm" appearance on ultrasound in a woman with 3 months of amenorrhea strongly indicates a hydatidiform mole, which is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD).

Complete vs Partial Mole 
 

Feature Complete Mole Partial Mole
Karyotype 46,XX or 46,XY (diploid, all paternal origin) 69,XXY / 69,XXX / 69,XYY (triploid, maternal + paternal)
Fetal tissue Absent Present (may see fetal parts or heartbeat)
Villi All villi hydropic Some villi hydropic, others normal
Trophoblastic proliferation Diffuse, circumferential, marked Focal, mild
Uterine size Larger than expected for gestational age Small or appropriate
hCG levels Very high (>100,000 mIU/mL often) Moderately elevated
Theca lutein cysts Common (due to very high hCG) Rare
Symptoms More pronounced (hyperemesis, early preeclampsia) Less severe or asymptomatic
Risk of malignancy (GTN) Higher (~15–20%) Lower (~1–5%)
Fetal heart sounds Absent May be present
P57 immunostaining Negative (no maternal genome) Positive (maternal genome present)

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th edition- page no 396

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for expectant management in unruptured ectopic gestation?
questions.solution:
Expectant management refers to careful observation without active medical or surgical intervention in selected cases of unruptured ectopic pregnancy, particularly when the body appears to be resolving the ectopic naturally.

Indications for Expectant Management of Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy:

  • Patient is asymptomatic (no abdominal pain or bleeding)

  • Hemodynamically stable

  • No signs of rupture on ultrasound

  • Ectopic mass size < 3–4 cm

  • No fetal cardiac activity

  • Serum β-hCG levels are low (commonly <200 mIU/mL)

  • β-hCG levels are falling on serial measurements (at least 15% decrease in 48 hours)

  • Patient is reliable for follow-up

    Why Option 1 is NOT an Indication:

A gestational sac size > 4 cm increases the risk of tubal rupture, even if the patient is asymptomatic at the time of presentation. Therefore, it is not safe to observe such a case expectantly.

Why the Other Options Are True Indications:

  • Asymptomatic: Suitable for observation if other criteria are met.

  • Decreasing beta hCG: Suggests resolving pregnancy.

  • Initial β-hCG < 200 mIU/mL: Strong predictor of spontaneous resolution.
     

Reference:Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 226-227

choices.text: 2 F, the pulse is 118 bpm and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding and is diagnosed as acute appendicitis. What is the next step of management? Complete blood count * Hemoglobin: 11g/dL * Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/yL * Platelets: 150,000 cells/yL Liver function tests * Aspartate transaminase (AST): 40U/L * Alanine transaminase (ALT): 48U/L Urinalysis * Protein: negative * Pus cells: 1-2/HPF * Bacteria: none USG Abdomen: Reveals a 7mm diameter, aperistaltic, noncompressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida at 1Oweeks gestation comes to the ER with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting began one day back and now the patient is unable to tolerate fluids. She complains of pain in the right upper quadrant which started a few hours back. On examination, her temperature is 100.2 F, the pulse is 118 bpm and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding and is diagnosed as acute appendicitis. What is the next step of management? Complete blood count * Hemoglobin: 11g/dL * Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/yL * Platelets: 150,000 cells/yL Liver function tests * Aspartate transaminase (AST): 40U/L * Alanine transaminase (ALT): 48U/L Urinalysis * Protein: negative * Pus cells: 1-2/HPF * Bacteria: none USG Abdomen: Reveals a 7mm diameter, aperistaltic, noncompressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, examination findings, and ultrasound results strongly indicate acute appendicitis in a 22-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks gestation.

Key points favoring appendicitis:

  • Right upper quadrant abdominal pain with tenderness and guarding.

  • Elevated leukocyte count (13,000 cells/µL).

  • Ultrasound shows an inflamed, noncompressible, dilated appendix (7 mm diameter).

  • No evidence of preeclampsia (normal BP, no proteinuria), no signs of infection elsewhere.

    Management considerations in appendicitis during early pregnancy:

  • Appendicitis is the most common non-obstetric surgical emergency in pregnancy.

  • Delay in treatment increases the risk of appendix rupture, peritonitis, fetal loss, and maternal morbidity.

  • Surgery is generally safe in all trimesters but is ideally done early to prevent complications.

  • Conservative management is usually not recommended in confirmed appendicitis due to the risk of progression.

  • Waiting till the second trimester is inappropriate here because symptoms are acute and worsening.

  • Reassurance alone is insufficient and unsafe.

    Therefore, the next step of management is: Do appendicectomy

    Additional notes:

  • Laparoscopic appendectomy is preferred if expertise is available, as it is associated with less postoperative pain, shorter hospital stay, and quicker recovery.

  • Perioperative care must include fetal monitoring and precautions to minimize uterine irritation.

  • Antibiotics covering common pathogens should be given perioperatively.

  • Close postoperative monitoring for maternal and fetal well-being is mandatory.


Reference:Williams Obstetrics 25th edition page no 1061

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not the first line of treatment for a 13-year-old girl's anovulatory irregular uterine bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is 4. Danazol
Androgens (Danazol) are not recommended, though effective, because of androgenic effects in young girls.

Management of Anovulatory irregular bleeding in Adolescent girls:
  • In an acute episode of bleeding, i.v. Estrogen 25 mg 6-8 hourly will control bleeding in 24-48 hours. Thereafter, Estrogen for 21 days with progestogen added for 10 days for 3-6 cycles will regularise the cycles.
  • In chronic menorrhagia, oral combined pills or cyclical progestogen is the first line of treatment. About 70%-80% responds well.
  • NSAIDs: Mefenamic acid 250-500 mg t.i.d during periods. Naproxen, ibuprofen are also given.
  • Tranexamic acid being an anti-fibrinolytic drug may be beneficial in controlling bleeding



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 139, 140.

questions.text: A young woman with average height and little to no pubertal development and anosmia can be seen in
questions.solution:
Kallmann's Syndrome
• It is a form of Hypogonadotrophic Hypogonadism (HH).
• Failure of communication between the hypothalamus and thhe anterior pituitary gland.
• Hypothalamic neurons (GNRH neurons) fail to migrate into the hypothalamus during embryonic development.

Clinical Features:
• Puberty failure
• Lack of testicle development in men
• Primary amenorrhea or failure to start menstruation in women
• Poorly defined secondary sexual characteristics
• Infertility
• Cleft palate or other craniofacial defects
• Anosmia or hyposmia

Investigations
• Low serum testosterone
• Low serum estrogens
• Low levels of LH and FSH
• Karyotype
• X-ray
• MRI

Mode of inheritance:
Genetic mutations in the KAL-I gene (X-linked) or as an autosomal dominant or recessive fashion.

Treatment:
Menstruation can be induced with combined estrogen and progestin therapy. Induction of ovulation is successful with exogenous gonadotropins.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 142, 143.

choices.text: Progesterone challenge test and look for withdrawal bleeding

questions.text: A female patient, age 24, has been experiencing amenorrhea for three months. The levels of LH and FSH are three times above average. What should we do next?
questions.solution:
Check serum estradiol levels
The history of Amenorrhea with raised FSH and LH point towards diagnosis of Premature ovarian insufficiency.
In women with POI, estrogen levels are usually low, because the ovaries are not functioning properly in their role as estrogen producers.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 94, 95, 143, 151.

questions.text: Which of these symptoms characterises Asherman syndrome?
questions.solution:
Scar tissue builds up inside the uterus and/or cervix, causing Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions or synechiae). The infective causes of these adhesions are schistosomiasis and TB, with dilatation and curettage(Most common), and uterine surgery being other causes.
Clinical Features are
1. Infertility
2.Amennorrhea
3. Hypomenorrhea

Oligomenorrhea is when the no of days after which mens occurs is delayed. It is seen in PCOS. 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 123,147.

questions.text: What is the fixative used in the PAP smear?
questions.solution:
95% ethyl alcohol
The fixative used is 95% ethyl alcohol+5 % ether.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 7-9.
Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 660.

questions.text: Select the drug of choice for precocious puberty in girls.
questions.solution:
GnRH analogue
The objectives of treatment for children with central precocious puberty (CPP) are to avoid psychosocial problems caused by early pubertal development and to normalize adult height (AH). A long-acting GnRH analog is the treatment of choice for CPP.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 84.

questions.text: You were sent a young woman who has primary amenorrhea. Examination indicates no axillary hairs and typical breast development. An examination of the pelvis reveals a clitoromegaly and a normally formed vagina. The gonads can be seen in the inguinal area on ultrasonography. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome
Findings of clitoromegaly with no axillary hairs and typical breast development are suggestive of partial AIS.
 
  • A genetic condition where affected people have male chromosomes and male gonads with complete or partial feminization of the external genitals
  • An inherited X-linked recessive disease with a mutation in the Androgen Receptor (AR) gene resulting in:
    - Functioning Y sex chromosome
    - Abnormally on X sex chromosome
  • Types
    - CAIS (completely insensitive to AR gene)
        • External female genitalia
        • Lacking female internal organs
    - PAIS (partially sensitive-varying degrees)
        • External genitalia apperance on a spectrum (male to female)
    - MAIS (mildly sensitive, rare)
        • Impaired sperm development and/or impaired masculinization
  • Also called Testicular Feminization





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 109, 113.

choices.text: Decreased level of adrenal androgens at puberty
Increased sensitivity of HPO axis to estrogen

questions.text: Which of the following factors causes female pubertal development?
questions.solution:
• Pulsatile release of GnRH during sleep
  • Pulsatile release of GnRH is facilitated by Kisspeptin during puberty. 
  • Puberty is initiated when GnRH is secreted in a pulsatile manner by hypothalamic neurons. This pulsatile release of GnRH allows pituitary gonadotrophs to release LH and FSH. LH begins androstenedione production in ovarian theca cells, while FSH allows aromatase in follicular cells to synthesize estradiol.
  • An increase in serum estradiol allows breast tissue to enlarge and influences linear bone growth and epiphyseal fusion, playing a significant role in the pubertal growth spurt.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 75.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman's mother complains that her period hasn't started when she brings her to your clinic. A general check reveals pubic hair and normally developing breasts. On pelvic examination, the uterus is not palpable and the vaginal termination is blind. You suspect which of the following?
questions.solution:
Mullerian agenesis
Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser Syndrome
• Congenital absence of uterus & vagina (small rudimentary uterus may be present)
• Normal ovaries +
• Genotype - 46XX; Phenotype-Female
• Associated with other congenital, renal aplasia, cervicothoracic somite dysplasia.
Diagnosis: At puberty with C/O primary amenorrhoea. Normal development of breast, body, proportionate hair distribution, external genitalia.
Vaginal vault - absent completely / short vagina can be present
Normal hormone profile.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 143, 144.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman visits your clinic to have her infertility evaluated. Asherman's syndrome can be seen on a hysterosalpingogram. What signs will the patient experience?
questions.solution:
• In Ashermann syndrome, Intrauterine adhesions cause total or partial obliteration of the endocervix and/or uterine cavity, resulting in hypomenorrhea or amenorrhea, infertility, and pregnancy loss.
     
  • Scar tissue builds up inside the uterus and/or cervix, causing Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions or synechiae). The infective causes of these adhesions are schistosomiasis and TB, with dilatation and curettage(Most common), and uterine surgery being other causes.
Clinical Features are
1. Infertility
2.Amennorrhea
3. Hypomenorrhea



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 123,147.

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented with complaints of pain in abdomen and menorrhagia. Endometrial biopsy was normal and sonogram of uterus showed diffusely enlarged uterus with no adnexal mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Complaint of menorrhagia with diffusely enlarged uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis.
  • Adenomyosis is a clinical condition where endometrial glands are found in the myometrium of the uterus.
  • One in three patients with adenomyosis is asymptomatic, but the rest may present with heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, or infertility.
  • Heavy menstrual bleeding is the most common symptom.
  • Fibroid uterus will have asymmetrically enlarged uterus with or without symtoms.

questions.text: A woman who had an abortion six months ago is currently experiencing secondary amenorrhea. Her FSH levels were 6 mlU/ml. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Secondary Amenorrhea with normal FSH levels are suggestive of Uterine synechiae.
 
  • Aggressive uterine curettage during early pregnancy can damage the basal layer of the endometrium, leading to scarring and adhesions within the uterus. This scarring interferes with normal endometrial growth and shedding, resulting in secondary amenorrhea, as observed in this patient. These intrauterine adhesions are referred to as uterine synechiae or Asherman syndrome.
  • In Asherman syndrome, there is no disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, so follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels remain within the normal range, typically between 4 and 25 IU/L, as seen in this patient.
  • In contrast, with pituitary dysfunction, FSH levels are usually decreased. In cases of ovarian dysfunction, the loss of negative feedback from ovarian hormones (such as estrogen) on the pituitary and hypothalamus leads to increased FSH levels, often rising above 25 IU/L
  • Asherman syndrome is characterized by a range of intrauterine scarring, which can include thin adhesions, dense bands, or complete obliteration of the uterine cavity. This condition typically results from endometrial damage following aggressive curettage, often related to miscarriage or elective abortion. It can also arise from other uterine surgeries, such as myomectomy or cesarean delivery, or from infections associated with intrauterine devices.
  • Patients with Asherman syndrome may present with amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss due to inadequate placentation, depending on the extent of the scarring.
  • On hysterosalpingography (HSG) or saline-infusion sonography, Asherman syndrome is identified by multiple filling defects. However, a definitive diagnosis is made through hysteroscopy. The preferred surgical treatment for the syndrome is hysteroscopic lysis of adhesions.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 153, 154. 
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 374, 375.

questions.text: A complex total abdominal hysterectomy was performed on a 52-year-old woman two weeks prior, and she now has persistent urine leakage and dysuria. Vesicovaginal fistula is suspected. The investigation of choice for making a diagnosis is:
questions.solution:

  • Cystoscopy: Cystoscopy with indigo carmine excretion test (5 mL intravenous) enables visualisation of the dye from each ureteric orifice individually and identifies which ureter is damaged. It helps in knowing the site and number of fistulae. It is the investigation of choice in VVF.

questions.text: Name the  HSG finding displayed below:
questions.solution:
This is a HSG picture showing single Uterine horn suggestive of Unicornuate Uterus.

Mullerian abnormalities :- 
Type 1 :- MRHK or Mullerian agenesis 
Type 2 :- Unicornuate uterus -1 sided mullerian duct develops - never leads to transverse lie (PYQ)
Type 3 :- Didelphic uterus - lack of fusion of both the mullerian ducts 
Type 4:- Bicornuate uterus - incomplete fusion 
-angle b/w 2 horns more than 75 degrees 
Type 5:- Septate uterus - septa which forms after fusion fails to resolve 
- mc type 
- mc type causing infertility 
-angle less than 75 degress 
- Treatment - metroplasty ,hysteroscopic septal resection(PYQ)
Type 6 :- Arcuate uterus - flat topped 
- no anatomical abnormality 
Type 7:- DES related anomalies - hypoplastic uterus ,T shaped uterus

Diagnosis :- 
1. Hysterosalpingography 
2. IOC = 3D USG 
3. Gold Standard - MRI 
4. BEST - Laparoscopy + Hysteroscopy(PYQ)

questions.text: Name the function of the instrument:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. laparoscopic sterilization
 
  • A Falope ring (or Y-ligation) is a ligature that is applied to the fallopian tubes during laparoscopic sterilization, a type of birth control. The laparoscopic ring applicator is a device used to quickly and accurately apply a Falope ring onto the fallopian tubes.
  • The applicator helps to ensure that each Falope ring is placed exactly in the correct location.
  • The device is made up of a long handle and the actual applicator, which consists of two arms that hold the Falope ring in its central chamber. The arms of the applicator are inserted into the fallopian tubes and then the Falope ring is released from the central chamber, applying the ligature to the fallopian tubes.
  • The device is designed in such a way that it can be used in any standard laparoscopy procedure.




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 635.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl's mother brings her to the gynaecology OPD complaining that the girl hasn't reached menarche. She reports having periodic stomach ache. Further inspection reveals middle abdominal edema. A bulging membrane is discovered in the vagina upon rectal examination.
questions.solution:
Bulge in vagina suggests imperforate hymen.

  • An imperforate hymen is a congenital abnormality where the hymen completely covers the vaginal opening, preventing menstrual blood from exiting the body.

  • Primary Symptoms: It often causes primary amenorrhea (absence of menstruation), cyclic pelvic pain, abdominal swelling, and sometimes urinary retention in adolescent girls.

  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made through a physical exam and may be supported by ultrasound to assess the extent of the blockage and trapped menstrual blood (hematocolpos).
    Treatment is by giving a cruciate incision. 

In Transverse vaginal septum bulging membrane PV wouldn't be seen.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is not an oral contraceptive pill's mode of operation?
questions.solution:
Ocps decrease the gonadotropin secretion.


Mode of action
• oestrogen inhibits secretion of FSH via negative feedback on the anterior pituitary, and thus suppresses development of the ovarian follicle
• progestogen inhibits secretion of LH and thus prevents ovulation; it also makes the cervical mucus less suitable for the passage of sperm
• oestrogen and progestogen act in concert to alter the endometrium in such a way as to discourage implantation.

They may also interfere with the coordinated contractions of cervix, uterus and fallopian tubes that facilitate fertilisation and implantation.

questions.solution:

So in these patients IUCD can be used with a shorter thread.
Condoms can be used but IUDs have lesser failure rate hence is better answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a possible cause of secondary amenorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Kalman syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea
Kallmann syndrome is a condition characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell. This disorder is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which is a condition resulting from a lack of production of certain hormones that direct sexual development.

          Kallmann's Syndrome
• It is a form of Hypogonadotrophic Hypogonadism (HH).
• Failure of communication between the hypothalamus and the anterior pituitary gland.
• Hypothalamic neurons (GNRH neurons) fail to migrate into the hypothalamus during embryonic development.

Clinical Features:
• Puberty failure
• Lack of testicle development in men
• Primary amenorrhea or failure to start menstruation in women
• Poorly defined secondary sexual characteristics
• Infertility
• Cleft palate or other craniofacial defects.
• Anosmia or hyposmia

Investigations
• Low serum testosterone
• Low serum estrogens
• Low levels of LH and FSH
• Karyotype
• X-ray
• MRI

Mode of inheritance:
• Genetic mutations in the KAL-I gene (X-linked) or as an
   autosomal dominant or recessive fashion.

Treatment:
Menstruation can be induced with combined estrogen and progestin
therapy. Induction of ovulation is successful with exogenous gonadotropins.
