choices.text: Anatomical difference between right and left side
Difference in blood supply to both sides
Right handedness is more common in the population

questions.text: Which of the following reasons is false for a study that discovered that the right ovary ovulates more than the left?
questions.solution:
All are possible explanation for the cause except that Option 3: Right handedness is more common in population
It is thought that right-sided predominance was either inherited or resulted from variations in the ovarian vasculature.
 
  • In a study conducted, it was seen that For both fertile and infertile women ovulation from the right ovary occurred more often than from the left ovary (55 versus 45%; P: < 0.005).
  • The ratio of pregnancies from right-sided ovulation (approximately 64%) per total number of pregnancies was higher than that of right-sided ovulation (approximately 55%) during non-pregnant cycles (P: < 0.0001).
  • Mid-luteal serum oestradiol and testosterone were higher (P: < 0.05) in right-sided ovulation than left-sided.
  • Taken together, in both fertile and infertile women the fertility potential of oocytes from the right ovary surpasses that of the left ovary.


Reference: Fukuda, M et al. “Right-sided ovulation favours pregnancy more than left-sided ovulation.” Human reproduction (Oxford, England) vol. 15,9 (2000): 1921-6. doi:10.1093/humrep/15.9.1921. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10966987/

questions.text: Which of the following treatments should be given to a patient complaining of a copious vaginal discharge and pruritus, although there is no cervical discharge on speculum examination?
questions.solution:
Metronidazole and fluconazole should be given for the management of this patient. (Option 1)
 
  • The patient is having copious discharge which may be phyiological or due to Bacterial vaginosis. Pruritus is a common symptom of Candida infection.
  • Therefore, This patient should be treated for both Bacterial Vaginosis and Candidiasis with Metronidazole and fluconazole.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 329-331.

questions.text: The following is not a part of the Spielberg's criteria:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Normal ovaries
Diagnosis of ovarian ectopic 
The Spielberg criteria are essential for confirmation of early ovarian pregnancy: 
a) fallopian tube at the affected site must be intact 
b) the gestational sac must occupy the normal position of the ovary 
c) the gestational sac must be connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament 
d) ovarian tissue must be located in the sac wall, which is essential for confirmation of early ovarian pregnancy

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 231.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of Physiological Vaginal Discharge?
questions.solution:
Physiological vaginal discharge is colourless , odourless and cyclical. It varies depending upon the level of hormones Estrogen and progesterone in the body.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 328, 329.

questions.text: What age should the investigation for primary amenorrhea be conducted in a girl who has fully developed secondary sexual characteristics?
questions.solution:
Amenorrhea
Literally, amenorrhea means 'without menses'. By definition, amenorrhea is the absence of menstruation. Amenorrhea may be primary or secondary.

Primary amenorrhea is diagnosed if:
(1) the absence of menstruation by the age of 13 years in the absence of growth or development of secondary sex characters. or
(2) no menstruation by the age of 15 even with development of secondary sex characters.
(3) If menstruation doesn't occur after 3 years of Thelarche.

Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three cycle intervals or six months in females who were previously menstruating.

Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/causes-of-primary-amenorrhea

questions.text: What is the average blood loss during menstruation?
questions.solution:
Normal blood flow during menses is 30-80 ml
Remember the following terms

• Menorrhagia: Excessive (>80 ml) & / or prolonged menstruation(>7), at regular intervals
• Metrorrhagia - Irregular, frequent bleeding of varying amounts but not excessive
• Menometrorrhagia Prolonged or excessive bleeding at irregular intervals
• Polymenorrhea Regular bleeding at intervals of less than 21 days
• Oligomenorrhea Bleeding at intervals greater than 35 days - may be irregular
• Intermenstrual Uterine bleeding between regular cycles


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 67.

questions.text: When the pH of vagina is lowest ?
questions.solution:
#Controversial question
 
  • In normal pregnancy (Option 1) vaginal pH was found to be between 3.8 and 4.0 and is the lowest among other given options.
  • Vaginal pH in Puberty (Option 4) may also fall to 4.
  • So Correct answer should be: Option 1> Option 4
 
  • The vaginal acidity is due to lactic acid which may be present in a variable amount.
  • The pH value is 5.7 in the newborn and reaches 6 to 8 in children, and falls to 4 at Puberty.
  • During pregnancy, the pH value is usually 4.
  • After menopause, the pH rises to 7.
  • The normal pH in healthy women during the child bearing period is above 4.5



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 328.
Riedewald, S et al. “Vaginal and cervical pH in normal pregnancy and pregnancy complicated by preterm labor.” Journal of perinatal medicine vol. 18,3 (1990): 181-6. doi:10.1515/jpme.1990.18.3.181. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2384841/

questions.text: Vaginal Discharge in an 8 year old Pre-pubertal girl is mainly due to-
questions.solution:
• Vulvovaginitis is an inflammation of the vulva and vaginal tissues . 
  • This is common problem in prepubertal girls. 
  • It is typically not caused by a specific pathogen and is not treated with antibiotics. 
  • It can also be caused by infection, irritation, a  foreign body, allergy, or systemic disease.
  • Physiological leucorrhea is more common in puberty due to hormonal changes.
  • Bacterial vaginosis and sexually transmitted diseases are less likely in pre-pubertal girls.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 333.

choices.text: Women who menstruate more than every 24 days
Women who menstruate less often than every 35 days
Women with menstrual flow for more than 5 days
Women with monthly menstrual blood loss more than 80 ml

questions.text: Exception to further evaluation is -
questions.solution:
Correct option 3:Women with menstrual flow for more than 5 days 
Rest all the options denote abnormalities of menstrual cycle and need further evaluation.

• Menorrhagia: Excessive (>80 ml) & / or prolonged menstruation (>7), at regular intervals
• Metrorrhagia - Irregular, frequent bleeding of varying amounts but not excessive
• Menometrorrhagia Prolonged or excessive bleeding at irregular intervals
• Polymenorrhea Regular bleeding at intervals of less than 21 days
• Oligomenorrhea Bleeding at intervals greater than 35 days - may be irregular
• Intermenstrual Uterine bleeding between regular cycles


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 122, 123.

questions.text: Where do we see Swiss cheese pattern endometrium -
questions.solution:
Metropathia Haemorrahagia (Schroeder's diseases)
• Seen in women between 40 to 50 years.
• Not related to parity.
• Typical history - 6 to 8 weeks amenorrhoea followed by menorrhagia (painless).
• Uterus is just bulky (myohyperplasia).
• HPE - cystoglandular hyperplasia or Swiss cheese appearance.
• May be associated with follicular cyst ovary (1 or both)





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 133.

questions.text: What is not true about Halban's Disease?
questions.solution:
• The persistence of the corpus luteum without pregnancy is called Halban syndrome.
  • Progesterone release from the corpus luteum continues.
  • It manifests itself in the clinic with progesterone breakthrough hemorrhage and adnexal mass formation occurs after menstrual delay.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: Which contraceptive method use after molar pregnancy is contraindicated/not indicated?
questions.solution:
CuT is not used due to risk of perforation as uterus is friable and use of IUCD can increase risk of bleeding. 

Contraception post Molar Pregnancy
  • Barrier methods until normal Beta -hCG level.
  • Once hCG level have normalised: Combined oral contraceptive (COC) pill may be used.
  • If oral COC was started before the diagnosis of GTD, COC can be continued as its potential to increase risk of GTN is very low
  • IUCD like Cu-T should not be used until  Beta-hCG levels are normal to reduce risk of uterine perforation.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 228.

questions.text: The area drawn in green colour represents:
questions.solution:
The green color area depicts mid-pelvis. It is bounded by the plane of greatest pelvic dimension above and mid-pelvis plane below. 
 

  • Location:

    • The mid-pelvis is the space between the pelvic inlet (upper border) and the pelvic outlet (lower border).
    • It is narrower than the pelvic inlet but wider than the pelvic outlet.
 

  • Significance in Labor:

    • The fetus must navigate through the mid-pelvis during the second stage of labor (descent). This involves the engagement, descent, and rotation of the fetal head.
    • In cases where the fetus is in occipital-posterior or other malpositions, the mid-pelvis may present challenges for the fetus to rotate and descend properly.







Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 101, 102, 104.

questions.text: A 25 years old lady with a 24 months baby has heavy irregular bleeding during menstruation. The baby is on breast feed. Which of the following contraceptive agent is advised to such a patient?
questions.solution:
The contraceptive of choice in a lactating mother with heavy irregular bleeding is MALA-N. 
 
  • MALA N is a combined oral contraceptive (COC) that contains 20-30 mcg of ethinyl estradiol (EE2) and 0.15 mg of levonorgestrel. It works by inhibiting ovulation through the suppression of pituitary hormones, FSH and LH.
 
  • COCs have the lowest failure rates and are effective in managing conditions like polymenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia. However, the risk of thromboembolism is highest during the first 6 weeks postpartum (puerperal period) with COCs, and they are known to suppress lactation.
 
  • In this case, since the child is 24 months old (and complementary feeding typically begins at 6 months, meaning the child is not fully dependent on breastmilk for nutrition) and the woman is well beyond the puerperal period, MALA N can be safely used.



Other options:

  • Option 1: Norethisterone enanthate depot is an intramuscular injection given every 2 months. Though it is suitable for lactating women, it has an increased risk of irregular menstrual cycle and low BMD. So, it is not preferred in this case.
 
  • Option 2: Copper T is not recommended for this patient, as it may worsen menorrhagia and lead to anemia.
 
  • Option 3: Progestasert is a hormone-releasing IUCD that prevents sperm entry by creating a thick mucus plug at the cervix. Its use is limited in cases of heavy, unexplained bleeding.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 682.

Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition, Page no 269-271, 273-277.

questions.text: Which one of the following option is a contraindication for the use of contraceptive shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Copper containing IUCD- Multiload 375.
  • Among the given options, undiagnosed vaginal bleeding is an absolute contraindication for its use. 





Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 615, 616, 630.

choices.text: Avoid intercourse for 1 month; Defer pregnancy for at least 6 months
Avoid intercourse for 3 months; Defer pregnancy for at least 1 year
Avoid intercourse for 6 months; Defer pregnancy for at least 2 years
Avoid intercourse for 1 year; Defer pregnancy for at least 6 years

questions.text: A young lady was operated for Vesicovaginal fistula. As a doctor, what advice will you give her at the time of discharge?
questions.solution:
A patient who has undergone vesicovaginal fistula repair, sexual intercourse should be avoided for at least 3 months whereas pregnancy should be avoiding for an year. 



Reference: William's Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 580.

Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition, Page no 220-223.

questions.text: Study the hysterosalpingogram given below and make a diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of septate uterus. 
 
  • It shows smooth fundal contour with widely diverging horns and an intercornual angle of less than 75 degrees. 
 
  • Bicornuate uterus, on the other hand, will show indented fundus with an intercornual angle of more than 75 degrees. 


Reference: William's Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 34, 35, 43, 421, 422.

Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 71, 72.

questions.text: All are non-contraception health benefits of OCP's except
questions.solution:
Non contraceptive benefits of OCPs:
  • Reduced dysmenorrhea
  • Ovarian cysts
  • Anemia
  • Endometriosis
  • Fibroids
  • Reduced risk of endometrial and ovarian cancers.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition Page no 263-265.

questions.text:
Recombinant HPV vaccine is based on which viral protein? 
1. L1 
2. L2
3. E1 , E2
4. E6, E7
questions.solution:
• HPV vaccine is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
 
  • The recombinant HPV vaccine is based on the L1 protein, which is the major capsid protein of the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • The L1 protein is expressed in yeast cells to produce virus-like particles (VLPs), which mimic the outer structure of the virus.
  • These VLPs are used in the vaccine to stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against HPV, thereby preventing infection.
 
  • L2 is the minor capsid protein but is not the primary target for the recombinant vaccines.
  • E1, E2, E6, and E7 are other proteins involved in HPV replication and oncogenesis but are not the basis for the current vaccines.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 647-650.

questions.text: An NCCT scan was suggested for a lady of reproductive age. She presented with a history of recent and rapid-onset headaches. Which of the following enquires need to be made by the radiology technician prior to the scan?
questions.solution:
• Pregnancy needs to be ruled out before performing NCCT in a woman of reproductive age group.
  • It’s important to assess the possibility of pregnancy in women of reproductive age, as certain imaging modalities should be approached with caution or avoided in pregnant patients to avoid radiation induced risks to the fetus.
 
  • Pregnancy: Exposure to radiation during the early stages of pregnancy can pose a risk to the fetus, especially during the first trimester. It is important to rule out pregnancy to ensure the safety of the patient and the fetus.
  • If there is any chance the patient could be pregnant, alternative imaging methods (such as MRI) or shielding may be considered.


Other options:
 
  • History of fall: Not specifically relevant for assessing risks related to the CT scan procedure.
  • History of hypertension: While important for clinical management, it does not directly impact the safety of a non-contrast CT scan.
  • Cochlear implant: Not a concern for non-contrast CT scans as CT scans do not use magnetic fields like MRI. However, this would be important to consider before an MRI scan.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 479, 736, 817.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl presented to the OPD with a webbed neck shield chest, widely spaced nipple and absent pubic hair. Streak ovaries were revealed on USG. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Turner’s syndrome : 45 XO

Features:
  • Short stature
  • Triangular face
  • Neck: Loose skin folds and Webbed neck
  • Chest : Shield (flat) chest & widely spaced nipples.
  • Increased carrying angle = >135° i.e. Cubitus vagus
  • Heart defects : Bicuspid aortic valve > Coarctation of Aorta.
  • IQ : normal.





Reference: Nelson's Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 669, 3003.

questions.text: Which of the following method of contraception is irreversible?
questions.solution:
Sterilization is an irreversible method of contraception, typically involving surgical procedures such as tubal ligation in women or vasectomy in men. These procedures are designed to permanently prevent pregnancy.


Other options:

  1. Injectable contraception: Reversible method, involves hormone injections for temporary contraception.
  2. Implants: Reversible method, hormonal implants are placed under the skin and can be removed.
  3. IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device): Reversible method, it can be inserted and removed by a healthcare provider.


Reference: William's Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 114-118.

choices.text: 14 year old with tanner stage 1 breast
13 year old with tanner stage 5 breast
12 year old with tanner stage 4 breast
11 year old with tanner stage 1 breast

questions.text: A girl presented with amenorrhea, which of the following will be classified as primary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Primary amenorrhea—
  • No menarche by 15 yrs of age in presence of secondary sexual characters (breast budding present)
                                                [OR]
  • No menarche by 13 yrs of age in absence of secondary sexual characters.
 
  • M/C/C—Gonadal dysgenesis
  • M/C type of Gonadal dysgenesis—Turner's syndrome
  • 2nd M/C/C—Mullerian agenesis.



Reference: William's Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 321, 322.

questions.text: A young female presents to the gynecology OPD with complaints of pain on standing and walking. She has a  history of multiple sexual partners. Visual inspection findings are shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classical history of the patient presenting with such severe pain and swelling that patients often find it difficult or impossible to walk, sit, or have sexual intercourse, with the typical vulvar lesion : Bartholin abscess.
Blockage of the Bartholin ducts is a common etiology of a vulvar mass.


Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 103.

questions.text: A 15 year-old patient came to the OPD with her mother with a complaint of primary amenorrhea. On physical examination her height is 155 cm, the breasts are not developed and there is no pubic or axillary hair. On TVS, the uterus, FT and ovaries are not seen. Inguinal region swellings are noted. What is the most probable diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggesting that our patient is suffering from a disorder of sexual development (DSD).
Critical findings include :
  1. Normal height (rule out Turner)
  2. Amennorhea
  3. The absence of ovaries (female gonads) with the presence of bilateral inguinal region swellings, which likely indicate cryptorchid (undescended) testis.
  • The absence of Mullerian duct structures including fallopian tube and ovary indicate that anti-Mullerian hormone is functional in this patient.
  • However, the expectation of menses and amenorrhea in this female, indicate that the patient has female external genitalia and phenotype, likely due to defect in androgen synthesis or activity.
  • Another key point is the absence of the development of breast (Tanner Stage I) which was expected as per the age and female phenotype of the patient.
  • Thelarche is dependent on estrogen, rather than androgens.
This indicates that there isn’t enough androgen production for aromatization to take place, indicating that testosterone production is deficient in this patient.
Those having no significant testosterone production appear female at birth and present at puberty with primary amenorrhea and sexual infantilism, lacking both pubic hair development (due to the lack of testosterone) and breast development (due to the absence of aromatizable substrate); the serum LH concentration is elevated (hypergonadotropic) and testosterone levels are abnormally low (hypogonadism).
  • Complete androgen insensitivity (XY DSD) patients usually are well-feminized due to excess androgen levels which are converted to estrogen by the process of aromatization. Thus, while pubic/ axillary hair are scanty due to androgen insensitivity, estrogen ensures development of breasts in such patients. (option B)
Mullerian agenesis patients generally have well-developed gonads, since ovaries are derivatives of the genital ridge and not affected in this XX DSD. (option C)

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 375.

choices.text: Take DMPA and no back up needed

questions.text: 32y old female on Depot Medroxy Progesterone Acetate (DMPA) come to your OPD 2 weeks past her due date for next DMPA. What would you advise her?
questions.solution:
DMPA is an injectable Progesterone formulation to be taken every three months. DMPA can be given upto 4 weeks after due date with no back up needed but if patient presents after 4 weeks advise UPT before starting DMPA. It is launched by Govt of India under the name ANTARA.

Reference: Schickler R, Crabtree-Sokol D, Patel J, Bender N, Nelson AL, Nguyen BT. The potential for intramuscular depot medroxyprogesterone acetate as a self-bridging emergency contraceptive. Contracept X. 2020 Dec 3;3:100050. doi: 10.1016/j.conx.2020.100050. PMID: 33367229; PMCID: PMC7749364.

questions.text: The recombinant form of Vaccine to prevent Cervical Cancer has which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The Recombinant HPV vaccine consists of HPV L1 major Capsid protein.
The L1 protein self assembles to Virus like particles when expressed into Eukaryotic cells.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No: 466.

questions.text: The contraceptive shown in the image below contains which of the following?
questions.solution:
The contraceptive device depicted in the image is the "Today" sponge, which contains nonoxynol-9. Here are the key details:

• Design: It is a mushroom-shaped polyurethane sponge, measuring 2 inches in diameter and 1.25 inches thick, and it contains 1 gram of nonoxynol-9.
• Usage: The sponge features a loop for easy removal and should be placed high in the vagina with the concave side covering the cervix.
• Effectiveness: It can remain effective for up to 24 hours and is intended for single use. The sponge acts as a mechanical barrier to prevent sperm from entering the cervical canal, absorbs semen, and contains a spermicidal agent.
• Failure Rate: The failure rate is approximately 9 to 16 per 100 woman-years.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with urinary leakage on coughing and sneezing, which is characteristic of stress urinary incontinence (SUI).

Key points:

  • Cause: Weakness of the pelvic floor muscles or urethral sphincter deficiency, often associated with:

    • Multiparity

    • Pelvic organ prolapse (as in this patient)

  • Other types of incontinence:

    • Urge incontinence: Sudden, intense urge to urinate, often due to detrusor overactivity

    • Overflow incontinence: Continuous dribbling due to bladder outlet obstruction or underactive detrusor

    • Neurogenic bladder: Due to spinal cord or neurological lesions; may show features of both urgency and retention

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram:
questions.solution:
The image of the hysterosalpingogram shows bilateral hydrosalpinx.

Hydrosalpinx refers to the distension of the fallopian tubes caused by the accumulation of fluid within the lumen, often following acute salpingitis. It is typically bilateral and results in the fallopian tubes becoming retort-shaped due to dilatation of the ampulla, which is filled with clear fluid. While the interstitial end of the tube remains open, the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. Hydrosalpinges can grow as large as 15 cm, allowing the contrast dye to enter the tube during hysterosalpingography, but preventing its exit due to the blockage at the fimbrial end.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the provided options, ovarian follicular cysts are the least likely cause of post-menopausal bleeding.
Post-menopausal bleeding is defined as vaginal bleeding occurring after six months of amenorrhea in women over 40 years of age, which marks the menopausal transition. Formation/Presence of ovarian follicular cysts in post menopausal women is highly unlikely.

Common cause of PMB include
  • Vaginal or endometrial atrophy - Most common
  • Urogenital infections 
  • Medications (eg, estrogen, tamoxifen, and anticoagulants)
  • Uterine leiomyomas
  • Genital tract malignancies
  • Vaginal foreign bodies
  • Endometrial polyps
  • Endometrial hyperplasia with or without atypia.

questions.text: A woman is suspected to have endometriosis. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus.

  • Investigation of choice: Laparoscopy

    • Allows direct visualization of endometrial implants.

    • Enables biopsy for histopathological confirmation, which is the gold standard. 

Other options — brief:

  1. CT scan: Poor sensitivity for detecting endometriotic lesions; not routinely used.

  2. MRI: Can detect deep infiltrating endometriosis and ovarian endometriomas but cannot replace laparoscopy for diagnosis.

  3. Ultrasound: Useful mainly for endometriomas, but cannot reliably detect peritoneal implants.

Key point:

Laparoscopy is both diagnostic and potentially therapeutic for endometriosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with acute onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a low-grade fever, with a pulse rate of 90 bpm and blood pressure of 126/84 mm Hg. She has regular menstrual cycles of 28 days. Pelvic examination shows a tender right adnexal mass. Ovarian torsion is suspected. What is the investigation of choice in this condition? Urine pregnancy testing-negative Serum B-HCG level-1 mIU/L
questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute onset lower abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a tender adnexal mass, which strongly suggests ovarian torsion.

  • Investigation of choice: Doppler Ultrasound of the pelvis

    • It evaluates blood flow to the ovary.

    • Absence or reduction of arterial and venous flow supports the diagnosis.

    • Can also assess ovarian size, edema, and presence of masses. 

Other options — brief:

  1. X-ray erect abdomen: Not useful for ovarian torsion; mainly used for bowel obstruction or free air.

  2. MRI abdomen: Can detect torsion but not first-line due to availability, cost, and time.

  3. CT abdomen: May incidentally show torsion but less sensitive and involves radiation.

Key point:

Doppler ultrasound is the first-line investigation for suspected ovarian torsion.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with a history of unprotected sex 95 hours ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
he patient had unprotected intercourse 95 hours ago (≈4 days). The choice of emergency contraception depends on time elapsed:

  • Levonorgestrel pills: Most effective within 72 hours (3 days). After 72 hours, efficacy decreases significantly.

  • Mifepristone: Can be used within 120 hours, but not widely available everywhere.

  • Oral contraceptive pills (combined OCPs): Typically used within 72 hours; efficacy beyond that is limited.

  • IUCD (Copper T): Can be inserted up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse and is the most effective emergency contraception.

Key point:

For unprotected sex 95 hours ago, copper IUCD is the preferred and most effective emergency contraceptive.

questions.text: The hormone acting on post ovulatory endometrium is:
questions.solution:
After ovulation, the corpus luteum secretes progesterone, which acts on the post-ovulatory (secretory) endometrium to prepare it for potential implantation.

Key points:

  • Follicular phase:

    • Dominated by estrogen, which causes proliferation of the endometrium.

  • Luteal (post-ovulatory) phase:

    • Progesterone transforms the endometrium from proliferative to secretory, making it suitable for embryo implantation.

    • Endometrial glands become coiled, and stroma becomes edematous.

  • Other hormones:

    • LH & FSH: Trigger ovulation and follicular maturation but do not act directly on endometrium.

    • Estrogen: Primarily acts during the proliferative phase.

questions.text: Which of the following is a weak estrogen derivative?
questions.solution:
• Estriol is a weak estrogen derivative.
  • There are three estrogens that are present in significant quantities in humans—beta- estradiol, estrone, and estriol.
  • Beta estradiol is secreted by ovaries. It is 80 times more potent than Estriol.
  • Estriol is an oxidative product derived from both estradiol and estrone, the conversion occurs mainly in the liver.
  • Estrone is formed in peripheral tissues from androgens secreted by the adrenal cortices and by ovarian thecal cells.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page No 364.

questions.text: A 17 year old female presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination she normal secondary sexual characteristics, breast development corresponding to tanner stage IV. Endocrine evaluation revealed normal levels of FSH, LH. And she had a 46XX karyotype. What could be the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
• The given patient shows features suggestive of mullerian agenesis.
  • It is the congenial absence of both the uterus and vagina termed as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome. Clinical features include. :
  1. Shallow vaginal pouch (1 to 2 inches deep).
  2. Uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina are absent.
  3. These patients have normal ovaries persist, as they originate from the genital ridge.
  4. Normal secondary sexual characters. -46XX karyotype.
  5. Other features: kidney abnormalities- horseshoe kidney, skeletal abnormalities
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain. On evaluation it was found that she hasn't attained menarche . On local examination a tense bluish mass was seen per vagina. What could be the possible diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Features of primary amenorrhea in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics, cyclical abdominal pain, acute retention of urine along with a tense bluish bulge is suggestive of an imperforate hymen.
  • Imperforate hymen is a type of Mullerian defect, of urogenital origin.
Reference: Shaws Textbook of Gynaecology ,18th Edition, Page No 67-69.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia?
questions.solution:
Puberty menorrhagia is most commonly caused by anovulatory cycles.

Anovulatory cycles lead to:
- Unopposed estrogen stimulation
- Endometrial hyperplasia
- Prolonged and heavy menstrual bleeding

Other potential causes include:

1. Endocrine dysfunction:
- Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
- Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism

2. Hematological disorders:
- Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
- Von Willebrand‘s disease
- Leukemia

3. Pelvic tumors:
- Uterine fibroids
- Sarcoma botryoides
- Estrogen-producing ovarian tumors

4. Pregnancy complications:
- Miscarriage (abortion)

Treatment:

1. Initial management:
- Reassurance and psychological support
- Rest and correction of anemia

2. Pharmacological treatment:
- In refractory cases, progestogens such as medroxyprogesterone acetate or norethisterone (5 mg, three times daily) are administered until the bleeding stops. Typically, bleeding is controlled within 3–7 days, and the medication is continued for 21 days. Normal cycles usually resume after 2–3 courses of treatment.

3. Emergency management:
- In cases of severe bleeding, conjugated equine estrogen (20–40 mg IV) can be given every 6–8 hours. Once bleeding is controlled, combined oral contraceptive pills are introduced.

Outcome:
Regular menstrual cycles are expected to establish once the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis matures.

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynaecology, 7th edition, Page no 43,44 .

questions.text: SRY region is located in:
Choose the incorrectly matched option.
questions.solution:
The incorrectly matched term is "Cystocelecolposuspension." The appropriate surgery for cystocele is anterior colporrhaphy.

### Surgeries for Uterovaginal Prolapse:

1. Anterior Colporrhaphy:
- Performed for cystocele or cystourethrocele.

2. Posterior Colporrhaphy/Colpoperineorrhaphy:
- Done for posterior defects such as rectocele or rectal defects with perineal laxity.

3. Le Forte's Repair:
- Preferred in elderly women with advanced prolapse or those unfit for major surgery.
- Not suitable for women wanting an active sexual life as it creates an adhesive area in the vaginal midline.

4. Abdominal Sling Surgeries:
- Ideal for young women who wish to retain menstrual and reproductive functions.
- These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. Examples include:
1. Abdominal Wall Cervicopexy (Modified by Purandare and Mathre): The sling is attached posteriorly to the cervix near the uterosacral ligaments.
2. Shirodkar's Sling Surgery: The sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
3. Khanna's Sling Surgery: The sling is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament.

5. Fothergill Surgery (Manchester Operation):
- Combines anterior colporrhaphy with cervical amputation. The Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in front of the cervix, followed by a colpoperineorrhaphy.
- Suitable for women under 40 who wish to retain reproductive function, though fertility may be reduced.

6. Ward-Mayo Surgery:
- A combination of vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair.
- Performed in women over 40 who do not wish to preserve reproductive function.

7. Moschowitz Surgery:
- Used for enterocele repair by obliterating the pouch of Douglas.

### Management of Vault Prolapse:

- For patients fit for abdominal surgery:
- Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, which suspends the vault to the sacral promontory extraperitoneally. This is ideal for younger women as it avoids coital difficulty, which may occur after vaginal surgeries.

- For patients unfit for abdominal surgery:
- Transvaginal sacrospinous colpopexy, usually performed in obese or elderly women who cannot undergo abdominal surgery.

- Colpocleisis:
- Can be performed if sexual activity is not desired.

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynaecology, 7th edition, Page no 217 .

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association with HRT?
questions.solution:
### Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) and Colon Cancer Risk

HRT has been found to reduce the risk of colon cancer.

### Indications for Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT):

1. **Therapeutic Uses:**
- Symptomatic women experiencing estrogen deficiency
- Adolescents with gonadal dysgenesis

2. **Preventive Uses:**
- High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as:
- Cardiovascular disease
- Osteoporosis
- Stroke
- Alzheimer‘s disease
- Colonic cancer
- Premature menopause, whether spontaneous or following surgery
- Menopause resulting from radiotherapy or chemotherapy, especially with alkylating agents
- Women requesting HRT for prevention of menopausal complications

### Contraindications for Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT):

- Unexplained abnormal genital bleeding
- Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
- Known or suspected estrogen-dependent tumors
- Active or previous venous blood clots
- Active or recent (within the last year) arterial blood clots
- Liver dysfunction or gallbladder disease
- Known hypersensitivity to estrogen preparations
- Known or suspected pregnancy
- Uterine fibroids, as HRT may cause the fibroids to enlarge

### Uses of Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT):

1. **Short-term Uses:**
- Management of hot flashes and vasomotor symptoms
- Relief from dyspareunia (painful intercourse) and low libido
- Treatment of urethral syndrome

2. **Long-term Uses:**
- Prevention and treatment of osteoporosis
- Reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 91-96 .

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not given in endometrosis?
questions.solution:
Estradiol is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as estrogen administration leads to further development of endometriotic lesions.
### Medical Management of Endometriosis

*For Minimal Disease:
- NSAIDs: First-line treatment for pain relief.
- Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs): Used if menstrual complaints are present. They inhibit gonadotropin release and reduce menstrual flow.

*For Moderate to Severe Disease:
- Oral Progestogens: Initiate treatment to counteract estrogenic effects on the endometrium, leading to endometrial atrophy.
- GnRH Agonists: The preferred choice for managing severe symptoms.

*Additional Treatment Options:
-Cabergoline: A vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) pathway inhibitor, effective for chronic pain related to endometriosis.

*Mnemonic for Drug Classes Used in Endometriosis Management: GOLD GAP**

- **G**: GnRH Analog (e.g., Leuprolide)
- **O**: Oral Contraceptive Pills
- **L**: Letrozole
- **D**: Danazol
- **G**: Gestrinone
- **A**: Antiprogesterone (e.g., Mifepristone)
- **P**: Progesterone (e.g., Medroxyprogesterone Acetate)

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 180-184 .

questions.text: A 38-year-old multi gravida presents with 2 years of infertility and dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of Douglas. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea, along with a retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of Douglas. These symptoms are suggestive of endometriosis. While laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis, it is not typically used for initial diagnosis; a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is often the next best step.

Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue in ectopic locations, including:

- Ovaries (which may present as chocolate cysts and cause left or right lower quadrant pain)
- Pouch of Douglas (pain during defecation)
- Uterosacral ligaments (chronic pelvic pain and infertility)
- Appendix (right lower quadrant pain)
- Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar
- Umbilicus
- Lungs (cyclical hemoptysis)

These extra-uterine sites are affected by hormonal changes, leading to symptoms specific to their location.

Investigations for endometriosis include:

- Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS), which may reveal a chocolate cyst
- MRI
- Serum CA-125 level, which may be elevated (greater than 35 U/mL)
- Laparoscopy, which is both diagnostic and therapeutic, allowing for the identification of endometriosis sites, biopsy, and surgical removal of deposits.

Treatment options for symptom control include:

- Oral contraceptive pills
- Mirena intrauterine device (IUD)
- GnRHanalogs
- Letrozole

Surgical management may involve:

- Minimally invasive techniques such as cautery, laser vaporization, and adhesion lysis
- Major procedures such as incision and removal of chocolate cysts, salpingooophorectomy, hysterectomy, and unilateral or bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 174-182 .

choices.text: Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period
Pain begins after a few hours after the onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours
GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment

questions.text: Which of the following statements about primary dysmenorrhea is true?
questions.solution:
Primary dysmenorrhea, characterized by cramping pain during menstruation, it may be affected by  psychological factors such as low social support, alexithymia, neuroticism and also by prolonged menstrual bleeding, a family history of dysmenorrhea, and a high caffeine diet.

*Classification:

1. Etiological:
- Primary dysmenorrhea occurs in women aged 18 to 25 with ovulatory cycles and begins just before or with the onset of menstruation, but not a few hours after. It is not associated with any pelvic pathology.
- Secondary dysmenorrhea is associated with pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and endometriosis.

2. Clinical:
- Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most common type, characterized by cramping pain primarily on the first and second days of menstruation.
- Congestive dysmenorrhea presents as worsening pelvic discomfort and pain a few days before menstruation, with relief of symptoms after menstruation. It is seen in conditions like PID, intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) use, pelvic vein varicosities, endometriosis, and fibroids.
- Membranous dysmenorrhea is rare and involves crampy pain with the passage of the endometrium as a cast during menstruation.

Management:
- Primary dysmenorrhea is managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), combined oral contraceptive pills, progestin-only pills, GnRH agonists, and androgens. Surgical options like hysterectomy are considered if medical management fails.
- Secondary dysmenorrhea treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause.

Other options - 

Pain starts with menstruation and can be there for 48 hours

NSAIDs are first line management 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition, Page no 471 .

questions.text: Fructose is absent in the seminal fluid, which of the following statements is true regarding this:
questions.solution:
Fructose is absent in seminal fluid in case of congenital absence of seminal vesicle and obstruction of the ejaculatory duct.

The ejaculatory duct is formed by the fusion of the ductus deferens and the duct of the seminal vesicle. A major portion of the semen volume is contributed by the seminal vesicles. Seminal fluid is alkaline and protects sperm from acidity in prostatic secretions and in the vagina. Seminal fluid also provides fructose as an energy source for sperm. If seminal vesicle is absent or if there is an obstruction at the level of the ejaculatory duct then semen analysis will reveal low ejaculate volume, oligospermia or azoospermia, low pH, and absence of fructose

 

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th edition, Page no 443 .

questions.text: What is the cause of LH surge? FSH: Follicle-stimulating Hormone LH: Luteinizing hormone
questions.solution:
Estradiol plays a crucial role in the menstrual cycle by causing the LH surge. For this surge to occur, estradiol concentrations need to reach 200 pg/ml for at least 50 hours.

Phases of the Menstrual Cycle:
1. Follicular Phase (Days 0-14)
The cycle begins with higher FSH levels, promoting the recruitment of a cohort of follicles, with one follicle destined for ovulation.
The primordial follicle matures into a Graafian follicle, while adjacent follicles undergo atresia.
LH receptors are upregulated in both the theca and granulosa cells.
As the phase progresses, follicles produce increased amounts of estrogen and inhibin.
The rising estradiol levels stimulate the proliferation of the endometrium and exert negative feedback on the anterior pituitary to suppress FSH release.

2. Ovulation (Day 14)
Towards the end of the follicular phase, a surge in estradiol levels leads to positive feedback, triggering the LH surge.
There is a small rise in progesterone levels, which also contributes to the FSH surge that accompanies the LH surge.
Ovulation occurs as a direct result of this estrogen-induced LH surge.

3. Luteal Phase (Days 14-28)
Ovulation is confirmed if progesterone levels exceed 3 ng/mL on cycle day 21, indicating the formation of the corpus luteum.
The corpus luteum secretes both estrogen and progesterone, leading to increased vascularity and secretory activity in the endometrium to prepare for potential implantation of a fertilized egg.
If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses towards the end of the luteal phase, resulting in a sharp decline in estradiol and progesterone levels.

4. Menses (Days 0-4)
The withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone leads to the shedding of the endometrium, resulting in menstrual bleeding.
This cyclical process is essential for fertility and the regulation of the reproductive system.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is done with the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Pipelle aspirator (a) and Vabra aspirator (b) are instruments used for obtaining endometrial samples.



Endometrial Sampling:
The Pipelle aspirator is commonly used for aspiration of the uterine cavity, with the obtained sample sent for histopathological examination.
It is particularly useful for screening postmenopausal women on hormone replacement therapy (HRT) or tamoxifen, as these treatments can increase the risk of endometrial changes.
Postmenopausal Bleeding:
Postmenopausal bleeding is defined as bleeding from the genital tract that occurs more than 12 months after the last menstrual period in a woman not on HRT.
All cases of postmenopausal bleeding must be investigated for endometrial malignancy, as advancing age is a significant risk factor.
Diagnostic Approach:
The first-line investigation for postmenopausal bleeding is transvaginal ultrasound (TVS).

Endometrial sampling is indicated in the following situations:
1. Endometrial thickness >4 mm on TVS.
2. Diffuse or focal increased echogenicity (heterogeneity) of the endometrium.
3. Inadequate visualization of the endometrium on TVS.
4. Persistent bleeding, even when endometrial thickness is less than 4 mm, as it may still indicate endometrial cancer.

questions.text: How long should a couple use contraception post-vasectomy?
questions.solution:
The couple should use contraceptive methods for 12 to 16 weeks, or about 3 months, following the male partner's vasectomy.

Vasectomy is a permanent sterilization procedure performed on males, involving the resection and ligation of a segment of the vas deferens bilaterally.

This procedure is typically done under local anesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum to access the vas deferens, which are then divided on both sides, blocking the passage of sperm. The no-scalpel technique has become more common, involving a single incision made with special forceps, eliminating the need for a skin stitch. Clips or plugs can also be placed over the vas deferens instead of cutting it. The failure rate for vasectomy is approximately 0.15%.

Overall, it is a relatively straightforward procedure with a low risk of complications. However, a patient who has undergone a vasectomy is not immediately sterile after the procedure, as sperm may still be present in the distal segments of the vas deferens for some time.

Therefore, it is estimated that at least 20 ejaculations or a period of 3 months is necessary to clear the stored sperm.

questions.text: Ovarian drilling is done in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is a surgical procedure used for the management of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).



PCOS is an endocrine disorder commonly found in women of reproductive age and can affect multiple body systems. The Rotterdam criteria are utilized for diagnosing PCOS, requiring the presence of any two of the following three components for a definitive diagnosis:

Clinical or biochemical hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism, acne)
Menstrual abnormalities, such as oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, anovulation, and infertility
Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound examination
Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include the presence of more than 20 follicles and/or an increased ovarian volume greater than 10 mL, or both.

Management of PCOS:
Weight reduction and lifestyle changes (such as smoking cessation) are recommended.
Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly prescribed to address menstrual irregularities, as well as to reduce acne and hirsutism.
Anti-androgens are effective for treating hirsutism, with OCPs containing cyproterone acetate often prescribed for patients experiencing hirsutism.
Many patients with PCOS are prone to insulin resistance, which can be managed with metformin. Acarbose may be used if metformin is not tolerated.
For patients presenting with infertility, clomiphene citrate is typically the first-line treatment for inducing ovulation, often in combination with dexamethasone and letrozole.
Laparoscopic Ovarian Drilling:
This procedure involves puncturing the ovarian capsule using either laser or unipolar electrocautery. The primary goal is to reduce the volume of androgen-producing ovarian tissue.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulligravid patient came to the clinic complaining of irregular bleeding for the past month. What would be the investigation of choice
questions.solution:
The first investigation to be done in a case of abnormal uterine bleeding
(AUB) in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is urine -hCG estimation or urine pregnancy test. This is done to rule out pregnancy. Pregnancy complications such as miscarriage, ectopic pregnancies, and molar pregnancies may present with AUB, hence, these need to be ruled out by urine β-hCG levels. This is done for all women in the reproductive age group. Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition • Page no: 139

questions.text: What is the management of choice in a nulligravida presenting with uterine prolapse, no cystocele or rectocele.
questions.solution:
Young women who have not completed their family are ideal candidates for abdominal sling surgery. These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. These include:
• Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre): sling attached to cervix posteriorly near uterosacral ligaments.
• Shirodkar's sling surgery: the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
• Khanna's sling surgery: - sling fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament.
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 16th Edition • Page no: 360

questions.text: 42-year-old lady comes with complaints of abdominal cramping and breast pain that is cyclical and occurs once a month. It is associated with headaches and difficulty concentrating at work. She notices that the pain begins a week before menstruation and resolves after menses. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of premenstrual syndrome.
Premenstrual syndrome (premenstrual tension) is a functional disorder and is recognized by cyclical changes that are associated with ovulatory cycles. It is usually seen in middle-aged women and occurs 1-2 weeks before menstruation and resolves after menses.
The classical symptoms include abdominal cramps, increasing breast tenderness, abdominal bloating, headache, sleeplessness, fatigue, difficulty in concentrating, and mood swings. The diagnosis is made on the basis of a carefully elicited history. Asking patients to document their symptoms in the form of a menstrual diary can also aid in diagnosis.
Treatment includes counseling and therapy for psychological symptoms, limiting salt intake, and symptomatic treatment of breast tenderness and pelvic pain. Vitamins B1, B6, and E may be used. Ref -Williams Gynecology 3rd edition page 262

questions.text: What is the location of Bartholin cyst?
questions.solution:
Bartholin cyst if located in the posterior one third of Vulva.The Bartholin glands are known as the greater vestibular glands in females. These glands are located in the posterior part of the vestibule and open through a duct into the vaginal orifice at approximately 5 and 7 o'clock positions. They secrete mucus during sexual arousal for lubrication.
They are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.
Bartholin cyst is caused by obstruction of the duct due to infection, trauma, mucus changes, and congenitally narrowed ducts. If the cyst gets infected, it leads to the formation of a Bartholin abscess. Escherichia coli is the most common causative agent. Ref -Shaws gynaecology 16th edition page 372

questions.text: Following MTP with dilation and curettage a 26 year old female presented with cyclical dysmenorrhea but no menstrual flow around the same time of her anticipated periods. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for the procedure
questions.solution: The given patient is suffering from asherman syndrome which refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries. Patients with Asherman syndrome may have light or absent menstrual periods (amenorrhea) with dysmenorrhea due to the endometrial build-up which occurs during the cycle. Hysteroscopy is used for the definitive diagnosis of Asherman syndrome which shows and irregular filling defect giving a moth eaten appearance. William's Gynaecology 3rd Edition • Page no: 372, 373, 381, 439

questions.text: Until when can a postpartum IUCD be inserted?
questions.solution: Postpartum IUCD should be inserted within 48 hours. IUCD acts by preventing implantation of the fertilised ovum by increasing contractility, tubal peristalsis and promotes leukocytic infiltration of endometrium making the fertilised egg unable to implant. Ref- Shaw's textbook of Gynaecology 16th editon Page 270,279

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD with spotting following IUD insertion. No history of pain or fever. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: SPotting is common side effect after IUD insertion and resolves spontaneosly. SInce there is no fever, abdominal pain the patient requires observation only. Complications of IUD- Pain, Bleeding, pelvic infection, uterine perforation, ectopic pregnancies. Ref- Parks textbook of PSM 27th edition- Page 572

questions.text: Which of the following pill would you prescribe a young woman who comes requesting for a post coital pill?
questions.solution: Levonorgestrel 1.5mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse can be used for emergency contraception. It can also be administered in two doses 0.75mg taken 12 hours apart. The tablet can be offered upto 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the longer coital- drug interval. Dutta's textbook of obstetrics page 503.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic criteria used to diagnose Bacterial Vaginosis?
questions.solution:
The Amsel Criteria are a set of clinical guidelines used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis , a common vaginal infection. Diagnosis requires the presence of at least three of the four following criteria:

Thin, homogenous vaginal discharge (often gray or white).
Elevated vaginal pH (greater than 4.5).
Positive "whiff" test (a fishy odor when potassium hydroxide is added to vaginal discharge).
Clue cells visible on microscopic examination (vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria. Ref- Shaws textbook of Gynaecology Page 385

questions.text: A male was referred to the urology OPD for evaluation of infertility. Karyotyping analysis revealed an XXY karyotype. Which of the following statements is not true about the condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has an XXY karyotype, which is characteristic of Klinefelter syndrome, a common cause of male infertility.

Key features:

  • Azoospermia or severe oligospermia: Testicular failure leads to absent or extremely low sperm production.

  • Testes size is reduced: Small, firm testes due to seminiferous tubule fibrosis.

  • Plasma estradiol levels are elevated: Relative increase due to peripheral conversion of testosterone to estradiol in adipose tissue.

  • FSH and LH levels are elevated, not reduced: Because of primary testicular failure, there is loss of negative feedback, leading to hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Reduced FSH is inconsistent with Klinefelter syndrome; elevated FSH is a hallmark.


Reference: Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 165

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hyper-estrogenic condition?
questions.solution:
Hyperestrogenism refers to conditions in which estrogen levels are relatively high compared to normal physiological levels.

  • Ovarian cancer: Certain estrogen-secreting ovarian tumors (like granulosa cell tumors) cause hyperestrogenism.

  • Endometriosis: Estrogen-dependent condition; local and systemic estrogen levels may be elevated.

  • Tamoxifen usage: Tamoxifen acts as a selective estrogen receptor modulator; in certain tissues (e.g., endometrium) it has estrogenic effects, leading to hyperestrogenic manifestations.

  • Low BMI: Associated with lower peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens in adipose tissue, leading to hypoestrogenism, not hyperestrogenism.

Key point: Peripheral adipose tissue contributes significantly to estrogen levels via aromatization; low body fat reduces estrogen production.



Reference:Shaws textbook of Gynaecology 17th edition page no 180-184

questions.text: Which of the following can not be used for emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Emergency contraception (EC) is intended to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. Only approved EC methods are recommended.

  • Levonorgestrel (LNG):

    • 0.75 mg single dose within 72 hours OR

    • 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours — both are effective.

  • Ulipristal acetate (UPA):

    • 30 mg single dose up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse.

  • Centchroman (Ormeloxifene):

    • A selective estrogen receptor modulator used as a weekly contraceptive.

    • Not recommended for emergency contraception.

    • Typical EC regimens are single dose of 30 mg or 60 mg, but not as a “twice in 24 hours” regimen.



Reference:Shaws textbook of gynaecology 17th edition Page no 270

questions.text: A male patient presented for the evaluation of infertility. He has been having recurrent hospitalizations for infections, since 2 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes:

  • Male infertility

  • Recurrent respiratory infections since early childhood

These features are characteristic of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD), also known as immotile cilia syndrome.

Key points:

  • Infertility: Male infertility occurs due to immotile sperm flagella, which share the same microtubular structure as cilia.

  • Recurrent infections: Impaired mucociliary clearance leads to chronic sinusitis, otitis media, bronchiectasis, and other respiratory infections.

  • Onset: Usually from early childhood.

  • Other features: May have situs inversus (Kartagener syndrome) in ~50% of cases.

Differential diagnoses:

  • Cystic fibrosis: Also causes infertility (azoospermia due to absence of vas deferens) and recurrent infections, but more commonly presents with pancreatic insufficiency, salty skin, and thick respiratory secretions.

  • Celiac disease: Malabsorption and gastrointestinal symptoms; infertility can occur but recurrent infections are not a hallmark.

  • COPD: Usually adult onset, often related to smoking; not congenital.


Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 2298

questions.text: A woman requests for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). The doctor decides to perform a suction evacuation. Till when can this be performed?
questions.solution:
Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) by Suction Evacuation:

  1. Definition:
    Suction evacuation (also called vacuum aspiration) is a surgical method used to terminate a pregnancy by aspirating the uterine contents using a suction device.

  2. Gestational Age Limit:

    • The maximum recommended gestational age for suction evacuation is 12 weeks.

    • Before 12 weeks, the procedure is safe, effective, and associated with minimal complications.

    • After 12 weeks, the fetal and placental size increases, making suction alone inadequate.

  3. Alternative Methods Beyond 12 Weeks:

    • 12–18 weeks: Dilatation and evacuation (D&E) is preferred.

    • >18–20 weeks: Medical abortion using mifepristone and misoprostol, or surgical methods under expert supervision.

    • Up to 24 weeks: In special circumstances, with legal and medical approval, termination may be performed (MTP Act provisions).

  4. Advantages of Suction Evacuation:

    • Minimal anesthesia required.

    • Low risk of uterine perforation compared to sharp curettage.

    • Quick recovery.

  5. Why 12 Weeks Is the Cutoff:

    • After 12 weeks, the uterus is larger, and tissue is more vascular, increasing the risk of hemorrhage.

    • Instrumentation may not reach all parts of the uterus effectively.

    • There is higher chance of incomplete evacuation, requiring additional procedures.



Reference: DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page no 203-206

questions.text: A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. What is the appropriate dosage of Misoprostol administered by the mucosal route?
questions.solution:
At 8 weeks of gestation (i.e., ≤ 63 days), medical abortion is an established and safe method. It typically involves two drugs:

  • Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed 24–48 hours later by

  • Misoprostol 800 mcg, commonly administered via:

    • Vaginal

    • Buccal

    • Sublingual mucosal routes

For mucosal routes (buccal/sublingual/vaginal), 800 mcg of Misoprostol is the recommended and effective dose.

Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • 200 mcg or 400 mcg: Subtherapeutic doses for early pregnancy termination

  • 600 mcg: Used for postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) prevention, not abortion

    FDA & WHO Recommended Misoprostol Dosage Table (Various Clinical Uses)

Indication Misoprostol Dose Route Notes
Medical Abortion (≤ 12 weeks) 800 mcg Vaginal / Buccal / Sublingual 24–48 hrs after 200 mg Mifepristone
Incomplete Abortion / Miscarriage (≤ 13 wks) 600–800 mcg Oral / Sublingual / Vaginal Single dose; repeat after 3 hours if needed
Cervical Ripening for Surgical Abortion 400 mcg Vaginal or Sublingual 3 hours before procedure
Induction of Labor (Term) 25 mcg every 4–6 hrs Vaginal Higher doses increase risk of uterine hyperstimulation
Induction of Abortion (2nd Trimester) 400 mcg every 3 hrs Vaginal / Sublingual Until expulsion
Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH) – Treatment 800–1000 mcg Sublingual / Rectal Used when oxytocin is not available
PPH – Prevention (after delivery) 600 mcg Oral Used when oxytocin is not available

  • For MTP at 8 weeks, Misoprostol 800 mcg mucosally is the correct dose.

  • Mifepristone should be administered before Misoprostol for better efficacy.

  • Route flexibility (buccal, vaginal, sublingual) depends on clinical setting and patient preference.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics 25th edition page no 360,362

choices.text: Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine

questions.text: A patient presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months. On examination, you notice a grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer over the prolapse. Which of the following is a cause for this decubitus ulcer and treatment?
questions.solution:
A decubitus ulcer in the context of uterovaginal prolapse is a pressure ulcer that forms due to chronic venous congestion and friction from the exposed, prolapsed vaginal and uterine tissue.

Pathophysiology:

  • In grade 3 prolapse, the cervix and part of the uterus lie outside the introitus continuously, leading to:

    • Impaired venous and lymphatic drainage

    • Dryness and exposure to air

    • Trauma from walking or clothing

    • Resulting in ulceration and inflammation (decubitus ulcer)

      Management:

  • The ulcer is not primarily due to infection or malignancy, but due to venous congestion.

  • Primary treatment involves:

    • Reducing the prolapsed organ back into the vagina

    • Daily dressing with glycerine and acriflavine to promote healing

    • Once the ulcer heals, definitive surgical management (e.g., vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair) can be planned

      Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • Option 1 (Infection and antibiotics): While secondary infection may occur, infection is not the primary cause of the ulcer.

  • Option 3 (Trauma and dressing): Trauma contributes, but the root cause is venous congestion; simple dressing is inadequate.

  • Option 4 (Malignancy and excision): Decubitus ulcers are non-malignant. Biopsy is done only if malignancy is suspected, which is not routine in typical prolapse cases.


Reference:Shaws textbook of Gynaecology 17th edition page no 291

questions.text: Marsupialization is an ideal treatment of choice for condition X involving the female reproductive tract, the lesion responsible for condition X is located at?
questions.solution:
Marsupialization is the treatment of choice for a Bartholin cyst or abscess, particularly when recurrent or symptomatic. The clinical scenario strongly suggests involvement of the Bartholin gland, a common site for cyst formation in women of reproductive age.

Pathogenesis of Bartholin Cyst and Abscess

  1. Bartholin Cyst:

    • Results from ductal obstruction, often due to inflammation or thickened mucus.

    • The gland continues to secrete mucus, which accumulates behind the obstruction, forming a non-infected cyst.

    • Often painless unless secondarily infected.

  2. Bartholin Abscess:

    • Arises when a cyst becomes secondarily infected, leading to pus accumulation.

    • Characteristically painful, red, warm, and may cause difficulty in walking or sitting.

    • Marsupialization or incision and drainage (I&D) is required for symptomatic relief and prevention of recurrence.

      Microbiology

Clinical Features

  • Presents as a unilateral vulvar swelling, often tender and fluctuant.

  • Pain is usually exacerbated by walking, sitting, or intercourse (dyspareunia).

  • On examination:

    • A tender, erythematous swelling in the posterior vestibule.

    • Transillumination may be positive in simple cysts (clear fluid).

    • Vulval architecture may show a deviation, sometimes forming an S-shaped cleft.

      Management

  • Marsupialization is the procedure of choice:

    • A permanent drainage tract is created by suturing the cyst wall to the overlying skin.

    • This reduces the recurrence rate and is especially preferred in recurrent or symptomatic cases.

  • Incision and drainage may be performed in acutely infected cases (abscess), but recurrence rates are higher unless followed by marsupialization.

  • Word catheter placement is another minimally invasive option that allows continuous drainage for several weeks.



Reference:Williams gynaecology 3rd edition page no 820,971-

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/IIl uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 56-year-old multiparous woman presents with:

  • Grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele (i.e., pelvic organ prolapse),

  • Urinary leakage during coughing and sneezing, which are classic triggers of increased intra-abdominal pressure.

These are hallmark features of stress urinary incontinence (SUI).

Why this is Stress Incontinence:

  • Pathophysiology: Weakening of pelvic floor muscles and fascial support (often due to multiparity, aging, and menopause) leads to urethral hypermobility or intrinsic sphincter deficiency.

  • Symptoms: Involuntary leakage of urine with physical exertion, coughing, sneezing, or laughing.

  • Associated findings: Commonly coexists with pelvic organ prolapse, such as cystocele (anterior vaginal wall descent with bladder prolapse).

    Incorrect Options:

  • Urge incontinence: Sudden, strong urge to void with involuntary leakage, typically due to detrusor overactivity. Not associated with prolapse or stress triggers like coughing.

  • Overflow incontinence: Due to bladder outlet obstruction or underactive detrusor, leading to continuous dribbling and high post-void residual. Common in diabetics, spinal cord lesions—not typically in pelvic organ prolapse.

  • Neurogenic bladder: Due to neurological dysfunction (e.g., spinal cord injury, MS). Would present with voiding dysfunction, incomplete emptying, or retention, often without stress triggers.

    Bottom Line:

Stress incontinence is the most common type in women with pelvic organ prolapse, especially when associated with physical strain-related leakage, as seen in this case.


Reference: Williams gynaecology 3rd edition page no 514,523

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. The per vaginal examination is shown below and a bluish swelling is seen along with it. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is characteristic of an imperforate hymen, a congenital anomaly where the hymen completely obstructs the vaginal outflow tract. This leads to cryptomenorrhea—a condition where menstruation occurs internally, but blood cannot exit the body due to anatomical obstruction.
Clinical Clues:

  • Age: 14-year-old girl (around the time of expected menarche)

  • Symptoms:

    • Cyclical abdominal pain → suggests menstruation is occurring internally

    • Midline hypogastric lump → likely distended uterus/vagina (hematometra/hematocolpos)

    • Primary amenorrhea → no menstrual bleeding due to outflow obstruction

    • Bluish swelling at the vaginal introitus → classic for imperforate hymen



Key Terminology

Term Definition
Cryptomenorrhea Menstruation with outflow obstruction; blood accumulates internally.
Hematocolpos Collection of menstrual blood in the vagina.
Hematometra Collection of menstrual blood in the uterus.
Hematosalpinx Collection of menstrual blood in the fallopian tubes (advanced cases).

Cause Key Features
Imperforate Hymen Congenital; bluish bulging membrane at the introitus due to pooled blood (hematocolpos).
Transverse Vaginal Septum Horizontal septum in the vaginal canal; presents as a pinkish, concave obstruction.
 

  • Pelvic Ultrasound:

    • First-line imaging modality.

    • Reveals distended vagina and uterus filled with fluid (hematocolpos ± hematometra).

    • Helps differentiate between imperforate hymen and deeper vaginal anomalies.

      Management

Condition Treatment
Imperforate Hymen Cruciate incision and excision of hymenal tissue to drain blood and re-establish flow.
Transverse Vaginal Septum Requires surgical resection and vaginoplasty; more complex reconstruction.


Other options:

  • Bartholin’s Cyst:

    • Presents as a unilateral, soft swelling near the posterior introitus.

    • Typically not associated with cryptomenorrhea.

  • Endometriomas (Chocolates cysts):

    • Arise from endometriosis due to retrograde menstruation.

    • May develop if cryptomenorrhea is long-standing and uncorrected.


Reference:Shaws textbook of Gynaecology 17th edition page no 144

choices.text: The procedure is done under local anesthesia.
Ano-scalpel technique is being widely used now.
Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure
The vas deferens Is the structure that is divided in the procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding vasectomy?
questions.solution:
1. The procedure is done under local anesthesia

    •  True. Vasectomy is a minor surgical procedure usually performed under local anesthesia in an outpatient setting.

  2. No-scalpel technique is being widely used now

    •  True. The no-scalpel vasectomy is preferred due to:

      • Fewer complications

      • Less pain

      • Shorter recovery time

  3. The vas deferens is the structure that is divided in the procedure

    •  True. In vasectomy, a segment of the vas deferens is ligated or cauterized to block the passage of sperm from the testes to the urethra.

      Incorrect Statement:

  4. Sterility is achieved 3 weeks after the procedure

    • False.

    • Sterility is not immediate after vasectomy.

    • It typically takes at least 3 months or 15–20 ejaculations to clear sperm from the ejaculatory ducts.

    • Patients are advised to use alternative contraception until two consecutive semen analyses confirm azoospermia.



Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 560

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with post-coital bleeding. On per vaginal examination, the following lesion is seen which bleeds on touching. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A cervical polyp is a benign, pedunculated growth arising from the endocervical canal. It often appears as a:

  • Cherry red or reddish-pink, smooth, soft lesion protruding from the external os

  • Bleeds easily on touch (friable)

  • Associated with post-coital bleeding, intermenstrual bleeding, or may be asymptomatic

    Differentiation from other options:

Condition Typical Appearance Key Features
Cervical Polyp Cherry red, soft, smooth, pedunculated Bleeds on touch, common cause of post-coital bleeding
Haemorrhagic cyst Cystic, often ovarian not cervical Seen on pelvic ultrasound, not visualized on per speculum exam
Cervical fibroid Firm, fleshy, pale (not red) Rare; presents as firm mass protruding through the cervical canal
Cervical cancer Irregular, friable, ulcerative or fungating May also bleed on touch, but more likely in older women, hard mass
 

A bleeding cherry red lesion protruding from the cervix in a middle-aged woman = Cervical polyp


Reference: Williams gynaecology 3rd edition page no 189-190

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal irritation and green frothy genital discharge. On examination, a strawberry vagina is visible. What will be the preferred drug?
questions.solution:
Metronidazole is used in treatment of Trichomonas vaginalis infection


Recommended Regimen
Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose
      OR
Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose

Alternative Regimen
Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days

Students should remember some characteristic features of few genital tract infection
Microbial diseases of the reproductive system

Disease Pathogen Symptoms
Bacterial Diseases
Gonorrhea Neisseria gonorrhoeae Painful urination, discharge of pus in males, abnormal vaginal discharge in females
Nongonococcal urethritis (NGU) Chlamydia trachomatis or other bacteria, including Painful urination and watery discharge, Chronic abdominal pain in females
Syphilis Treponema pallidum Initial sore at sire of infection, later skin rashes and mild fever; final stages may be severe lesions, damage to cardiovascular and nervous systems.

Viral Diseases
Genital Herpes Herpes simplex virus type 2; HSV type 1 Painful vesicles in genital area
Genital warts Human papilloma viruses Warts in genital area
AIDS Human Immunodeficiency virus (HIV) loss of appetite, weight loss, persistent cough, attack on T cells (immunocompromised), easily prone to fungal and other bacterial pathogens as secondary opportunistic infections.
Fungal Disease
Candidiasis Candida albicans Severe vaginal itching, yeasty odor, yellow discharge
Protozoan Diseases
Trichomoniasis Trichomonas vaginalis Vaginal itching, greenish yellow discharge

Condition Appearance Symptoms Associated Signs
Herpes Simplex Virus Painful vesicles or ulcers Burning, itching, pain Lymphadenopathy, systemic symptoms (fever)
Syphilis (Primary) Painless ulcer (chancre) Usually asymptomatic Indurated borders, regional lymphadenopathy

questions.text: A 30-year-old girl from a low socioeconomic class who lives in a hill station complains of amenorrhea, mild fever, loss of appetite, and frequent urination in addition to other symptoms including dysuria and hematuria. Her concerns are most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Genitourinary tuberculosis is very common in India.

Most common site of infection of genital tuberculosis is the fallopian tubes ( spreads from lungs via hematogenous route ) and the pathological process leads to blockage of tubes. Its features include -
1. Dysuria
2. Urinary frequency
3. Urinary urgency
4. Urinalysis may show pyuria and bacteriuria
5. Micturition pain
6. Weakness of stream
7. Genital ulcers
8. Hematuria
9. Flank pain
10. Low-grade fever

HSG- shows golf club appearance of Fallopian tubes.
