questions.text: Which of the following problems may result from persistent pelvic inflammation?
questions.solution:
• Pyometra, or pyometrium, is defined as the accumulation of pus in the uterine cavity resulting from interference with its natural drainage. 
  • The most common cause of pyometra is malignant diseases of genital tract and the consequences of their treatment (radiotherapy).
  • Other causes are benign tumors like leiomyoma, endometrial polyps, senile cervicitis, cervical occlusion after surgery, pelvic infections, and congenital cervical anomalies.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 342-345.

questions.text: What is the CDC regimen to treat chlamydia infection in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Azithromycin
 
  • Untreated chlamydial infection has been linked to problems during pregnancy, including preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, and low birth weight.
  • The newborn may also become infected during delivery as the baby passes through the birth canal.
  • Exposed newborns can develop eye and lung infections.
  • CDC Regimen for Chlamydial Infection During Pregnancy Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose. Alternative Regimen Amoxicillin 500 mg orally 3 times/day for 7 days
  • Doxycycline and tetracycline are contraindicated in Pregnancy as it can cause nasal hypoplasia in fetus. 



Reference: Sexually Transmitted Infections Treatment Guidelines 2021, CDC (2021). URL: https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment-guidelines/chlamydia.htm
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice to treat chlamydia infection in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Erythromycin

Since Azithromycin and Amoxicillin are not in the option the other medicine that can be used to treat Chlamydia in pregnancy is Erythromycin.

  • Because of concerns regarding chlamydia persistence after exposure to penicillin-class antibiotics that has been demonstrated in animal and in vitro studies, amoxicillin is listed as an alternative therapy for C. trachomatis for pregnant women.
  • Erythromycin is no longer recommended because of the frequency of gastrointestinal side effects that can result in therapy nonadherence.
  • In addition, systematic reviews and meta-analyses have noted an association with macrolide antimicrobials, especially erythromycin, during pregnancy and adverse child outcomes, indicating cautious use in pregnancy.
  • Doxycycline and Tetracycline are contraindicated in pregnancy as they can cause nasal hypoplasia. 



Reference: Sexually Transmitted Infections Treatment Guidelines 2021, CDC (2021). URL: https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment-guidelines/chlamydia.htm
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: Which of these causes non immune hydrops fetalis
questions.solution:
• Parvo virus B19 causes Non immune hydrops
  •  Hydrops fetalis is a serious condition characterized by abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, such as the abdominal cavity, pleural cavity, and skin.
  • Etiology: Common causes include Rh incompatibility, infections (like parvovirus B19 and toxoplasmosis), fetal anemia, cardiac defects, and chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Clinical Features: Signs may include fetal edema (swelling), polyhydramnios (excess amniotic fluid), and ultrasound findings such as thickened skin, ascites, or pleural effusion.

  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily through ultrasound imaging, which reveals the fluid accumulation



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 360.

questions.text: At 34 weeks of pregnancy, a woman experiences fluid leakage from her vaginum and meconium-colored liquor. The most likely cause amongst the following organisms:
questions.solution:
Listeria Monocytogenes

  • Listeriosis is a rare infection, but is about 20 times more common in pregnant women than in the general population.
  • Pregnant women account for 27% of all listerial infections which can cause mild illness in mothers, but can be devastating to the fetus, in some cases leading to severe disease or fetal death.
  • During the first trimester of pregnancy, listeriosis may cause miscarriage. As the pregnancy progresses to third trimester, the mother is more at risk.
  • Listeriosis can also lead to premature labor, the delivery of a low-birth-weight infant, or infant death
  • Listeria in newborns can be classified as early onset or late-onset infection. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid is common in newborns with early onset Listeria.
  • Respiratory difficulty is common, including a history of cyanotic episodes, rapid breathing, and grunting.
 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1196.
Online source https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/965841

questions.text: All of the following interventions are recommended to prevent mother to child transmission of HIV, except:
questions.solution:
Rest all are recommended measures to reduce mother to child transmission of HIV
The PMTCT Cascade
1. Utilization of Antenatal Care (ANC)
2. Receiving HIV pretest counseling
3. Acceptance of HIV test
4. Receiving HIV test results & post-test counseling
5. Use of ARV prophylaxis for mom and/or baby (For seropositive mom)
6. Use of Labor &Delivery services which include PMTCT interventions
7. Postnatal follow up of mom and baby with HIV test for exposed infant and timely linkage to treatment, care and support.

questions.text: A female who is sexually active presents with excessive, foamy, foul-smelling discharge as well as severe itching with exposed strawberry cervix in per speculum examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis infection
Foul smelling discharge with strawberry cervix points towards Trichomonas infection.
Trichomoniasis is a very common STD caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis (a protozoan parasite)
Women with it may notice-Itching, burning, redness or soreness of the genitals,discomfort when peeing; and
A clear, white, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge (i.e., thin discharge or increased volume) with a fishy smell.
Recommended Regimen for Trichomoniasis Among Women. Metronidazole 500 mg 2 times/day for 7 days.
Alternative Regimen for Women and Men- Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.

Strawberry cervix

questions.text: A 18-year-old female patient arrives at the gynaecology OPD with six months of amenorrhea, h/o low grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and generalised weakness. During a clinical  examination, a pelvic mass with ascites-like symptoms was felt on the left side. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
TB with tubo-ovarian mass
Six months of amenorrhea, h/o low grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and generalised weakness point towards diagnosis
GUTB, as with other cases of TB, is usually caused by infection with M. tuberculosis. However, other species of mycobacteria in the MTB complex, including Mycobacterium bovis, Mycobacterium africanum, Mycobacterium pinnipedii, Mycobacterium microti, Mycobacterium caprae, and the TB vaccine bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG), can rarely cause disease. In developing countries, the incidence tends to be higher at around 15 to 20%.

Medical Treatment
GUTB, in general, is treated like pulmonary TB with a four-drug regimen for six months (rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for the first two months, then isoniazid and rifampicin for four months).
Patients that may need longer treatment include patients with HIV co-infection, kidney abscesses, or bone infiltration.
Patients with multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) require treatment with MDR-TB regimens that include fluoroquinolones, bedaquiline, delaminid, aminoglycosides, etc., and the regimen may extend up to 18 to 24 months.
Surgical Treatment
Patients with GUTB complicated with ureteral stricture and hydronephrosis should be treated with early stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy.
Nephrectomy is considered in patients with non-functioning kidneys, patients with co-existing renal cell carcinomas, and those with extensive disease involving the whole kidney.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 350-354.

choices.text: Helps to Diagnose cancer in Genital Tract
Helps to Diagnose other associated Genital infections in the Patient

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman who frequently contracts Trichomonas vaginalis infection visits the gynecology outpatient department.
She was told to get a PAP Smear. She is curious about the purpose of this test and enquires about the same. What will be the appropriate response?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Helps to Screen for Cervical Cancer
 

A Pap smear, or Papanicolaou test, is primarily used to screen for cervical cancer by detecting precancerous or cancerous changes in cervical cells. While it can sometimes incidentally detect infections like Trichomonas vaginalis or other abnormalities, its primary purpose is not to diagnose infections but to catch early signs of cervical cancer.

Other options:

  1. Helps to Diagnose cancer in Genital Tract: While the Pap smear can help in identifying precancerous or cancerous cells in the cervix, it’s not a diagnostic tool for all genital tract cancers.
  2. Helps to demonstrate Trichomonas vaginalis infection: Although Trichomonas may occasionally be seen in a Pap smear, other tests like a wet mount or NAAT are more reliable for diagnosing infections.
  3. Helps to Diagnose other associated Genital infections in the Patient: Pap smears are not specifically designed for diagnosing infections.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 364.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains to the OP that her vaginal discharge is green and itchy locally. The cervix seems to be a strawberry upon close inspection. What is the course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Metronidazole
This is a typical case of green vaginal discharge with strawberry cervix suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis.
Trichomoniasis is a very common STD caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis (a protozoan parasite)
Women with it may notice
Itching, burning, redness or soreness of the genitals;
Discomfort when peeing; and A clear, white, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge (i.e., thin discharge or increased volume) with a fishy smell.
Recommended Regimen for Trichomoniasis Among Women. Metronidazole 500 mg 2 times/day for 7 days. Partner is also given the same treatment. 
Alternative Regimen for Women and Men. Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 364, 365.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman complains of vaginal discharge and localised itching. The results of a Pap test revealed the following image. What might be the cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Gardenella vaginalis
The history of vaginal itching with presence of CLUE CELLS indicate Bacterial vaginosis causes by Gardenella vaginalis.
Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by adherent gram-negative rods, observed in vaginal smears from women with bacterial vaginosis.
AMSEL CRITERIA IS USED FOR DIAGNOSIS OF BV

Amsel Criteria for Diagnosis of BV: Three of the following four criteria must be met. Establishes accurate diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis in 90% of affected women.

1) Homogeneous, non-clumping vaginal discharge (color and amount may vary)

2) Amine (fishy) odor when potassium hydroxide solution is added to vaginal secretions (commonly) called the "whiff test")

3) Presence of clue cells (greater than 20%) on microscopy

4) Vaginal pH greater than 4.5

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 330, 331.

questions.text: A young female has lower abdomen pain for one month. She reports mild intermenstrual bleeding and dysuria with scanty vaginal discharge which had subsided on its own within a week.  She has a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This female is most likely to suffer from pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The most common cause of PID is sexually transmitted diseases (STD), with gonococcal and chlamydial infections being the most common.
  • While chlamydial infection is often subacute and remains undiagnosed, Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection frequently presents as acute PID, as in this patient.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 68.

questions.text: A female patient is diagnosed with recurrent genital infections. In which of the conditions does her male partner need to be treated?
questions.solution:
In cases of recurrent genital infections, treatment of the male partner is required only when the infection is sexually transmissible and can persist asymptomatically in men.

  • Trichomoniasis:

    • Caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, a sexually transmitted protozoan.

    • Men are often asymptomatic carriers, which can lead to re-infection of female partners.

    • Both partners must be treated simultaneously to prevent recurrence. 

  • Herpes genitalis:

    • Viral infection; treatment of the male partner is not mandatory unless symptomatic.

    • Recurrences are due to latent virus in the affected individual, not reinfection.

  • Bacterial vaginosis:

    • Not considered sexually transmitted in the traditional sense; male partner treatment is not recommended.

  • Candida albicans:

    • Usually endogenous overgrowth; male partner treatment is only indicated if he is symptomatic.

questions.text: Amsel's criteria is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Amsel’s criteria is a clinical diagnostic tool for bacterial vaginosis (BV).

  • Diagnosis requires at least 3 of the following 4 criteria:

    1. Homogeneous, thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge

    2. Vaginal pH > 4.5

    3. Positive “whiff test” (fishy odor when 10% KOH added to vaginal discharge)

    4. Clue cells on wet mount microscopy

  • Other options:

    • Chlamydial vaginitis: Diagnosed by NAAT or culture

    • Gonococcal vaginitis: Diagnosed by Gram stain or culture

    • Trichomonas vaginitis: Diagnosed by wet mount microscopy showing motile trichomonads

questions.text: A 32 year old female presents with grey-white vaginal discharge and on gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are seen. Clue cells are-
questions.solution:
Clue cells are epithelial cells with a fuzzy border or granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering to their surface, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by organisms such as *Mobiluncuscurtisii*, *Gardnerellavaginalis*, *Mycoplasma hominis*, and *Haemophilus vaginalis*. It typically presents with a malodorous (fishy smelling) vaginal discharge and minimal vulval irritation.

Amsel‘s Criteria is commonly used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis. A diagnosis is made when 3 out of the following 4 criteria are present:

1. Thin, white, homogenous vaginal discharge
2. Vaginal fluid pH > 4.5
3. Fishy odor of the discharge, especially when 10% KOH is added (positive Whiff test)
4. Presence of clue cells on microscopy

The standard treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days. Alternatively, ampicillin 500 mg or cephalosporin 500 mg twice daily for 7 days can also be effective.

 

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th edition, Page no 56,57 .

questions.text: All the following can result in non-immune hydrops except -.
questions.solution:
ABO incompatibility is not a cause of nonimmune hydrops. Hydrops is diagnosed when there are two or more fetal effusions—such as pleural, pericardial, or ascitic—or one effusion plus anasarca. It can be associated with red cell autoimmunization, known as immune hydrops, but otherwise, it is classified as nonimmune. The pathogenesis of hydrops includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability.

•Etiology of HydropsFetalis

*Cardiovascular:
- Structural defects: Ebstein anomaly, tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve, hypoplastic left or right heart, premature closure of ductus arteriosus, arteriovenous malformation (vein of Galen aneurysm).
- Cardiomyopathies.
- Tachyarrhythmias.
- Bradycardia, which may occur in heterotaxy syndrome with endocardial cushion defect or with anti-Ro/La antibodies.

**Chromosomal:**
- Turner syndrome (45,X), triploidy, trisomies 21, 18, and 13.

*Hematological:
- Hemoglobinopathies, such as ?-thalassemia.
- Erythrocyte enzyme and membrane disorders.
- Erythrocyte aplasia/dyserythropoiesis.
- Decreased erythrocyte production (myeloproliferative disorders).
- Fetomaternalhemorrhage.

*Lymphatic Abnormalities:
- Cystic hygroma, systemic lymphangiectasis, pulmonary lymphangiectasis.

*Infections:
- Parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, Lyme disease.

*Syndromic:
- Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita, lethal multiple pterygium, congenital lymphedema, myotonic dystrophy type 1, Neu-Laxova, Noonan, and Pena-Shokeir syndromes.

*Thoracic Abnormalities:
- Cystic adenomatoid malformation.
- Pulmonary sequestration.
- Diaphragmatic hernia.
- Hydro/chylothorax.
- Congenital high airway obstruction sequence (CHAOS).
- Mediastinal tumors.
- Skeletal dysplasia with a very small thorax.

*Gastrointestinal:
- Meconium peritonitis, gastrointestinal tract obstruction.

*Kidney and Urinary Tract:
- Kidney malformations.
- Bladder outlet obstructions.
- Congenital (Finnish) nephrosis, Bartter syndrome, mesoblasticnephroma.

*Placental, Twin, and Cord Abnormalities:
- Placental chorioangioma, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, twin reversed arterial perfusion sequence, twin anemia-polycythemia sequence, cord vessel thrombosis.

*Other Rare Disorders:
- Inborn errors of metabolism: Gaucher disease, galactosialidosis, GM1 gangliosidosis, sialidosis, mucopolysaccharidoses, mucolipidoses.
- Tumors: sacrococcygealteratoma, hemangioendothelioma with Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.

 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 361 .

questions.text: A young sexually active female patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of lower abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On examination, the body temperature is 103 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse rate is 109 per minute and there is abdominal tenderness. Cervical motion tenderness is present on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Key Points on Pelvic Inflammatory Disease:

Definition: PID involves the inflammation of the upper genital tract, including the fallopian tubes and ovaries.
Etiology:
It commonly affects sexually active young women.
Often preceded by a sexually transmitted infection (STI), with gonococcal and chlamydial infections being the most frequent culprits.
Clinical Presentation:
Symptoms:
Lower abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, dysuria, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia.
Vaginal discharge is also commonly seen.
The symptoms can vary depending on the causative organism.
Examination Findings:
Fever (103–104°F), abdominal tenderness, tachycardia, and the presence of a pelvic mass.
Complications of Chronic PID:
Chronic pelvic pain, menorrhagia, ectopic pregnancy, and infertility.

Diagnostic Criteria for Acute PID:
Primary Findings: Presence of uterine, adnexal, or cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of acute PID, particularly if other causes are excluded.
Supporting Criteria:
1. Oral temperature >38.3°C (101.6°F).
2. Mucopurulent cervical discharge or cervical friability.
3. Presence of abundant WBCs on saline microscopy of cervical secretions.
4. Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) or C-reactive protein (CRP).
5. Detection of N. gonorrhea or C. trachomatis in cervical specimens.

questions.text: A woman presents with complaints of greenish-frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. On examination vulvovaginal erythema is noticed. On saline microscopy, motile organisms are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and microscopic findings point towards trichomoniasis as the diagnosis.

Clinical Features:
Vaginal Discharge: The discharge is typically profuse, thin, slightly green, and frothy in appearance.
Associated Symptoms: Patients may experience vaginal irritation, dysuria (painful urination), and increased urinary frequency.
Cervical Inflammation: A characteristic feature is the presence of punctate hemorrhagic spots on the cervix, commonly referred to as "strawberry cervix," which is indicative of trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.
Diagnosis:
Microscopic Examination: The diagnosis is confirmed by identifying motile trichomonads on wet mount examination of vaginal discharge.

Visual Evidence:
The accompanying image illustrates the "strawberry cervix," a hallmark sign associated with trichomoniasis, emphasizing the inflammation and appearance typical of this sexually transmitted infection.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presented with malodorous discharge in the vagina which started a week earlier. On examination, Whiff's test is positive and the gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. This infection is commonly treated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis: Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)

Key findings in the case:

  • Malodorous vaginal discharge

  • Positive Whiff’s test (fishy odor when 10% KOH is added)

  • Clue cells on Gram stain (vaginal epithelial cells studded with bacteria)

These findings are diagnostic of bacterial vaginosis, most commonly caused by Gardnerella vaginalis and an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora.

Treatment:

  • First-line treatment: Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days

  • Alternative: Clindamycin (oral or intravaginal)

    Incorrect options:

  • Doxycycline – used for Chlamydia trachomatis

  • Azithromycin – also used for Chlamydia

  • Tetracycline – older antibiotic rarely used now, also used for Chlamydia

    Amsel's Criteria for Diagnosis of Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)

    Amsel's criteria are clinical diagnostic criteria used to identify bacterial vaginosis. The diagnosis is made when 3 out of the following 4 criteria are met:

    Criterion Description
    1. Homogeneous vaginal discharge Thin, white or gray discharge that coats the vaginal walls uniformly.
    2. Elevated vaginal pH Vaginal fluid pH > 4.5 (normal vaginal pH is 3.8–4.5).
    3. Positive Whiff test A fishy odor when 10% KOH is added to vaginal discharge (amine odor).
    4. Clue cells on microscopy Vaginal epithelial cells that appear stippled or "fuzzy" due to adherent bacteria under wet mount microscopy. They should make up at least 20% of epithelial cells seen.

Reference: Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition page no 384-385,164-165

choices.text: Degradation of the insulin by the placenta
Increasing demand for insulin as the pregnancy advances
Increased production of the human placental lactogen

questions.text: A 25-year-old 26-week pregnant woman was diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Which of the following is not a likely cause for it?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Recurrent vaginal candidiasis in present pregnancy.

Gestational diabetes occurs due to increased insulin resistance during pregnancy, primarily because of hormones like human placental lactogen, estrogen, and progesterone. These hormones rise as pregnancy progresses, increasing the demand for insulin. The placenta also produces enzymes that degrade insulin, contributing further to insulin resistance.

Recurrent vaginal candidiasis is a consequence of gestational diabetes, not a cause. Elevated blood glucose levels provide a favorable environment for Candida growth, leading to recurrent infections.


Reference:DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page no 327

questions.text: Which medication is not prescribed for PCOD in a 30-year-old woman with infertility?
questions.solution:
• Drug not given in PCOD in a 30-year-old lady with infertility is OCP as OCP itself is a contraceptive agent which inhibits ovulation.
  • Rest all the drugs above can be given in PCOD with infertility

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly prescribed for managing symptoms of PCOD (such as irregular periods, acne, and hirsutism) by regulating menstrual cycles and reducing androgen levels. However, they are generally not prescribed when a woman is seeking to conceive, as they prevent ovulation and therefore do not aid in achieving pregnancy.

In contrast:

  1. Clomiphene and

  2. Letrozole are ovulation-inducing medications used to help women with PCOD and infertility to conceive.

  3. Metformin may also be prescribed to improve insulin sensitivity, which can aid in ovulation and support fertility in women with PCOD.

 



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 316.

questions.text: A couple is struggling with infertility. Following an examination, a semen study revealed that the husband had azoospermia. According to the rectal examination, the vas was not palpable. Low volume, high viscosity, and fructose were all characteristics of the semen. What might you do from there?
questions.solution:
CFTR gene mutation analysis

This is a case of obstructive azoospermia due to CBAVD

Congenital absence of the vas deferens (CAVD) is a condition in which the vasa deferentia reproductive organs fail to form properly prior to birth. It may either be unilateral (CUAVD) or bilateral (CBAVD).There are two main populations of CAVD; the larger group is associated with cystic fibrosis and occurs because of a mutation in the CFTR gene while the smaller group is associated with unilateral renal agenesis (URA). 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 206, 207.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation.
questions.solution:
Essure is a way of hysteroscopic tubal ligation and laproscopic.

 Essure is a metal coil which when placed into each fallopian tube induces fibrosis and blockage.
      




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 274.

questions.text: A young female's infertility is caused by a disorder in which various lifestyle components have been identified. Which of the following changes in lifestyle will not have any impact in the management of the particular disorder?
questions.solution:
The lifestyle change that will likely not have any impact in the management of the particular disorder related to infertility is:

Option 3. Vegan diet

  • A vegan diet, while generally healthy, does not specifically target common fertility-related disorders like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which often benefit from weight management, physical activity, and dietary changes that regulate insulin levels.
 
  • Weight loss, more exercise, and a low-carbohydrate diet—can directly impact hormonal balance, insulin sensitivity, and ovulatory function, all of which can help improve fertility in conditions like PCOS.
 

Other options:

  1. Weight loss: Reducing excess weight can improve hormonal balance and ovulation in women with PCOS.
  2. More exercise: Regular exercise helps regulate insulin levels, supports weight management, and can enhance fertility.
  3. Low carbohydrate diet: A low-carb diet may improve insulin sensitivity and reduce symptoms of PCOS, which can aid in managing infertility.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314-316.

questions.text: What is the next step in managing a 32-year-old woman with bilateral tubal block seen at cornu on a hysterosalpingogram and a five-year history of primary infertility?
questions.solution:
Laproscopy and hysteroscopy

  • Since the HSG is showing only cornual block , it must be reconfirmed  by doing a laproscopy and hysteroscopy and a chromopertubation test.
  • Sometimes during HSG there can be a cornual spasm which can give a wrong impression of cornual block . 
  • Hence such cases must be reconfirmed before taking patient for IVF 
Mullerian abnormalities :- 
Type 1 :- MRHK or Mullerian agenesis 
Type 2 :- Unicornuate uterus -1 sided mullerian duct develops - never leads to transverse lie (PYQ)
Type 3 :- Didelphic uterus - lack of fusion of both the mullerian ducts 
Type 4:- Bicornuate uterus - incomplete fusion 
-angle b/w 2 horns more than 75 degrees 
Type 5:- Septate uterus - septa which forms after fusion fails to resolve 
- mc type 
- mc type causing infertility 
-angle less than 75 degress 
- Treatment - metroplasty ,hysteroscopic septal resection(PYQ)
Type 6 :- Arcuate uterus - flat topped 
- no anatomical abnormality 
Type 7:- DES related anomalies - hypoplastic uterus ,T shaped uterus

Diagnosis :- 
1. Hysterosalpingography 
2. IOC = 3D USG 
3. Gold Standard - MRI 
4. BEST - Laparoscopy + Hysteroscopy(PYQ)



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 217-219.

questions.text: What can be seen in the HSG image below?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is genital TB as areas of blocked/constricted fallopian tubes are seen in the HSG.
It is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Infection almost always results from spread from an extragenital source, usually from a hematogenous source or less commonly, via lymphatic vessels or from the peritoneal cavity.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 217, 351.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about Swyer syndrome?
questions.solution:
Can be fertile with ovum donation 

Because women with Swyer syndrome lack ovaries, they are infertile.
However, they can become pregnant through the implantation of donated eggs.

XY gonadal dysgenesis, also known as Swyer syndrome, is a type of hypogonadism in a person whose karyotype is 46,XY. Though they typically have normal female external genitalia, the person has functionless gonads, fibrous tissue termed “streak gonads”, and if left untreated, will not experience puberty. Such gonads are typically surgically removed (as they have a significant risk of developing cancer)

The typical medical treatment is hormone replacement therapy.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 112, 141.

questions.text: Which of the following is a menopausal diagnostic sign?
questions.solution:
Menopause is the time in most women's lives when menstruation ends permanently. Usually, menopause starts between the ages of 45 and 55.

 Criteria for Menopause:

1. Estrogen (E2) low at 10-20 pg/ml
2. Estrone (El)- 30-70 pg/ml
3. E2/El < 1
4. Serum FSH > 40 IU/L


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 86, 87.

questions.text: Young female with a history of spontaneous abortion and secondary amenorrhea . Her FSH 6 IU/ml. What is the most probable cause of amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Uterine synechiae. It develops after D and C where later fibrous bands of Uterine synechiae develops, this is known as Asherman syndrome. 
As this is a case of secondary Amenorrhea with normal FSH levels , ovarian failure and pituitary failure are ruled out.
In ovarian failure, FSH > 25 IU/ ml
In Pituitary failure FSH < 5 IU/ ml
In pregnancy due to high estrogen in body FSH < 0.1 IU/ ml


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 153, 154. 
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 374, 375.

questions.text: A postmenopausal female arrived with a biopsy report of endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia should be managed by Type 1 Hystrectomy as there is high risk of malignancy.
As a simple rule, students should remember, hyperplasia without atypia can be given a trial of hormonal treatment in the form of mirena insertion followed by repeating biopsy to see for progression of disease after 3 months.
In cases of Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia , risk of progresion to malignancy is high , so Hystrectomy is indicated.


Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th edition, Page no 703.
Berek and Novak's Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 2363, 2364.

questions.text:
A patient who is the father of two children and whose wife is unable to conceive is diagnosed with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Low prolactin levels
A patient of hypo- hypo will have low FSH and low LH which will ultimately lead to low spermatogenesis and low testosterone.
However, prolactin levels will be high in such cases.


Reference: Berek and Novak's Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 2242.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman arrived to the infertility clinic's OPD. Bromocriptine was prescribed for her. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Hyperprolactinemia
Bromocriptine and cabergoline are used in the treatment of Hyperprolactinemia
Bromocriptine is a dopamine D2 receptor agonist used for the treatment of galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia and other prolactin-related conditions.
 

Bromocriptine-

  • Starting Dose: Usually begins at 1.25 mg to 2.5 mg daily, taken with food to minimize gastrointestinal side effects.
  • Maintenance Dose: The dose may be gradually increased, typically to a range of 2.5 mg to 15 mg per day, depending on the individual response and the condition being treated.

Cabergoline-

  • Starting Dose: Typically starts at 0.5 mg per week, which can be taken as a single dose or divided into two doses.
  • Maintenance Dose: The dose may be gradually increased, with a common maximum dose of up to 1 mg to 2 mg per week, depending on the patient's response and tolerance.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 150,198, 199.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is diagnosed with primary amenorrhea. She had an immature uterus and a 45XO karyotype upon assessment. What is the next line of action?
questions.solution:
HRT to induce puberty
Primary amenorrhea with XO karyotype indicates Turner syndrome which needs treatment with HRT.
Gonadectomy is required only if there is an associated Y chromosome as such patients have high risk of gonadoblastoma.

Treatment of Turner syndrome
• The best way to treat this disorder is:
   Hormone replacement therapy
• Hormone replacement therapy is usually started at the time of normal puberty, around 12 years.
• Teenagers are treated with growth hormone to help them reach a normal height.
• They may also be given low doses of androgens (male hormones that females also produce in small quantities) to increase height and encourage hair and muscle growth.
• Some patients may take the female hormone estrogen to promote sexual development.


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 3003, 3004.

questions.text: A couple arrives for an infertility assessment. The HSG was normal, but azoospermia was discovered by semen analysis. What diagnostic procedure allows for the separation of testicular failure from vas deferens obstruction?
questions.solution:
In cases of testicular failure,  FSH levels will be high but in cases of obstruction, FSH levels will be normal as spermatogenesis happens normally.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 208.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl arrived for an evaluation of secondary amenorrhea. She has PCOS, which caused hirsutism, irregular bleeding and infertility, about which she is worried. Which of the following medications should not be administered?
questions.solution:
OCPs If the patient is also suffering from infertility, then OCPs can’t be used as they are contraceptive. If Infertility was not in option, then the best option is Tamoxifen. However, all the following can be used in PCO patients. Clomiphene and tamoxifen for induction of ovulation. OCPs for regulating the cycles and to control hirsutism Spirinolactone is used for control of hirsutism.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 316.

choices.text: Absence of oocytes in the ovaries (streak ovaries)

questions.text: A 16-year-old female complains of primary amenorrhea with a high FSH level. Her height was measured at 58 inches. What would the ovary's histopathology findings be?
questions.solution:
• Primary amenorrhea with high FSH and short stature(58 inches height) is highly suggestive of Turner syndrome.
  • Turners syndrome is caused due to a missing or partially missing X chromosome (Karyotype - 45, XO)
  • One of its characteristic features is streak ovaries. Clinical Features of Turner's Syndrome include: Short stature Streak ovaries: They do not experience puberty or menstruation.
  • Lack of Secondary sexual characteristics: underdeveloped breasts, a narrow pelvis, and a lack of pubic hair. Cardiac and/or renal defects. Eg bicuspid aortic valve/horseshoe kidney,Webbed neck, Low-set ears, Broad chest with widely spaced nipples, Cubitus valgus, The forearms may curve outward at the elbows, Low posterior hairline, Multi-pigmented naevi.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 144.

questions.text: Primary amenorrhea was discovered in a 16-year-old female with normal pubic hair and breast tissue. Upon examination, the uterus was gone, and the vagina was blind. What is the proper diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mullerian agenesis

Differential diagnosis between MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser) and AIS (androgen insensitivity syndrome)
MRKH AIS
Genotype XX Genotype XY
Normal female serum T levels Normal male T levels
Normal female pubic and axillary hair Decreased pubic and axillary hair
Normal female height Increased height compared with female counterparts
Normal ovaries located high on the pelvic side wall Intra-abdominal testicles
No increased risk of gonadal malignancy Gonads removal recommended after puberty due to increased risk of malignancy

Note: Milder forms of AIS might present a less affected phenotype.
Abbreviation: T. testosterone.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 143.

questions.text: For which of these condition given below is hormone replacement therapy not given?
questions.solution:
Prevention of CAD

Hormone replacement therapy can be useful in controlling menopausal symptoms (hot flashes,urogenital atrophy  etc.) and helping to prevent osteoporosis. 

It has also been suggested that although estrogen might reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease, primarily by improving lipid profile or by vascular effects, estrogen may increase the injury resulting from ischemia, either by increased cell death pathways or by adverse remodeling.
 

Benefits Risks
Short term
• Controls symptoms during the menopause transition within days or weeks/improves mood
 		 • Oral HRT increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
• Increases the risk of CVD in women who start HRT after age 60 and in those who already have risk factors, such as smoking, being overweight, or having high blood pressure or high cholesterol
Long term
• Keeps bones healthy, reducing the risk of osteoporosis and fractures (broken bones)		 • Small increase in breast-cancer risk after age 60
• Reduces the risk of CVD (as long as HRT is started within 5-6 years of the menopause transition and there are no other risk factors) • Slight increase in the risk of gallbladder disease
•May protect against memory loss and possibly Alzheimer's disease
• Reduces the risk of boewl cancer		 Note: Some of these risks (for example, DVT) are not increased when oestrogen is administered by patch, gel or spray rather than as tablets.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 91-94.

questions.text: Primary amenorrhea, small stature, widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and primary amenorrhea are present in a 22-year-old female. The likely  Karyotype is
questions.solution:
45 XO ( Turner syndrome) 





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 144.

questions.text: A 70 years old female is on treatment with Alendronate for 7 years for osteoporosis. Now she complains of pain in right thigh. What is the next best  investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
2. X-ray

  • Thigh pain in a patient on long-term bisphosphonate therapy (e.g., Alendronate) raises concern for an atypical femoral fracture (AFF), which is a known rare complication of prolonged bisphosphonate use.
  • X-ray is the first-line investigation to evaluate for an atypical femoral fracture. It may show a transverse fracture or signs of a stress reaction (e.g., cortical thickening) in the femoral diaphysis, even before a complete fracture develops.

Other options:
 
  1. DEXA scan: Measures bone density but does not help in identifying fractures or stress reactions, so it is not relevant for diagnosing the source of pain.
  2. Serum vitamin D levels: Important for assessing bone health but not directly related to evaluating the cause of thigh pain.
  3. Serum alkaline phosphatase levels: Can indicate increased bone turnover in certain conditions but is not specific for diagnosing an atypical femoral fracture.
DEXA scans can measure tiny reductions in bone density. This makes it possible to diagnose osteoporosis in its early stages but it is not used as an investigation to diagnose femur fracture.

Category Bone mass (BMD derived from DEXA measurement)
  • Normal- Spinal or hip BMD within 1.0 SD below the young adult female reference mean (T-score ≥ -1.0)
  • Low bone mass (osteopenia)- Spinal or hip BMD between 1.0 and 2.5 SDs below the young adult female reference mean (T-score<-1.0 and >-2.5)
  • Osteoporosis- Spinal or hip BMD ≥ 2.5 SDs below the young adult female reference mean (T-score ≤ -2.5)
  • Severe/established osteoporosis BMD ≥ 2.5 SDs below the young adult female reference mean and the presence of one or more fragility fractures.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 89, 90.

hot flushes

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist used
questions.solution:
They induce ovulation, spermatogenesis, and an increase in the production of estrogen and testosterone by increasing LH/FSH release through pulsatile dosing used to treat oligospermia (male infertility), anovulation, delayed puberty, and sexual infantilism.
They reduce the synthesis of estrogen and testosterone with continuous dosing. Consequently, it is utilized to treat illnesses that depend on estrogen and testosterone, such as prostate cancer, endometritis, uterine fibroids, and ER positive breast cancer.

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution:
Bilateral hydrosalpinx
Damage and blockage of the end portion of a fallopian tube can cause it to become filled with fluid; the swollen and fluid-filled tube is called a hydrosalpinx
The potential causes include:
Sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
Endometriosis
Infection in a fallopian tube
Inflammation from appendicitis
Scarring from surgery for appendicitis and other conditions
Previous surgery on the fallopian tube

questions.solution:
• Hysteroscopic septum resection is now the procedure of choice for management of uterine septum.
  • Historically, metroplasty for a septum was performed by laparotomy via the Jones or Tompkins procedure, which involved excising a wedge of the uterine fundus containing the septum or opening the fundus and incising the septum Strassmann metroplasty is used for bicornuate uterus.
Mullerian abnormalities :-

-angle b/w 2 horns more than 75 degrees

- mc type 
- mc type causing infertility 
-angle less than 75 degress 
- Treatment - metroplasty ,hysteroscopic septal resection(PYQ)
Type 6 :- Arcuate uterus - flat topped 
- no anatomical abnormality

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has been married for two years goes to an infertility clinic. She received HMG. She had dyspnea and stomach pain during treatment. The image below appears in her USG reports. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a condition that can occur in women undergoing fertility treatments, particularly those involving hormone medications to stimulate the ovaries, such as in vitro fertilization (IVF) or ovulation induction. Here’s an overview of the condition:

Causes:
- Hormonal Treatments: OHSS is primarily caused by the use of injectable hormones (like gonadotropins) to stimulate the ovaries, leading to the development of multiple follicles.
- Individual Factors: Some women may be more susceptible due to factors like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or previous episodes of OHSS.

Symptoms:
OHSS symptoms can range from mild to severe and typically manifest as follows:
- Mild Symptoms
  - Abdominal bloating
  - Mild abdominal pain
  - Nausea
  - Vomiting
  - Diarrhea

Moderate to Severe Symptoms:
  - Severe abdominal pain
  - Rapid weight gain (more than 2.2 kg or 5 lbs in a few days)
  - Shortness of breath
  - Oliguria 
  - Swelling in the abdomen or legs
  - Thrombosis 

Diagnosis:
Diagnosis is usually made based on clinical symptoms and may be confirmed with imaging tests (such as ultrasound) to assess ovarian size and fluid accumulation in the abdomen.

Treatment:
Treatment depends on the severity of OHSS:
- Mild Cases: Often managed with rest, hydration, and over-the-counter pain relief.
- Moderate to Severe Cases: May require hospitalization, intravenous (IV) fluids, and monitoring. In severe cases, procedures to remove excess fluid from the abdomen (paracentesis) may be necessary.

Prevention:
- Careful Monitoring: Monitoring hormone levels and ovarian response during fertility treatments can help prevent OHSS.
- Adjusting Treatment Protocols: Using lower doses of hormones or alternative medications may reduce the risk.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 223.
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 223, 454-457.

questions.text:
On a 3D ultrasound, a uterine didelphys in a 28-year-old woman who was being tested for infertility was discovered.
Except for one, all of these are potential complications.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Transverse lie

Transverse lie is not possible in Uterine didelphys because the diameter of each cornu is less and cannot accommodate a fetus in transverse lie. 

Complications of Uterine Didelphys :
  • Repeated pregnancy loss.
  • Early labor.
  • Torn vaginal tissue between the two vaginas during labor.
  • Breech baby (facing feet first) who needs a C-section delivery.
  • Low birth weight.
  • Intrauterine growth restriction.
  • Kidney problems‌
  • Due to lack of space transverse lie is not commonly seen.


Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 422, 423.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 35, 37.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with normal periods of 28 days enters an infertility clinic. What should  the ovulation test be taken?
questions.solution:
Seum progesterone on day 21
After ovulation, corpus luteum is formed which secretes progesterone whose levels peak around day 21.

questions.text:
Which of the following are symptoms of endometriosis?
A. Dysmenorrhoea
B. Infertility
C. Irregular bleeding
D. Vaginal discharge
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. A, B and C
  • Clinical presentation of endometriosis varies in women.
  • Patients often present with symptoms such as intermenstrual bleeding, painful periods (dysmenorrhea), painful intercourse (dyspareunia), painful defecation (dyschezia) and painful urination (dysuria).


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 178, 179.

questions.text: Which of the following tests given below is used as marker for ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. AMH
  • Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH), a peptide growth factor of the transforming growth factor-β family, is a reliable marker of ovarian reserve.
  • Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH), a marker of ovarian reserve, declines over a woman’s reproductive lifespan. AMH is highly correlated with a woman’s age and number of primordial ovarian follicles, and has been shown to predict time to menopause in women in their 40s.
  • For these reasons, it was assumed that AMH levels could predict a woman’s reproductive potential or serve as a ‘fertility test.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 225.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Asthenospermia
 
  • Asthenozoospermia (or asthenospermia) is the term used to describe reduced sperm motility.
Kartagener’s syndrome (a.k.a Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia) is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder (due to dyenin defect) comprising the triad of:
  1. Situs inversus
  2. Chronic sinusitis
  3. Bronchiectasis.
  • The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.
  • Male patients with this syndrome are almost invariably infertile because of immotile spermatozoa. The immotility is due to variety of ultrastructural defects in dynein arm of cilia and sperm tail.



Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 9th edition, Page no 683.
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 205, 206.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with primary amenorrhea, normal sexual development and normal breasts, but absent pubic axillary hair. The examination shows bilateral inguinal hernias. Ultrasound shows an absent uterus and a blind vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Androgen Insensitivity syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is when a person who is genetically male (who has one X and one Y chromosome) is resistant to male hormones (called androgens).
  • As a result, the person has some of the physical traits of a woman, but the genetic makeup of a man.
Clinical features of AIS:
  • Genetically male (46,XY) with female external genitalia
  • Absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina
  • Internal testes (often undescended)
  • Sparse or absent pubic and axillary hair
  • Normal breast development
  • Primary amenorrhea (absence of menstruation)
  • Infertility
  • Female gender identity
  • Increased risk of gonadal tumors if testes are not removed
  • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome is treated with estrogen replacement therapy after puberty.
  • Undescended testicles will be surgically removed because of the risk that they will become cancerous.
  • Treatment for partial androgen insensitivity syndrome may include corrective surgery to match gender identity.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 113, 114.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is normal functioning of the ovaries seen?
questions.solution:
MRKH syndrome

A simple algorithm to differentiate different causes of primary amenorrhea .
    
Mullerian abnormalities :- 
Type 1 :- MRHK or Mullerian agenesis 
Type 2 :- Unicornuate uterus -1 sided mullerian duct develops - never leads to transverse lie (PYQ)
Type 3 :- Didelphic uterus - lack of fusion of both the mullerian ducts 
Type 4:- Bicornuate uterus - incomplete fusion 
-angle b/w 2 horns more than 75 degrees 
Type 5:- Septate uterus - septa which forms after fusion fails to resolve 
- mc type 
- mc type causing infertility 
-angle less than 75 degress 
- Treatment - metroplasty ,hysteroscopic septal resection(PYQ)
Type 6 :- Arcuate uterus - flat topped 
- no anatomical abnormality 
Type 7:- DES related anomalies - hypoplastic uterus ,T shaped uterus

Diagnosis :- 
1. Hysterosalpingography 
2. IOC = 3D USG 
3. Gold Standard - MRI 
4. BEST - Laparoscopy + Hysteroscopy(PYQ)


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: What is the best course of action for an infertile woman who has bilateral cornual block on hysterosalpingography?
questions.solution:
hysteroscopy and laproscopy

A case of bilateral cornual block could be because of cornual spasm during the HSG procedure.
Hence, one should go for laparo-hysteroscopy to confirm the cause before going for IVF.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 217-219.

questions.text: HRT is given to all postmenopausal women except:
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy can be useful in controlling menopausal symptoms (hot flushes, urogenital atrophy  etc.) and helping to prevent osteoporosis. 

It has also been suggested that although estrogen might reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease, primarily by improving lipid profile or by vascular effects, estrogen may increase the injury resulting from ischemia, either by increased cell death pathways or by adverse remodeling.

Indications of HRT in Post-menopausal women:

  1. Relief of Vasomotor Symptoms:

    • Hot flashes and night sweats (moderate to severe).

  2. Management of Urogenital Symptoms:

    • Vaginal dryness, atrophic vaginitis, and urinary symptoms (local or systemic HRT).

  3. Prevention of Osteoporosis:

    • For women at high risk of fractures who cannot use other treatments.

  4. Premature or Early Menopause:

    • Women with menopause before age 40 or early menopause (ages 40-45).

  5. Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease:

    • For women under 60 or within 10 years of menopause (not recommended solely for cardiovascular protection).

  6. Mood and Sleep Disturbances:

    • Mood swings, anxiety, depression, and sleep disorders related to menopause.

  7. Quality of Life Improvement:

    • When menopausal symptoms significantly affect daily living.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 91-94.

questions.text: When would you do transvaginal sonography in postmenopausal bleeding if the endometrial thickness is?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. 4 mm

  • Many studies have validated the use of transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) as the initial screening method for endometrial cancer.

Cut off value of Endometrial thickness on TVS, for performing Endometrial biopsy in a Post-menopausal women:

  • ACOG: >=4 mm
  • FIGO: >=5 mm

Shaw's textbook also mentions the cut off to be 4mm for endometrial biopsy.

  • ln a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness and this cut-off value is 10 mm in a perimenopausal woman.
  • ln a menopausal woman with vaginal bleeding, even an endometrial thickness of less than 4 mm has the risk of cancer and the entire endometrium should be suspected to a histopathology study.

Though the answer is controversial, most appropriate answer should be chosen as 4 mm> 5 mm.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 435.

questions.text: A 16-year-old woman complained of primary amenorrhea when she went to the gynaecology OPD. She is 150 cm tall, with underdeveloped breasts, and the feminine phenotype. Vagina was discovered during further examination. Normal uterus was seen on ultrasound, however gonads were not seen. Investigations revealed a high FSH level and an XY karyotype. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gonadal dysgenesis

  • XY gonadal dysgenesis, also known as Swyer syndrome, is a type of hypogonadism in a person whose karyotype is 46, XY.
  • Though they typically have normal female external genitalia, the person has functionless gonads, fibrous tissue termed “streak gonads”, and if left untreated, will not experience puberty.
  • Such gonads are typically surgically removed (as they have a significant risk of developing cancer).
  • The typical medical treatment is hormone replacement therapy.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 141-143, 149.

questions.text: A woman of 25 had artificial insemination. Ovary exhibited 8 follicles on USG. The level of serum estradiol was 808 pg/ml. What is the next step in this patient's care?
questions.solution:
Retrieve follicles should be the next best step

  • A mature follicle produces about 150-250 pg/ml of estrogen
  • Here, for 8 follicles , 808 pg/ml estrogen is not high. There is no risk of ovarian hyperstimulation.
  • Hence, we can safely go for Oocyte retrieval.
  • Giving cabergoline, cancelling cycle and not giving hcg are strategies to prevent OHSS which is not required in this case.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 210.

questions.text: A young woman complains of infertility as well as cyclical discomfort and dysmenorrheal symptoms. Which one of the following would be an option for her investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Diagnostic laproscopy

  • Infertility as well as cyclical discomfort and dysmenorrheal symptoms are suggestive of Endometriosis.
  • Laparoscopy is the gold standard in the diagnosis of endometriosis. TVS cannot detect endometriosis. 
  • The diagnosis should be validated by peritoneal and tissue biopsy because corpus luteal hematoma can resemble a chocolate cyst.

Role of laparoscopy: 

• To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
• Locate the site of endometriosis and staging
• To take biopsy.
• To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation and removal


Therefore, Laproscopy is considered a gold standard for diagnosis of endometriosis.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 178-180.

questions.text: What is the most common symptomatic manifestation in menopausal women?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Hot flashes

  • The menopause transition is associated with various symptoms, which can interact to produce morbidity.
 
  • Vasomotor symptoms are the most commonly reported, but vaginal dryness/dyspareunia, sleep difficulties and adverse mood changes have all been shown to worsen as women approach menopause.
     



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 88.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Stein-Leventhal syndrome is not true?

Primary diagnostic features of human PCOS:

Polycystic ovaries

Due to insulin resistance, there is increased fasting insulin levels in PCOD affected women.

choices.text: Multiple corpora lutea cysts in the ovaries

questions.text: Which of the following does not characterize Stein-Leventhal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Multiple corpora lutea cyst in the ovaries.
Stein-Leventhal syndrome is a synonym for PCOS.
 
  • There are small follicles and not corpora lutea cysts
 
  • In polycystic ovary syndrome, one or both ovaries can contain multiple small, immature ovarian follicles that can appear as cysts on medical imaging.
 
  • Normally, ovarian follicles contain egg cells, which are released during ovulation. In polycystic ovary syndrome, abnormal hormone levels prevent follicles from growing and maturing to release egg cells. Instead, these immature follicles accumulate in the ovaries.
 
  • Affected women can have 12 or more of these follicles. The number of these follicles usually decreases with age.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 151, 313, 315.

questions.text: In the hysterosalpingography image given below, where is the most likely location of blockage?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Cornual

Diagnosis: Hysterosalpingogram showing bilateral cornual block.

Correct labelling of Fallopian tube structures on HSG is shown below:  


 
  • Management if tubes are normal: To assess the male factors and ovarian factors for infertility.
Causes of tubal block:
  • Physiological spasm
  • Genital TB
  • Salpingitis
  • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • Benign polyps within the tubal lumen
  • tubal endometriosis and intratubal mucous debris.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 559.

questions.text: On hysterosalpingography, an infertile woman exhibits a bilateral cornual block. Which is the most effective treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Hysteroscopic cannulation
 
  • Bilateral cornual block should be confirmed by laproscopy and hysteroscopy along with chromopertubation and the cornual block should be treated by hysteroscopic cannulation.
  • Out of the given options, hysteroscopic cannulation (option 4) is the most effective treatment for a bilateral cornual blockage. Hysteroscopic cannulation is a minimally invasive procedure in which a small catheter is passed through the cervix and into the fallopian tubes.
  • The catheter is used to clear any blockages in the tubes, allowing the eggs to travel from the ovaries to the uterus for fertilization.

Other options: 
 
  • IVF (in vitro fertilization) (option 1) is an alternative treatment option for infertility.
  • However, it bypasses the fallopian tubes altogether, so it is not effective for women with a bilateral cornual blockage. Salpingectomy (option 2) involves the surgical removal of one or both fallopian tubes. While this may be effective in cases where the tubes are severely damaged or infected, it is not the best option for a bilateral cornual blockage as it removes the chance of natural conception.
  • Salpingostomy (option 3) is a surgical procedure in which a small incision is made in the fallopian tube to remove the blockage. However, this procedure is not as effective as hysteroscopic cannulation, as it has a higher risk of scarring and re-blockage.

Therefore, the correct option is 4. Hysteroscopic Cannulation, as it is a minimally invasive and effective treatment for a bilateral cornual blockage.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 559.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has been shown to almost double the rate of successful pregnancy in case of a patient with a large thick walled Hydrosalpinx who is planned for IVF?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Salpingectomy
 
  • Tubal factors account for approximately 25% of cases of infertility, and the most severe manifestation of tubal disease is hydrosalpinx, accounting for 10-30% of tubal diseases.
 
  • Hydrosalpinx is a distension or dilatation of the fallopian tube in the presence of a distal tubal occlusion, and the most common cause is pelvic inflammatory disease. Hydrosalpinx contain embryotoxic fluid which can kill the zygote. 
 
  • Women with hydrosalpinx have lower implantation and pregnancy rates in assisted reproductive technology (ART), due to a combination of mechanical and chemical factors thought to disrupt the endometrial environment.
 
  • Current guidance is removal of the tube by salpingectomy (preferably laparoscopically) before IVF treatment.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 142, 203.

questions.text: Which amongst these is the age distribution for vulval carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• The age distribution for vulval carcinoma is commonly seen in the following range: 55-85 years
  • Most commonly diagnosed at ages 65 to 74, with the median age at diagnosis of 69 years. Vulval carcinoma can occur at any age, although it is less common in younger women.
