questions.text: A 22-year old female brought by her mother-in- law to the gynecology OPD complaining of inability to conceive for the last six months. She has been cohabiting with her husband without using any contraception. Her BMI is 23 kg/m2. What will be the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Infertility is defined by the failure to achieve a successful pregnancy after 12 months or more of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse or due to an impairment of a person's capacity to reproduce either as an individual or with her/ his partner.
While the definition of infertility has historically included a time-interval of 12 months, investigation and treatment for primary infertility is initiated depending on the age of the patient.

Thus, the next line of management involves reassuring the patient that they should continue efforts to conceive for the next 6 months.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 428.

questions.text: A female undergoing treatment for infertility with IVF was given Inj. HMG, presents with a history of vomiting, nausea, and headache. The USG is shown below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A female receiving human menopausal gonadotropin (LH/ FSH) injection as part of her IVF treatment for infertility is experiencing symptoms of abdominal distension and discomfort including nausea and vomiting with Sonography revealing enlargement of ovaries with multiple cysts.
This is most likely due to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, which is the most serious complication of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation (COH) for assisted reproduction technologies (ART). 

* Extra Edge:
  • OHSS treatment is generally supportive. Paracentesis is typically performed transvaginally as an outpatient and can ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory disttess.
  • Re-accumulation of ascites may prompt additional paracenteses or rarely placement of a percutaneous "pigtail" catheter for continuous drainage.
  • Untreated hypovolemia can lead to renal, hepatic, or pulmonary end-organ failure. Thus, fluid balance must be maintained by replacement with an isotonic fluid such as normal saline.
  • Monitoring of electrolytes is critical. Because of hypercoagulability in these women, prophylaxis for thromboembolism is strongly considered with severe OHSS.
  • During exogenous ovulation, strategies to avoid OHSS induction include decreasing follicular stimulation (a lowered FSH dose), "'coasting" (withholding FSH administration for one or more days prior to the hCG trigger injection), prophylactic treatment with volume expanders, and substitution of hCG for FSH during the final days of ovarian stimulation.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 457.

questions.text: 23y old young girl came to Gyne OPD with Irregular menstrual cycles associated with facial hair. She was overweight. All of the following can be advised, except?
questions.solution:
The Patient's history is suggestive of Polycystic Ovarian Disease (PCOD). Anti Androgens are recommended in PCOD only if patients have no improvement after 6 months with OCPs.
PCOS diagnosing criteria requires 2/3. -Oligo/Amenorrhoea, Hirsutism/acne ,USG suggestive of PCOS-12 or more follicles located peripherally 2-9mm and Enlarged ovaries with volume >10mm3.

 * Extra Edge: 
Polycystic ovarian morphology (PCOM) is one criterion for PCOS diagnosis. Earlier sonographic criteria for PCOM included ~12 small cysts (2 to 9 mm in diameter) or an increased ovarian volume (>10 mL) or both per ovary {Fig. 18-10). More recently, follicle number per ovary (FNPO) threshold values have been raised due to improved sonographic imaging resolution. Namely, an FNPO threshold of>20 follicles and/or ovarian volume > 10mL in either ovary has been adopted by ESHRE and ASRM. The AE-PCOS guidelines use the same ovarian volume value but a higher FNPO threshold of ~25 follicles. Notably, criteria do not apply to women taking combination oral contraceptive pills.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 401.

questions.text: A lady on oral contraceptive pills presented with white discharge per vaginum. It is not associated with itching or foul smell and stains her underwear yellow in color. Examination of the discharge revealed normal lactobacilli and acidic pH. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the vaginal discharge is not associated with itching or foul odor, and the presence of normal lactobacilli along with an acidic pH suggests a diagnosis of increased normal vaginal discharge.

Leucorrhea refers to an excessive amount of normal vaginal discharge, which is characterized by the following:

- Persistent vulval moistness or staining of the undergarments (yellowish-brown when dry) or a need to wear a pad.
- The discharge is non-purulent, non-offensive, non-irritating, and does not cause itching (pruritus).

This normal discharge is regulated by endogenous estrogen levels. An increase in estrogen stimulates the secretory activity of the endocervical glands, and the superficial vaginal epithelium becomes rich in glycogen. As a result, normal vaginal secretion is expected to increase in conditions where estrogen levels are elevated, such as:

- Puberty: Elevated estrogen levels lead to increased secretions.
- Menstrual cycle: Secretions peak around ovulation due to a rise in estrogen and increase before menstruation due to pelvic congestion.
- Pregnancy: Increased estrogen and vascularity cause an increase in vaginal secretions.
- Sexual excitement: Bartholin‘s glands produce abundant secretions.

Differential Diagnosis:

- Vaginal candidiasis: Typically presents with itching and a thick, white, "cottage cheese"-like discharge. The absence of itching in this case makes candidiasis less likely.
- Bacterial vaginosis: Characterized by a thin, gray, and foul-smelling discharge. Since this patient‘s discharge does not have a foul smell, bacterial vaginosis is ruled out.
- Chlamydial infection: While chlamydia can cause abnormal vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually not associated with yellow staining of underwear, and many individuals remain asymptomatic.

Therefore, the most probable diagnosis is A. Increased normal vaginal discharge.

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynaecology, 6th edition, Page no 551-552 .

choices.text: Weight loss + Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins
Weight loss + Metformin + Induction of Ovulation with clomiphene
Weight loss + folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with 6 years of infertility, has a BMI of 33 and facial hair. Investigations reveal she has (PCOS) and spills from bilateral tubes. She and her husband are trying to conceive, what would be the best plan of management for this lady?
questions.solution:
.**Clinical Management of Obese PCOS Patients**

In managing obese patients with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), the primary approach involves:

1. **Weight Loss and Folic Acid Supplementation**: Initiate with weight reduction, as even a modest weight loss (5% of body weight) can help restore ovulatory cycles in some cases. Folic acid is also recommended to prevent neural tube defects before conception.

2. **Spontaneous Ovulation Induction**: After addressing weight loss and folic acid supplementation, attempt spontaneous ovulation induction. This is because weight loss can improve ovulatory function in many cases.


3. **Induction of Ovulation**: If spontaneous induction fails, move to pharmacological induction of ovulation.

**Overview of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)**

PCOS is a multisystem disorder prevalent among women of reproductive age, involving metabolic and endocrine dysfunctions. Contributing factors include lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemia.

**Clinical Features of PCOS:**
- **Menstrual Abnormalities**: Oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea.
- **Hyperandrogenism**: Symptoms such as hirsutism, acne, and alopecia.
- **Insulin Resistance**: Indicated by acanthosis nigricans.
- **Infertility**: Difficulty in conceiving.

**Diagnosis of PCOS:**

The Rotterdam criteria are used for diagnosis. At least two of the following three components must be present:
1. **Menstrual Abnormalities**: Oligo/amenorrhea, anovulation, infertility.
2. **Hyperandrogenism**: Hirsutism or acne.
3. **Ultrasound Findings**:

- Enlarged ovaries with a volume greater than 10 mL.
- Presence of 12 or more small follicles (2-9 mm in diameter) arranged peripherally.

**Investigations:**

1. **Hormonal Studies**: To assess hormonal imbalances.
2. **Ultrasound**: Confirms the diagnosis of PCOS by showing enlarged ovaries with multiple peripheral follicles and helps rule out other conditions like ovarian tumors or endometrial hyperplasia.
3. **Laparoscopy**: In therapeutic cases, may reveal bilateral enlarged ovarian cysts.

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314-317 .

questions.text:
In which of the following statementswill you suspect primary amenorrhea
A. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age
B. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche
C. High levels of TSH and short stature
D. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age
questions.solution:
**Primary Amenorrhea** is defined as the absence of menstruation by age 15 or within 3 years of breast development (thelarche). It can also be suspected if menstruation has not started by age 14 and there are signs of hirsutism, excessive exercise, or an eating disorder. According to the conventional definition, primary amenorrhea is the failure to initiate menstruation by age 16 or the absence of secondary sexual characteristics by age 13.

**Secondary Amenorrhea** refers to the absence of menstruation for 3 months or more in a female who previously had regular menstrual cycles.

**Causes of Primary Amenorrhea:**

1. **Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism**: Includes hypothalamic and pituitary dysfunction.
- Kallmann‘s syndrome
- CNS tumors (e.g., craniopharyngioma)
- Delayed puberty

2. **Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism**: Includes primary ovarian failure and resistant ovarian failure.
- 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency

3. **Chromosomal Abnormalities**:
- Turner‘s syndrome (45, X)
- Pure gonadal dysgenesis (46, XX or 46, XY)
- Androgen insensitivity syndrome (46, XY)

4. **Developmental Defects of the Genital Tract**:
- Imperforate hymen
- Transverse vaginal septum
- Vaginal or cervical atresia
- Absent uterus in Mullerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome)

5. **Other Causes**:
- Uterine synechiae (congenital)
- Adrenogenital syndrome
- Cretinism
- Juvenile diabetes
- Malnutrition
-Weight loss
-Anaemia
-Tuberculosis

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 141,142 .

questions.text: Ina 46XY female complete gonadal dysgenesis was noted. Complete gonadal dysgenesis is caused by what in the SRY gene?
questions.solution:
A point mutation in the SRY gene is commonly linked to complete gonadal dysgenesis, though some sources argue that SRY deletion is more frequently associated. Nonetheless, idiopathic causes account for approximately 85% of cases.

Pure gonadal dysgenesis may result from a point mutation in the SRY gene, SRY deletion, or mutations in other genes involved in testis determination such as DAX1, SF-1, or CBX2. This condition leads to underdeveloped dysgenetic gonads that do not produce androgens or AMH, resulting in a prepubertal female phenotype and a normal Mullerian system due to the absence of AMH.

Typically, individuals present with a lack of secondary sexual characteristics at puberty and amenorrhea. Diagnostic tests reveal absent estrogen production, elevated FSH levels (>40 miU/mL), and low estradiol levels (<25 pg/mL).

Women with streak ovaries are infertile but can conceive with oocyte donation. They require cyclic estrogen and progestogen treatment to encourage feminization, develop secondary sexual characteristics, and prevent osteoporosis.

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 144.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea and signs of virilization. She has prepubertal development of breasts and pubic hair and is tanner stage 2. She has a blind-ended vagina and clitoromegaly. She has normal male testosterone levels. Her genotype is 46XY. What ts the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. This condition is characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase, which converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent form of the male sex hormone. Testosterone is crucial for the development of male internal genitalia, while DHT is essential for the development of male external genitalia.

In individuals with 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, the conversion of testosterone to DHT is impaired. Consequently, while testosterone levels are normal and male internal genitalia (Wolffian ducts) develop appropriately, the external genitalia appear female at birth due to low DHT levels. As these individuals approach puberty, they may experience virilization driven by increased testosterone, leading to changes such as clitoromegaly. However, there is typically no breast development due to the absence of estrogen, which results from the lack of DHT conversion. Pubic hair growth is also minimal since its development depends on both testosterone and DHT.

Diagnosis can be confirmed by noting an elevated ratio of testosterone to DHT after hCG administration.

Management options for a child diagnosed with 5 alpha-reductase deficiency who wishes to be raised as female include:
- Removal of the testes before puberty to prevent virilization.
- Initiation of estrogen therapy to induce and maintain feminization, starting at the usual age of puberty or immediately following gonadectomy if performed in adulthood.

Other differential diagnoses include:

- 17 alpha-Hydroxylase Deficiency: This condition results in decreased testosterone production by the adrenal glands but normal testosterone production from the testes. Depending on the balance of testosterone and DHT, the external genitalia may appear female or ambiguous. Additionally, this deficiency leads to reduced levels of 17-OH progesterone and cortisol, causing increased ACTH levels, elevated aldosterone, hypertension, and hypokalemia.

- Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: An X-linked recessive disorder characterized by the absence or dysfunction of androgen receptors, leading to a lack of response to testosterone. Patients typically have elevated serum testosterone levels but no signs of virilization. Breast development occurs normally as testosterone is converted to estrogen.


- Swyer Syndrome: This condition arises from a mutation in the SRY gene on the Y chromosome, resulting in dysgenetic gonads and the absence of AMH and testosterone production. As a result, individuals develop female internal and external genitalia and exhibit no signs of virilization.
 

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th edition, Page no 375-376,413-414 .

questions.text: A girl presented with complaints of irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth.USG revealed multiple ovarian follicles. Which of the following would be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
String of pearls appearance of ovaries in PCOS 


 

This girl has polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which explains her irregular periods, acne, hirsutism, and multiple ovarian follicles on ultrasound.

In PCOS, the ovaries produce excess androgens, leading to elevated serum testosterone, which causes the acne and increased facial hair.

Other hormones:

  • FSH is usually normal or low, not increased.

  • LH is often elevated, giving an increased LH/FSH ratio.

  • Sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) is typically decreased, not increased.

Therefore, the hormone that would be increased in this patient is serum testosterone.



Reference:Shaws textbook of gynaecology 17th edition page no 314-317

choices.text: Each follicle should be 2 to 9 mm in size
At least 10 follicles should be present for diagnosis
The ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on OCPs

questions.text: Which of the following options is not correct regarding the USG criteria for PCOD?
questions.solution:
The USG (ultrasound) criteria for diagnosing polycystic ovary morphology (PCOM) are based on the Rotterdam Criteria (2003) and the latest ESHRE/ASRM (2023) updates.

According to these guidelines:

Correct Criteria for PCOM on Ultrasound:

  1. Follicle size:

    • Each follicle should be 2 to 9 mm in diameter
      This is true and a key component of the follicular count criterion.

  2. Follicle number per ovary (FNPO):

    • Earlier (2003 Rotterdam): ≥ 12 follicles per ovary

    • Updated (2018-2023 ESHRE/ASRM using high-resolution probes):
      ≥ 20 follicles per ovary (on either ovary)
      So, the statement "At least 10 follicles" is incorrect and outdated.

  3. Ovarian volume:

    • 10 mL is diagnostic of PCOM (in absence of dominant follicle or corpus luteum)
      This is correct.

  4. Effect of OCPs:

    • OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills) can suppress follicular development

    • Hence, morphological criteria (USG findings) are not reliable in women who are on OCPs
      So, this statement is correct.



Reference: Williams gynaecology 3rd edition page no 39

questions.text:
A woman who had an abdominal lump was examined. After surgery, it was discovered that she had smooth-surfaced bilateral ovarian tumors.
On microscopy, they showed signet-ring-shaped mucin-secreting cells. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Krukenberg tumor

  • Signet-ring-shaped mucin-secreting cells are characteristic of Krukenberg tumor. 
  • The tumor is usually bilateral, solid with smooth surfaces and usually maintaining the shape of the ovary. The typically form rounded or reniform, firm white masses. Sometimes they are bosselated and may attain a big size. There is no tendency of adhesion (i.e. capsule remains intact).
  • The cut surfaces usually look yellow or white in color with cystic space at places due to degeneration. Cut surface has waxy consistency.
  • Histologically, the stroma is highly cellular. The mucin within epithelial cells compresses the nuclei to one pole, producing ‘signet ring’ appearance. The scattered ‘signet ring’ looking cells are characteristic of Krukenberg tumor.
  • In most patients with Krukenberg’s tumors, the prognosis is poor. Median survival being less than a year. Rarely, no primary site can be identified and the Krukenberg’s tumor may be a primary tumor.





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 464, 465.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child appears with an umbilical and hypogastric lump in the lower abdomen. Upon examination, it is found to be mobile and cystic, and the examiner is unable to get their fingers between the mass and the pelvic bone. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Ovarian cyst

Upon examination, the mass was found to be mobile and cystic, and the examiner was unable to get their fingers between the mass and the pelvic bone. This indicates pelvic origin of the mass which is most likely to be an ovarian cyst.

questions.text: Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia was diagnosed in a postmenopausal woman after biopsy.What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Hysterectomy
 
  • Postmenopausal female with biopsy report as endometrial hyperplasia with atypia is having increased risk of malignancy. So the next line of management is hysterectomy.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia carries a reasonably high risk of progression to endometrial cancer if not adequately treated.
  • Simple hyperplasia without cytologic atypia carries a less than 1% chance of progression to cancer, whereas complex hyperplasia without atypia has 2% to 3% chance of progression to cancer. Thus these two entities are usually treated medically using progesterone therapy.
  • With cytologic atypia, simple hyperplasia and complex hyperplasia carry an 8% and 27% to 28% chance of progression to cancer, respectively.
  • With cytologic atypia, hysterectomy is usually the treatment of choice unless future fertility is still desired
  • In case of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, Progesterone is given. 



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 703.
Berek and Novak's Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 2363, 2364.

questions.text: Except for__________, all are possible indicators of choriocarcinoma after hydatidiform mole:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. More number of theca lutein cysts
 
  • Increased number of theca lutein cyst is NOT an indicator of Choriocarcinoma. Increased size or persistence of theca lutein cysts indicate Choriocarcinoma.
  • Suburethral nodules are seen in metastasis of choriocarcinoma.

Risk factors for malignant conversion for Hydatidiform mole are:
  1. Age <20 years or >= 40 years
  2. Parity >=3
  3. Previous history of Molar pregnancy
  4. Size of uterus >20 wks POG
  5. Serum beta-hCG >1,00,000 IU/ml
  6. Persistence or increased size of Theca lutein cysts

Indicators of malignant change are:
  • Increased vascularity
  • Suburethral nodules
  • Uterine (Myometrial) nodules



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 241, 242.
Berek and Novak's Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 2774.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady arrives with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visual mass seen in cervix on speculum examination. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Targeted biopsy

The greatest fear for patients experiencing postcoital bleeding and providers taking care of these patients is the concern for underlying malignancy. Postcoital bleeding is the presenting complaint in 11% of women with cervical cancer. Mass is seen which is pathological hence targeted biopsy should be done. 

Common causes of postcoital bleeding:

  •      Cervical polyps
  •      Cervical ectropion
      2.  Infection

I Tumor confined to ovaries or fallopian tube(s)
IA Tumor limited to 1 ovary (capsule intact) or fallopian tube; no tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface; no malignant cells in the ascites or peritoneal washings
IB Tumor limited to both ovaries (capsules intact) or fallopian tubes; no tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface; no malignant cells in the ascites or peritoneal washings
IC Tumor limited to 1 or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, with any of the following
IC1 Surgical spill
IC2 Capsule ruptured before surgery or tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface
IC3 Malignants cells in the ascites or peritoneal washings
II Tumor involves 1 or both ovaries or fallopian tubes with pelvic extension (below pelvic brim) or peritoneal cancer
IIA Extension and/or implants on uterus and/or fallopian tubes and/or ovaries
IIB Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
III Tumor involves 1 or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, or peritoneal cancer, with cytologically or histologically confirmed spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis and/or metastasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes
IIIA Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only (cytologically or histologically proven)
IIIA1(i) Metastasis up to 10 mm in greatest dimension
IIIA1(i) Metastasis more than 10 mm in greatest dimension
IIIA2 Microscopic extrapelvic (above the pelvic brim) peritoneal involvement with or without positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes
IIIB Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis up to 2 cm in greatest dimension, with or without metastasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes
IIIC Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis more than 2 cm in greatest dimension, with or without metasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes (includes extension of tumor to capsule of liver and spleen without parenchymal involvement of either organ)

questions.text: What is included in the treatment of Ca cervix IIIB?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Intracavity Brachytherapy followed by External Beam Radiotherapy

Stage-Based Management of Localized Cervical Cancer: 
 
Stage Treatment
Early disease Stage IA1 Surgery, total hysterectomy, radical hysterectomy and conization
Stage IA2, IB, or IIA Combined external beam radiation with brachytherapy and radical hysterectomy with bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy for patients with stage IB or IIA disease 

Radical vaginal trachelectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection is appropriate for fertility preservation in women with stage IA2 disease and those with stage IB1 disease whose lesions are \(\leq 2\) cm 

Cisplatin-based chemotherapy with radiation for stage IA-IIA patients who have specific high-risk features (Positive lymph nodes, surgical margins, and/or parametria)
Advanced disease Stage IIB, III, or IVA Cisplatin-based chemotherapy with radiation
Metastatic disease Stage IVB and recurrent cancer Cisplatin on a palliative basis, radiation therapy for control of bleeding and pain, and systemic chemotherapy for disseminated disease including cisplatin, paclitaxel, carboplatin docetaxel, topotecan, and bevacizumab



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 427, 429.

questions.text: An operation was performed on a patient who had an adnexal mass, and the subsequent tumour was excised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Mature teratoma
 
  • The image shows hair with debacle material suggestive of a Dermoid cyst ( mature teratoma)
  • It is a type of germ cell tumor that is usually made up of several different types of tissue, such as hair, muscle, and bone.

MATURE CYSTIC TERATOMA (DERMOID CYSTS): 

• Most common germ cell neoplasm
• Well-differentiated derivations from at least two of the three germ cell layers
• Younger age group (mean patient age, 30 years)
• Asymptomatic
• Grow slowly
• Bilateral in about 10% of cases



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 445, 446.

Population Recommended screening method Comments
Women younger than 21 years No screening -

-

Women vaccinated against HPV Follow age-specific recommendations (same as unvaccinated women) -

questions.text: Hysteroscopic myomectomy scores over open myomectomy in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Less recurrence 

  • In minimally invasive surgery, bleeding and post operative pain is less and ambulation is early.
  • However, recurrence and pregnancy rates are same in minimally invasive vs open method 


Advantages of Hysteroscopic myomectomy: 

  • Rapid postoperative recovery
  • Less postoperative pain and reduced need of postoperative analgesia
  • Excellent visualization of organs and tissues
  • Shorter hospital stay and reduced concomitant cost
  • Quicker resumption of day-to-day activity
  • Less adhesion formation
  • Minimal abdominal scars (cosmetic value)
  • Reduced blood loss
  • No large incisions
  • Less risk of incisional hernia
  • Increased patient’s satisfaction.
  • Less morbidity than laparotomy



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 512, 523.

questions.text: Which of the following are not risk factors for cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Low parity.
Multiparty is a risk factor for cancer cervix not less parity.
As during pregnancy there is exstrophy of squamo-columnar junction leading to increased vulnerability to HPV virus which is the causative agent of Ca Cervix. 
 

Cervical Cancer Risk Factors: 
  • Human papillomavirus infection
  • First intercourse at an early age
  • Multiple sex partners
  • Lack of regular Pap tests
  • History of sexually transmitted infections 
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Multiparity
  • Immunodeficiency 
  • Long-term oral contraception use (>5 years)
  • Smoking
  • Low socioeconomic status
  • Poor access to health care 



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 408.

questions.text: What is the radiation dose for early and locally advanced carcinoma of the cervix at point A during brachytherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 70-75 Gray and 75-80 Gray
 
  • Point A was defined as a point 2 cm above the cervical os and 2 cm apart from os on the line perpendicular to uterine axis. It is a hypothetical point representing the crossover of the ureter and uterine artery, located in the paracervical triangle, and is considered as a critical point for radiation tolerance.
  • On the other hand, point B, which was designated as 5 cm from the midline at the level of point A, represented the dose delivered to the pelvic lymph node.
  • It has been calculated that point A gets about 7000–8000 cGy and point B 2000 cGy. Taking into consideration that cancerolytic dose is approximately 7000–7500 cGy, the rest of the dose at point B is supplemented by external beam irradiation of 4000 cGy spreading over another three weeks.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 497.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 294.

questions.text: Which of the following gynaecological primary most frequently causes intraocular metastasis in females?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Breast
 
  • Breast Ocular metastasis can represent the initial manifestation of breast carcinoma, with up to 26% of orbital breast metastases presenting before the discovery of the primary tumor.
  • The most common primary sites of metastatic carcinoma to the orbit are the breast, lung, prostate, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney.
  • For breast carcinoma, the interval from primary diagnosis to orbital metastasis is 3–5 years.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1316.

choices.text: Observation and follow-up for cyst after 2–3 months

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is experiencing some lower abdominal ache. She previously underwent two normal full-term deliveries. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks back. A palpable lump in the adnexa is discovered during a pelvic exam. You discover a 5 cm ovarian cyst on the USG pelvis. What ought you do next?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Observation and follow-up for cyst after 2–3 months.
Since her last period was 3 weeks ago, it could be a luteal cyst which is large and hence symptomatic. The pain could be most likely due to ovulation.

Management of Simple cyst: 
 
  • A simple cyst <7 cm, unilocular, echo free without solid areas or papillary projections, with normal serum cancer antigen (CA 125) should be followed up with repeat ultrasound (endovaginal) in 3–6 months time.
  • COCs suppresses the levels of gonadotropins. Thereby COCs reduces the stimulatory effects on the ovaries and the cysts. Low vascular resistance on color flow Doppler study suggests malignancy whereas high resistance usually suggests normal or benign disease. A cyst in a perimenopausal or postmenopausal women should be removed when CA 125 is abnormal (>35 IU/mL) or the cyst is persistently large (>10 cm).
  • Removal (cystectomy) may be done by laparotomy or laparoscopy.
Adnexal Mass of ovary in  reproductive age-
3-5cm- wait and watch
5-7 cm- Follow up with USG
>= 7cm- Surgery 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 452-457.

The technique of fimbriectomy as described by Kroener employs the ligation of the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures and then division and removal of the infundibulum of the tube

questions.text: In an endoscopic examination of the uterus, the woman who had complained of AUB had the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Leiomyoma
This picture represents a case of multiple uterine fibroids.

Gross/Endoscopic appearance of Fibroid: 
 
  • The uterus is enlarged; the shape is distorted by multiple nodular growth of varying sizes. Occasionally, there may be uniform enlargement of the uterus by a single fibroid. The feel is firm.
  • Cut surface of the tumor is smooth and whitish. The cut section, in the absence of degenerative changes, shows features of whorled appearance and trabeculation. These are due to the intermingling of fibrous tissues with the muscle bundles.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 156, 157.

questions.text: Which of the following is most frequently linked to cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. HPV 16.
While all options are high risk types of HPV associated with cervical cancer, HPV 16 is most commonly associated.

Most human papillomavirus infection is harmless and clears spontaneously but persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (especially type 16) can cause cancer of the cervix, vulva, vagina, anus, penis, and oropharynx.

 HPV types: 
 
High risk 16, 18, 31, 33,35, 39, 45, 51, 52,
56, 58, 59, 68, 73, 82
Probable high risk 25, 53, 56
Low risk 6, 11, 40,42, 43,44, 54,
61, 70, 72, 81

  4. Size of uterus >20 wks POG
  5. Serum beta-hCG >1,00,000 IU/ml or plateau in beta-hCG levels
  6. Persistence or increased size of Theca lutein cysts
Indicators of malignant change are:
  • Increased vascularity

questions.text: All risk factors point to a full hydatidiform mole developing into choriocarcinoma, except:
questions.solution:
Suburethral nodule is an indicator/sign of metastasis of choriocarcinoma. Rest all 3 has increased risk of progression of mole into choriocarcinoma.

Risk factors for malignant conversion for Hydatidiform mole are:
  1. Age <20 years or >= 40 years
  2. Parity >=3
  3. Previous history of Molar pregnancy
  4. Size of uterus >20 wks POG
  5. Serum beta-hCG >1,00,000 IU/ml or plateau in beta-hCG levels
  6. Persistence or increased size of Theca lutein cysts
Indicators of malignant change are:
  • Increased vascularity
  • Suburethral nodules
  • Uterine (Myometrial) nodules

  • The given history is suggestive of Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome.
  • It is the most common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age group. Clinical features include irregular or absence menstrual cycle, excessive facial and body hair, acne, infertility and acanthosis nigricans.



 


Management:
—Weight Loss
—Metformin : To deal with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome
—OCPs : To regularise menstrual cycles, to treat hirsutism
—Infertility-
First Line : Letrozole (DOC), Clomiphene Citrate, Bromocriptine
Second Line : Human menopausal gonadotropin, Laparoscopic Ovarian drilling
Third Line : Synthetic GnRH.

A 28-year-old infertile woman comes to you. questions.text: Which is the component that does NOT belong to Papanicolaou stain?
questions.solution:
Eosin B is NOT a component of Papanicolaou stain

Staining steps:

  1. Hematoxylin: Applied first to stain the nuclei.
  2. Orange G (OG-6): Applied next to stain keratinized cells.
  3. Eosin azure (EA): Applied to stain the cytoplasm and various cell components, giving differential colors to different cell types.

Light green SF is a sub-component of EA

Purpose of each component:

  • Hematoxylin: Provides contrast for nuclear features, which is critical for identifying abnormal or malignant cells based on nuclear morphology.
  • OG-6 (Orange G): Highlights keratinized cells, aiding in distinguishing different layers of squamous cells.
  • EA (Eosin Azure): Differentiates various types of epithelial cells based on their cytoplasmic staining properties, allowing for the identification of immature, intermediate, and mature squamous cells.




Reference: Bancroft's Theory and Practice of Histological Techniques, 8th edition, Page no 132.

questions.text: Which fixative is used in a PAP smear?
questions.solution:
The fixative used is 95% ethyl alcohol+ 5% ether
 

The fixative commonly used in a Pap smear is 95% ethanol or a similar alcohol-based solution. The purpose of the fixative is to preserve the cells collected from the cervix, preventing them from drying out or undergoing further changes before staining.

Types of fixative used:

  1. 95% Ethanol:
    • Most commonly used.
    • Ensures rapid fixation and good preservation of cellular details.
  2. Alcohol-based Fixatives:
    • May contain ethanol, methanol, or isopropanol.
    • Commercially available in spray forms, often used immediately after sample collection to prevent air-drying of cells.
  3. Carbowax (Alcohol-based Fixative with Polyethylene Glycol):
    • Used in spray fixatives to create a coating over the cells.
    • Prevents air-drying and helps preserve the sample until it can be stained.
Importance of proper fixation: 
 
  • Prevents Air-Drying: Cells that air-dry can become distorted, which makes microscopic evaluation difficult.
  • Preserves Morphology: Fixatives maintain the structure of both the nucleus and cytoplasm, which is essential for accurate diagnosis.
Fixative used in liquid based cytology is methanol. 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text:

A. Vaginal retraction
B. Scrape cervix

Procedure of PAP smear collection:
 
Undress completely only from the waist down
                                      \(\downarrow\)
Lie down on your back on an exam table with knees bent (lithotomy position). Heels rest in supports called stirrups
                                      \(\downarrow\)
Insert speculum into vagina. The speculum hold the walls of your vagina apart so that doctor can easily see cervix
                                      \(\downarrow\)
Take samples of your cervical cells using a soft brush and a flat scarping device called a spatula.
                                       \(\downarrow\)
Make thin smear and send it to pathology lab

Fix in 95% ethyl alcohol

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the HPE given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Malignant teratoma
 
  • Malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary composed of cells from the three germ layers, containing variable amounts of mature and immature tissue
  • Affects mostly young females < 20 years old
  • Grossly solid ovarian tumor mass with necrosis and hemorrhage on cut sections
  • Grading is performed based on the amount of immature neuroepithelium
  • Can have associated nodal or peritoneal gliomatosis (presence of mature neural tissue), which increases risk of recurrence
  • Grading and stage are the most important factors for prognosis, greatly improved after chemotherapy
Histopathological findings in Malignant Teratoma:
 
  • Immature Tissue Elements: Presence of primitive neuroectodermal tissue (neuroblasts, rosettes) and immature mesenchymal or epithelial tissue.
  • Malignant Components: Somatic malignancies such as squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, or sarcomas within the teratoma.
  • High-Grade Features: Cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic activity.
  • Necrosis and Hemorrhage: Common in malignant areas, reflecting the aggressive nature of the tumor.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 461.

choices.text: Partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman came in with a 2x3 cm labia majora ulcer that had been present for six months without healing and no palpable lymphadenopathy. Squamous cell cancer is evident after biopsy. The required treatment consists of:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral LN dissection
 
  • According to recent FIGO guidelines, a lesion measuring 2 cm x 3 cm with no palpable lymph nodes is classified as stage 1B vulvar cancer.
  • The recommended management for stage 1B includes a radical partial vulvectomy for the primary tumor. Although lymph nodes may appear normal upon palpation, they can still be affected, so a Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB) or inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is advised.
  • If the vulvar lesion is more than 2 cm from the midline and located laterally, an ipsilateral lymph node dissection is performed. However, if the lesion is within 2 cm of the midline, a bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is recommended.
  • In this case, the optimal management approach is partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection, given the lesion's characteristics and location.

 



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 680, 682, 684.

questions.text: Which of the following is least common in uterine fibroid?
questions.solution:
Sarcomatous change is least seen in uterine fibroid. Because risk of fibroid uterus developing from sarcoma is 0.5% and is the least common secondary change.
 

Here’s a brief summary of the common types of fibroid degeneration:

  1. Hyaline Degeneration:

    • Most common type (up to 60% of cases).
    • Fibroid tissue becomes glassy and homogeneous due to protein deposition.

  2. Cystic Degeneration:

    • Results from further progression of hyaline degeneration.
    • Leads to the formation of fluid-filled cystic spaces within the fibroid.

  3. Red (Carneous) Degeneration:

    • Typically occurs during pregnancy.
    • Caused by venous thrombosis and hemorrhage within the fibroid, leading to acute pain and red discoloration of the tissue.
    • C/f- abdominal pain, increased ESR, leukocytes and fever. 
    • Differential diagnosis is torsion of fibroid- severe abdominal pain but no fever or leukocytosis. 

  4. Calcific Degeneration:

    • Occurs in older women.
    • Calcium deposits form within the fibroid, making it hard and gritty.

  5. Fatty Degeneration:

    • Rare.
    • Involves the accumulation of fat within fibroid cells.

  6. Sarcomatous Degeneration:

    • Extremely rare (<1% of cases).
    • Represents malignant transformation into leiomyosarcoma.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 160.

questions.text: Which type of FIGO fibroid classification is a submucosal fibroid assigned to if it protrudes less than 50% into the uterine cavity?
questions.solution:
• The FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) fibroid classification system is used to describe the location of uterine fibroids. It has four types, and submucosal fibroids are assigned to Type 0 or Type 1, depending on their degree of protrusion into the uterine cavity.
 

  • Type 0: A pedunculated submucosal fibroid entirely within the endometrial cavity, with no myometrial involvement.

  • Type 1: A submucosal fibroid with ≥50% of its volume in the endometrial cavity and <50% within the myometrium.

  • Type 2: A submucosal fibroid with <50% of its volume in the endometrial cavity and ≥50% within the myometrium.

  • Type 3: A fibroid completely within the myometrium but abutting the endometrium without extending into the endometrial cavity.

  • Type 4: A fibroid entirely within the myometrium, not in contact with the endometrium or serosa.

  • Type 5: A subserosal fibroid with ≥50% of its volume within the myometrium and <50% extending outside the uterine serosa.

  • Type 6: A subserosal fibroid with <50% of its volume within the myometrium and ≥50% extending outside the uterine serosa.

  • Type 7: A pedunculated subserosal fibroid, attached to the uterus by a stalk.

  • Type 8: A fibroid located in an ectopic position (e.g., in the cervix, broad ligament, or parasitic fibroids not involving the myometrium)




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 129.

DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 226.

questions.text: Which of these are the most common ovarian tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Epithelial tumors
  • Epithelial tumors are the most common type of ovarian tumors, accounting for approximately 80-90% of all ovarian tumors.
  • These tumors arise from the surface layer of the ovary, which is composed of epithelial cells.
  • Epithelial tumors are further classified into different subtypes based on their histology, such as serous, mucinous, endometrioid, and clear cell tumors.
 
  • Germ cell tumors are rare tumors that arise from the germ cells of the ovary and account for only 5% of all ovarian tumors. These tumors are more common in younger women and are usually benign. However, some malignant germ cell tumors can also occur.
 
  • Sex cord-stromal tumors and fibrous stromal tumors are also rare types of ovarian tumors that arise from the supporting tissue of the ovary. Sex cord-stromal tumors account for only 1% of all ovarian tumors and can produce hormones such as estrogen and testosterone.
 
  • Fibrous stromal tumors, also known as fibromas, are benign tumors that arise from the connective tissue of the ovary.

questions.text: What is the most common signs /symptom of cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. vaginal bleeding

Vaginal bleeding is the most common symptom of cervical cancer.

Signs and symptoms of cervical cancer include:

1. Vaginal bleeding: This is the most common sign of cervical cancer. It may occur between periods, after sexual intercourse, or after menopause. The bleeding may be light or heavy, and it may have a foul odor.

2. Pain: Pain in the pelvis, lower back, or legs may occur if the cancer has spread to nearby tissues and organs.

3. Hematuria: Hematuria, or blood in the urine, is not a common symptom of cervical cancer. It may occur if the cancer has spread to the bladder or kidneys.

4. Vaginal discharge: Vaginal discharge that is watery, bloody, or foul-smelling may occur if the cancer has spread to nearby tissues.
Therefore, option 1, vaginal bleeding, is the correct option as it is the most common sign of cervical cancer.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 411.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 289.

Triad

          • VEGF increasing vascular permeability
          • Tumor compressing lymphatics, preventing drainage (tumors 10+cm)

• Pleural effusion more common & mistaken for cirrhosis c/b Hepatic Hydrothorax
      • Usually exudative, but can be transudative
      • SAAG <0.5 (non-portal HTN)

• Resolution after removal of the tumor

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady with primary gastric cancer presents with a big complicated ovarian tumor and ascites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Krukenberg tumor 

  • Krukenburg tumor is a metastatic malignancy of the ovary characterized by mucin-rich signet-ring adenocarcinoma that primarily arises from a gastrointestinal site in most cases and less commonly from other sites.
  • The tumor spreads by retrograde lymphatic spread. 
  • Often these tumors are bilateral (over 80%), given their metastatic nature.

questions.text: Which age group does not exhibit Paget's disease of the breast?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Childhood 

  • Paget’s disease of the nipple, also known as Paget’s disease of the breast, is a rare condition associated with breast cancer.
  • It causes eczema-like changes to the skin of the nipple and the area of darker skin surrounding the nipple (areola).
  • t’s usually a sign of underlying breast cancer in the tissue behind the nipple.

Since the breast tissues are not well developed in childhood, this is rarely found in childhood age group.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 813, 852.

questions.text: Origin of Carcinoma Cervix mostly corresponds to which common site -
questions.solution:
Option 2 is correct - New Squamocolumnar junction.
 
  • Carcinoma of the cervix is a type of cancer that arises from the cells of the cervix.
  • The cervix is the lower part of the uterus that opens into the vagina. 
  • The squamocolumnar junction (SCJ) is the area where the squamous cells of the ectocervix (outer part of the cervix) meet the columnar cells of the endocervix (inner part of the cervix).
  • This junction is a common site for the development of precancerous and cancerous lesions.
  • However, the origin of carcinoma cervix mostly corresponds to the new squamocolumnar junction (NSCJ), which is formed after menarche (onset of menstruation) and moves towards the external os (opening of the cervix) with age.
  • The NSCJ is the site where the transformation zone (TZ) is located, which is the area where most cervical cancers arise.
Therefore, option 2 - New Squamocolumnar junction - is the correct answer.





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 409.

questions.text: Sarcoma Botryoides mostly commonly arises from:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Vagina
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a malignant tumor which arises from embryonic muscle cells.
  • It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in childhood and young adulthood, and accounts for 4 to 6% of all malignancies in this age group.
  • This tumor presents as a submucosal lesion giving the typical “grape-like” appearance and is usually seen in female infants and young children.
  • Sarcoma botryoides is usually reported as a vaginal tumor in the female reproductive tract of infants.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 480.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 283.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Coffee Bean Nuclei seen on HPE ?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Brenner Tumor

Tumor with coffee bean shaped nuclei:

1. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
2. Granulosa cell tumor
3. Brenner tumor
4. Langergan cell histiocytosis
5. Invasive ductal carcinoma of pancreas
6. Chondroblastoma


Coffee Bean Nuclei in Brenners tumor
Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 444.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1022.
