questions.text: A 55-year-old woman arrives with breathing difficulties, abdominal distension, bleeding, and pelvic pain. A clinical examination indicates ascites-like symptoms and high CA-125 values. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. CA ovary

Epithelial ovarian cancer presents as a wide variety of vague and nonspecific symptoms, including:
  • bloating, abdominal distension or discomfort
  • pressure effects on the bladder and rectum
  • constipation
  • vaginal bleeding
  • indigestion and acid reflux
  • shortness of breath
  • tiredness
  • weight loss
  • early satiety

Raised CA-125 is a marker of ovarian cancer.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 465.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for Vulvar cancer?
questions.solution:
The risk factors for vulvar cancer include smoking, human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, vulvar dystrophy, and lichen sclerosus.
  • Vulval hamartomas are not considered a risk factor for vulvar cancer.

Risk factors for Vulval CA:
 
  1. Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection
  2. Smoking
  3. Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)
  4. Vulvar dystrophies (e.g., lichen sclerosus)
  5. Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV, immunosuppressive drugs)
  6. Advanced age
  7. Chronic vulvar inflammation or irritation
  8. History of cervical, vaginal, or anal cancer
  9. Obesity
  10. Diabetes
  11. Early sexual activity
  12. Multiple sexual partners



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition Page no 473, 475.

questions.text: Most common age group for vulvar cancer is ?
questions.solution:
• The incidence of vulvar cancer increases with age, and it is most commonly diagnosed in women over the age of 60.
  • Vulvar cancer is most common in postmenopausal women, with the peak incidence occurring in the 6th to 8th decades of life.
 
  • However, HPV-associated vulvar cancers can occur in younger women (30–50 years), but these are less common compared to the overall incidence in older age groups.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition Page no 475-477.

questions.text: An in-utero exposure to Diethyl stilbestrol (DES) can lead to which type of carcinoma in the daughter?
questions.solution:
Exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during fetal development can lead to clear cell carcinoma of the vagina in female offspring.
 
  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was used during pregnancy in the mid-20th century to prevent miscarriage and other complications.
  • In daughters exposed to DES in utero (referred to as DES daughters), there is an increased risk of developing clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina or cervix, often presenting in their late teens or early adulthood.
  • The vaginal adenosis (replacement of squamous epithelium with glandular epithelium) caused by DES exposure is a precursor lesion for this carcinoma.


Other options:
 
  1. Sarcoma botryoides: A rare embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, unrelated to DES exposure.
  2. Squamous cell carcinoma of the vagina: Typically occurs in older women, not linked to DES exposure.
  3. Basal cell carcinoma: A skin malignancy, not related to DES.



Reference: William's Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 45, 108, 424, 691.

questions.text: Identify the image given
questions.solution:
• Cystic teratoma is the most common ovarian neoplasm.
  • It consists of well-differentiated derivatives of all three germ cell layers (i.e., ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) developing as hair, muscle, teeth, or bone.
  • These tumors are generally benign but may undergo a malignant transformation in 1% to 2% of the cases.
 

Gross Morphological Features of a Mature Cystic Teratoma:

  • Cystic structure: Well-encapsulated, fluid-filled mass.
  • Contents: Hair, sebaceous material, teeth, bone, and sometimes cartilage.
  • Color: Yellowish or creamy due to sebaceous material.
  • External surface: Smooth and shiny.
  • Solid elements: May contain solid areas of cartilage, bone, or teeth.
  • Benign nature: No invasion into surrounding tissues.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition Page no 446.

questions.text: A 37-year-old multiparous, unmarried woman having regular intercourse is on OCP. Her mother had breast cancer at 50 years of age and her sister had breast cancer at 40 years of age. What is to be advised to this patient?
questions.solution:
Testing and screening recommendations for BRCA 



Since the 37-year-old female has two first-degree relatives with a history of breast cancer with one of them being diagnosed at the age of less than 50 years - she should undergo BRCA testing.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, Page no 822-825 .

questions.text: A 16 year old girl’s mother had a history of cervical cancer and she was operated for the same. What advice will be given to the girl?
questions.solution:
An adolescent girl with a history of cervical cancer in her mother (first-degree relative) is being advised counseling for prevention and/ or early identification of the same.
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is central to the development of cervical neoplasia and can be detected in virtually all cases of cervical cancer. 
  • Primary prevention of cervical cancer targets prevention of HPV infection by vaccination against HPV is the most suitable method to prevent the development of cervical cancer in the patient.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 3th Edition, Page. No- 630.

questions.text: A female presented to the gynecology OPD with a foul-smelling bloody discharge per vaginum mixed with mucus. She gives a history of multiple sexual partners. The patient is diagnosed with cervical cancer extending to the left parametrium with lateral wall involvement. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient with bloody vaginal discharge and a history of multiple sexual partners likely has persistent HPV infection, which is implicated in the etiopathogenesis of cervical cancer, which was diagnosed in this patient.
  • The management is based on the staging of the patient:
  1. Left parametrium involvement indicates that the stage of the patient is at least IIB (revised 2018 FIGO cervical cancer staging system)
  2. Since lateral wall i.e. pelvic wall invasion is seen, this indicates extension to the pelvic wall, which is most appropriately staged as stage IIIB.
  3. Stage III disease is considered locally-advanced disease, for which we administer primary chemoradiation.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 665.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Virilising tumor of the ovary?
questions.solution:
Arrhenoblastoma is also called as Sertoli- Leydig cell tumor.
It is Sex cord Stromal tumor. Seen in woman of reproductive age group.
Associated with virilisation with features of hirsutism, deepening of voice and menstrual irregularities.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th Edition, Page No 449.

questions.text: 65y old female is diagnosed to Ovarian Maligancy with Peritoneal Mets. She has a poor general condition. Which of the following would be her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Stage III Ovarian Malignancy in poor general Condition.
Ideal Treatment would be Neo adjuvant Chemotherapy [Paclitaxel+Carboplatin] followed by Debulking surgery and then three cycles of chemotherapy.


Fig: In stage IIIC, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and has spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis, such as the omentum. The cancer in the omentum is larger than 2 centimeters. Cancer may have also spread to lymph nodes behind the peritoneum or to the surface of the liver or spleen

Reference: Arora T, Mullangi S, Vadakekut ES, et al. Epithelial Ovarian Cancer. [Updated 2024 May 6]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK567760/

questions.text: Which of the following leads to an increased risk of borderline Ovarian Tumors?
questions.solution:
Risk factors for borderline Ovarian Tumors-
Low Parity
Infertility
Smoking 
Obesity.
HPE-Atypical Epithelial Proliferation without stromal invasion.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No: 732.

questions.text: Cervarix is used to vaccinate against which of the following human papillomavirus serotypes?
questions.solution:
Cervarix is a bivalent HPV vaccine that protects against HPV types 16 and 18, which are responsible for approximately 70% of cervical cancers worldwide.

  • HPV 6 and 11: Cause genital warts, targeted by Gardasil (quadrivalent or nonavalent vaccine), not Cervarix.

  • HPV 6 and 16 / HPV 11 and 18: Not correct combinations for Cervarix.

Key point:

Cervarix = bivalent vaccine for oncogenic HPV 16 and 18 to prevent cervical cancer.

questions.text: A pre-menopausal woman is diagnosed with lymph node-positive, early invasive breast cancer. IHC reveals ER +, PR +, and HER-2-neu 1+. Which of the following drug will you provide for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has ER-positive (estrogen receptor), PR-positive, and HER2-negative breast cancer.

Key points:

  • Hormone receptor-positive breast cancer:

    • Treated with endocrine therapy.

  • Pre-menopausal women:

    • Tamoxifen (a selective estrogen receptor modulator) is the drug of choice.

    • Anastrozole (an aromatase inhibitor) is typically used in post-menopausal women.

  • HER2 status:

    • HER2 is 1+, which is considered negative; hence trastuzumab is not indicated.

  • Combination therapy:

    • Not required here because HER2-directed therapy is unnecessary.

questions.text: A patient presents with an endometrial thickness of 14mm with an adnexal mass. She has a history of complex endometrial hyperplasia with the presence of atypical cells. Which of the following is likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis
This patient, presenting with endometrial hyperplasia and an adnexal mass, is likely experiencing endometrial cancer with metastasis to the ovaries.

Investigations for Endometrial Carcinoma
For patients undergoing transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) who have an endometrial echo complex (EEC) greater than 4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or non-visible EEC, endometrial sampling is a recommended next step.

Key Investigations:
1. Endometrial Aspiration Biopsy:

This is the initial investigation for abnormal uterine bleeding, particularly in women over 35 years of age.
2. Dilatation and Fractional Curettage:

Previously considered the gold standard for diagnosis, it is now less commonly used.
3. Hysteroscopy and Biopsy:

This is currently the investigation of choice for diagnosing endometrial cancer.
4. Transvaginal Ultrasound (TVUS):

Utilized as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy to provide additional information.
5. Pap Smear:

While helpful as a screening tool, it is not reliable for diagnosing endometrial carcinoma.
Follow-Up for Postmenopausal Bleeding
If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding continue, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be conducted using one or a combination of the following methods: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to?
questions.solution:
Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified as a type of epithelial cell tumor.

Epithelial ovarian tumors originate from the mesoepithelial cells located on the ovarian surface, with approximately 80% of all ovarian cancers being epithelial in nature.

Clear cell carcinoma is also referred to as a mesonephroid tumor. Histopathological examination of clear cell carcinoma reveals large cuboidal epithelial cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, which characteristically form tubules, glands, and small cystic spaces. These cystic spaces are lined by hobnail cells, which are clear cells with large dark nuclei extending into the lumen. This type of carcinoma is highly malignant.

Malignant epithelial tumors can spread extensively through transcoelomic spread. They may extend through the capsule onto the peritoneal surface, affecting the omentum, intestinal viscera, and sub-diaphragmatic space. An ascitic tap in such cases will typically show blood-stained fluid containing tumor cells. Additionally, the cancer may metastasize to para-aortic lymph nodes and other areas, including the opposite ovary, liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Which type of hysterectomy is done in a case of carcinoma cervix stage I B?
questions.solution:
• Stage IB carcinoma cervix = lesion confined to cervix, >5 mm depth or >7 mm width (but still limited to cervix).

  • Standard management:

    • Radical hysterectomy (Type III hysterectomy, Wertheim’s procedure) + bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection (for operable cases).

    • Alternatively, concurrent chemoradiation may be considered depending on operability and patient factors.

Types of hysterectomy (Piver–Rutledge classification):

  • Type I (Simple): For benign disease / CIN.

  • Type II (Modified radical): Early carcinoma cervix (IA2).

  • Type III (Radical): Stage IB & IIA (no parametrial involvement).

  • Type IV: Advanced parametrial disease.

  • Type V: Involves removal of adjacent organs, very advanced/recurrent cases.

questions.text: Where is Ovoid and tandem radiotherapy used?
questions.solution:
Ovoid and tandem brachytherapy is a combination technique where a tandem and ovoid applicators are used for radiation treatment.
A tandem is a narrow tube, that is inserted through the cervix into the uterus, while the ovoids are placed in the upper part of the vagina. Once in place, a radioactive source is introduced into both the tandem and ovoids, ensuring precise radiation delivery to the cancerous tissues. DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition • Page No: 293, 294

choices.text: Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with a smooth transition and is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination, the right adnexal mass was palpable, non-tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step?
questions.solution:
• The patient is postmenopausal, with a small (3×3 cm), smooth, non-tender ovarian cyst. Postmenopausal ovarian cysts are more concerning than premenopausal ones due to the risk of malignancy.

  • Risk factors in this patient:

    • Age >60

    • Positive family history (mother with ovarian carcinoma)

    • Use of hormone replacement therapy (slightly increases ovarian cancer risk)

Next step:

  • CA-125 measurement is a widely accepted initial evaluation for postmenopausal ovarian cysts.

  • If CA-125 is normal and the cyst is simple, small (<5 cm), regular monitoring with ultrasound is appropriate.

  • Immediate surgery is generally reserved for:

    • Complex cysts

    • Cysts >5-10 cm

    • Rapidly growing cysts

    • Elevated CA-125 or suspicious features on imaging

Other options:

  • CT scan is not routinely required for a simple cyst; USG is sufficient.

  • Exploratory laparoscopy is not indicated for small, simple, asymptomatic cysts with normal CA-125.

  • Just reassurance without CA-125 is not ideal given postmenopausal status and family history.


Reference
Berek and Novak's Gynecology 16th edition - Page nos:985

questions.text: McCall culdoplasty is done in which of the following?
questions.solution:
• McCall culdoplasty is a surgical procedure performed during hysterectomy to prevent post-hysterectomy vaginal vault prolapse.

  • It involves obliteration of the cul-de-sac (pouch of Douglas) and suspension of the vaginal cuff to the uterosacral ligaments.

  • By doing so, it provides support to the vaginal apex and reduces the risk of vault prolapse.

Other options:

  • Urethrocele repair: Involves anterior vaginal wall repair.

  • Enterocele repair: May be combined with vault prolapse repair but is not the primary indication for McCall.

  • Rectocele repair: Involves posterior vaginal wall repair.

Key point: McCall culdoplasty is specifically aimed at vault suspension after hysterectomy.



Reference:Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition page no 361

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida presented with right flank pain. MRI evaluation revealed a solid, enhancing 5x13x7 cm right ovarian mass. Salpingo-oophorectomy was successfully done and microscopic examination of the tumor cells showed a close resemblance to primordial germ cells. It was also noticed that the tumor appeared histologically identical to a testicular seminoma. Which of the following is not secreted by this tumor?
questions.solution:
The tumor described is a dysgerminoma, which is the ovarian counterpart of a testicular seminoma. Key features:

  • Occurs in young women, usually <30 years.

  • Solid, lobulated, and often unilateral.

  • Histologically resembles primordial germ cells and testicular seminoma.

  • Common tumor markers: LDH, β-hCG (in some cases), placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Not typically secreted: Sex hormones. Dysgerminomas are generally hormonally inactive, unlike some other germ cell tumors (e.g., granulosa cell tumors, which secrete estrogen, or yolk sac tumors, which secrete AFP).

So the answer is Sex hormones.



Reference: Williams gynaecology 3rd edition page no 762

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with complaints of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. A USG scan was done and is shown below. Which of the following hormonal levels need to be checked in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a hydatidiform mole, the ultrasound typically shows a “snowstorm” or “cluster of grapes” appearance with no identifiable fetus in complete moles, which correlates with the grape-like vesicles seen clinically.

So, combined with the USG findings, the next step is to check beta-hCG levels, both for diagnosis and monitoring.

FSH, LH, GnRH are not relevant in this context.



Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 240

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for Ca Cervix?
questions.solution:
Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a group of more than 200 related viruses, of which about 40 types infect the anogenital tract. HPV is the primary etiological agent for cervical cancer.

High-Risk HPV Types for Cervical Cancer

  • HPV Types 16 and 18 are the two most important high-risk (oncogenic) HPV types and are responsible for approximately 70% of cervical cancers worldwide.

  • Other high-risk types include 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, and 68, with types 31 and 33 being more commonly implicated.

    Mechanism of Oncogenesis

  • High-risk HPV types produce viral oncoproteins E6 and E7.

  • E6 protein binds to and promotes degradation of p53 tumor suppressor protein, preventing apoptosis.

  • E7 protein binds to and inactivates the retinoblastoma protein (pRb), causing uncontrolled cell cycle progression.

  • These disruptions lead to genomic instability and malignant transformation of cervical epithelial cells.

    Common High-Risk HPV Types in Cervical Cancer

  • HPV 16: Most prevalent; linked to squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma.

  • HPV 18: Second most common; associated more with adenocarcinomas.

  • HPV 31 and 33: Also recognized as high-risk types contributing to a smaller but significant proportion of cervical cancers.

    Why other options are incorrect?

  • HPV 19 and 32 are not considered high-risk types for cervical cancer.

  • HPV 32 is generally associated with benign lesions like oral papillomas.

  • HPV 19 is a low-risk or less studied type, not linked to malignancy.

    Clinical Significance

  • HPV DNA testing for types 16 and 18 is part of cervical cancer screening programs.

  • HPV vaccines (like Gardasil 9) cover HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58 (high-risk types), providing protection against most oncogenic HPVs.


Reference: Williams gynaecology 3rd edition page no 627

questions.text: The least common route of spread of vulval cancer is ____.
questions.solution:
Vulvar cancer primarily spreads through:

Route Frequency Details
Lymphatic Most common Spread to inguinal → femoral → pelvic nodes (e.g., external iliac).
Direct Common Local extension to adjacent structures like urethra, vagina, anus.
Vascular Least common Hematogenous spread (via blood) occurs late and is uncommon.
 

  • Lymphatic spread is the most important prognostic factor and guides surgical planning.

  • Vascular spread (e.g., to lungs, liver, bones) is rare and usually seen in advanced stages.



Reference:Shaws textbook of Gynaecology 16th edition page no 479

questions.text: Which is the instrument shown?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Esophageal temperature probe
 
  • Esophageal temperature probes are used to monitor core body temperatures in patients receiving anesthesia. The probe is advanced either through the nasal passage or oral cavity, before following a similar path to a nasogastric tube.
  • Other images: Pulmonary artery catheter, also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter or right heart catheter, is a balloon-tipped catheter that is inserted into a pulmonary artery in a procedure known as pulmonary artery catheterization or right heart catheterization.

   

  • NAVA catheter – Neurally adjusted ventilatory assist is a mode of mechanical ventilation. NAVA delivers assistance in proportion to and in synchrony with the patient's respiratory efforts, as reflected by an electrical signal. This signal represents the electrical activity of the diaphragm, the body's principal breathing muscle.


   



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1094.

Er A, Qureshi P, Knipe H, Esophageal temperature probe. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 18 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-94366. URL: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/oesophageal-temperature-probe?lang=us

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument in the picture?
questions.solution:
Episiotomy scissor is the name of instrument shown in the image, and it is easily recognized by the presence of an angulation.  



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 531, 620.

questions.text: What is the instrument given below used for?
questions.solution:
The Karman suction cannula used for the suction and evacuation of the abnormal fetus, miscarriage, or spontaneous abortion.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 646, 753.

questions.text: Identify the use of the following instrument-
questions.solution:
Doyen's Retractor is the illustration provided.
 
  • Obstetric uses include cesarean sections, hysterectomy, and exploratory laparotomy for ruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.
 
  • Gynecological uses include abdominal hysterectomy, Wertheim's hysterectomy, tuboplasty, sling procedure, Purandare's cervicopexy, exploratory laparotomy for ovarian tumors and myomectomy.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 751.

questions.text: What is the image mentioned below is used for ?
questions.solution:
Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used to prepare the Pap smear, as seen in the image.
 
Method: The Ayres spatula is rotated by 360° over portio vaginalis of cervix and first slide is prepared with cytobrush while second one is prepared from endocervix.



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 628, 630, 631.
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text: What tools are utilised in a PAP smear?
questions.solution:
For taking a PAP smear:
 
  • A Cusco's speculum is introduced.
  • Cervix is visualised and smear taken with the help of Ayre spatula or cytobrush.
  • Once taken, it is smeared on glass slide and immediate dipped in fixative of 95% alcohol + 5% ether.
  • Later the slides are stained in lab with papinacolou stain for identification of abnormal cells.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text: Identify the given speculum
questions.solution:
Cusco’s speculum is a self retaining, bivalved speculum used for vaginal and cervical examination.





Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 528, 529.

questions.text: Identify this tool used in PAP smears:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of Ayre's spatula.
 
  • Ayre's spatula is a medical instrument used primarily for collecting cervical cell samples during a Pap smear (Papanicolaou test). It is a flat, wooden or plastic spatula with a curved, elongated shape, designed to gently scrape cells from the ectocervix (the outer part of the cervix) to screen for cervical cancer, precancerous conditions, and other abnormalities.
 
  • In practice, it is often used in combination with a cytobrush to collect samples from the endocervix (the canal within the cervix).



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 527.

questions.text:
Which instruments are used for LSCS?
A. Green Armytage
B. Allis forceps
C. Cusco's speculum
D. Doyen's retractor
E. Karman canula
F. Shirodkar retractor
G. Scalpel
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. A, B, D, G

The instruments commonly used for Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS) include those that assist in clamping, retracting, and cutting tissue.

The appropriate set includes:
  • Green Armytage is used to hold the uterine angles to prevent excessive bleeding.
  • Allis forceps can also be used to hold the uterine edges and angles to prevent PPH
  • Doyen retractor is used to retract the soft tissue and bladder during lscs
  • Scalpel is used to give an incision.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 669, 748, 749, 751, 756, 758.

questions.text: Name the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the picture can be easily identified as an episiotomy scissor due to its angulated blades. 
 
  • Episiotomy scissors are specialized surgical scissors used during childbirth to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum (the area between the vagina and the anus) to enlarge the vaginal opening and facilitate delivery. These scissors typically have an angled or curved blade to make the cut easier and more controlled, minimizing trauma to surrounding tissues.
 
  • The curved design allows the healthcare provider to cut at the correct angle, usually mediolateral or midline, reducing the risk of tearing during childbirth and aiding in a cleaner, controlled incision.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 531, 620.

questions.text: What is the given procedure done in the labor room?
questions.solution:
The most common procedure done in a labor room is the Non-stress Test.
 
  • A non-stress test (NST) is a fetal monitoring method used to assess the baby's well-being by measuring the fetal heart rate in response to movement. It is typically performed in the third trimester, especially in high-risk pregnancies.
 
  • A reactive result, where the heart rate increases appropriately, indicates good fetal health, while a non-reactive result may require further testing. The NST is safe, non-invasive, and helps ensure the fetus is receiving adequate oxygen.
 
  • This test looks at the fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movement as a measure of fetal health.
 
  • It involves the use of Doppler to detect the fetal heart rate accelerating when the mother perceives fetal movement. 


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 123, 693, 694.
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, page no 448, 450.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Examiner of vagina and cervix is done post delivery to look for any cervical and vaginal tears using Sims posterior vaginal wall speculum.

Uses of Sim's speculum are: 
 
  • Gynecological Examinations: It is used during routine pelvic exams to visualize the vaginal walls and cervix.
  • Procedures: Sim's speculum can be employed in procedures such as Pap smears, biopsies, or the insertion of intrauterine devices (IUDs).
  • Labor and Delivery: It may also be used during labor to assess the progress of cervical dilation.

Sim's speculum is valued for its ability to provide a clear view of the vaginal and cervical areas, facilitating various gynecological assessments and procedures.






Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 528.

questions.text: Which of the following cases in the OT will you manage hysteroscopically?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy can be performed for diagnostic or therapeutic indications.
Indications
  • Suspicion of the intracavitary lesion.
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • Abnormal endometrial thickening.
  • Intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome)
  • Postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Infertility.
  • Mullerian congenital anomaly.
  • Removal of foreign bodies.
 
  1. Asherman syndrome :The role of hysteroscopy is diagnostic and also therapeutic in such patients since adhesiolysis can be performed. 
  2. Submucous fibroids require resection by the hysteroscopic approach and, this approach is a first-line approach for heavy menstrual bleeding due to such fibroids.
  3. Laparoscopic sterilization is the main method for interval (ie, sterilization not performed postpartum) female permanent contraception. 
  4. Endocervical polyps, also referred to as cervical polyps are mucous polyps that arise from the mucous membrane of the cervical canal. They are simply treated by avulsion or by torsion, to the extent that no anesthetic agent is needed for this.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 146, 212.

questions.text: Identify the instrument
questions.solution:
The image displayed is of Cusco's bivalve self-retaining vaginal speculum.



Uses:
General Clinical Examination: It is commonly used during gynecological examinations.
Cervical Smear Preparation: It facilitates the inspection and preparation of the cervix for cytology screening.
Visual Inspection: It allows for the visualization of the cervix and vaginal fornices to identify any local causes (such as polyps or ectopy) of antepartum hemorrhage (APH).
Detection of Amniotic Fluid Leakage: It can be used to detect leakage of amniotic fluid from the cervical os in cases of suspected premature rupture of membranes (PROM).
Advantage:
Self-Retaining: The design allows it to remain in place without continuous manual support, providing hands-free access for examination and procedures.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used by obstetricians:
questions.solution:
The image depicts Wrigley's forceps, classified as outlet forceps.



This instrument is lightweight, weighing about a third of the standard long-curved forceps. It is shorter in length due to the reduction in the length of the shanks and handles, featuring a pronounced cephalic curve along with a slight pelvic curve.

Criteria for Outlet Forceps Delivery:
1. Scalp is visible at the introitus without the need to separate the labia.
2. The skull is positioned at the pelvic floor.
3. The sagittal suture is aligned in the anteroposterior diameter, either in a right or left occiput anterior position.
4. The fetal head rests on the perineum.
5. Rotation of the fetal head is less than 45 degrees.

questions.text: Identify the given contraceptive device
questions.solution:
IUD - Intrauterine devices are contraceptive devices inserted into the uterine cavity. The different generations of IUDs include:
• First-generation IUDs: Inert or non-medicated devices like Lippes loop.
• Second-generation IUDs: Medicated with metallic elements like copper eg: Cu-T-220 C, Nova T, Multi-load Cu-250, Multi-load Cu-
375.
• Third-generation IUDs: Hormone-containing IUDs like Progestasert, Mirena (LNG-20).
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition • Page no: 530

questions.text: A 46-year old lady is being evaluated for abnormal uterine bleeding by a dilatation and curettage procedure. The following instruments are placed on a table in the minor operating theatre. Which of the following instruments will be used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Hegar's dilators, Simpson's uterine sound, and Sim's uterine curette are among the tools 1, 2, and 3 that are used for dilatation and curettage (D&C).

Tools utilized in D&C:
  • Sim's speculum: It exposes the cervix by retracting the posterior vaginal wall.
 
  • Rectractors of the anterior vaginal wall: These devices pull back the wall to reveal the cervix.
 
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: used to support the cervix's anterior lip
 
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is an angulated instrument that is 30 cm long, with a blunt point that is rounded at one end and a handle at the other. It is employed to gauge the uterus's length. The measuring markers that are used to identify it

There are two types of cervical dilators: Hegar's dilator, which has two ends and is used to dilate the cervix, and Hawkins' dilator.



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 966, 967.

questions.text: What is the other name for an outlet forceps?
questions.solution:
• Outlet forceps are designed for deliveries where the fetal head has reached the pelvic outlet, and the scalp is visible at the vulva.

  • Wrigley's forceps are short, slightly curved, and used for low or outlet deliveries.

  • Other forceps:

    • Piper forceps – used for after-coming head in breech deliveries.

    • Kielland forceps – used for rotational deliveries due to its sliding lock and minimal pelvic curve.

    • Das forceps – specialized forceps in some regions, not commonly used as outlet forceps.



Reference:DC Dutta's textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition page no 619

questions.text: The usage of the given device in the picture is?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Karman's cannula, which is primarily used for menstrual regulation or aspiration.

Menstrual Regulation/Aspiration
This procedure involves aspirating the endometrial cavity 1-3 weeks after a missed period in women with a previous normal menstrual cycle and a positive urine pregnancy test. 

Procedure
1. Preparation: The procedure is conducted under aseptic conditions.
2. Cervical Dilation: The cervix may be gently dilated using dilators sized 4-5 mm.
3. Insertion of Karman's Cannula: A 5-6 mm Karman's cannula is inserted and connected to a 50 ml syringe for suction.
4. Aspirating: The cannula is rotated and moved in and out with gentle strokes to ensure complete aspiration.

Uses
  • Early pregnancy termination (usually up to 9 weeks gestation)
  • Management of incomplete abortion or miscarriage
Contraindications
-Advanced Pregnancy: The procedure should not be performed if the pregnancy is advanced.
-Pelvic Inflammation: It is also contraindicated in the presence of local pelvic inflammatory conditions.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th edition page no 368

questions.text: During your internship, you notice the following instrument being used by the senior resident. The uses of this instrument include all of the following except
questions.solution:
Simpson's uterine sound is the instrument seen in the picture above. The Fallopian Tube Recanalization process does not employ it.

Keeping the device in the midline and making sure it is not forced, it is introduced into the uterine cavity while being held like a pencil with the thumb and first two fingers.

Among the uses are:

* To determine the length of the cervical cavity and uterus

* In order to identify cervical stenosis

* To sound the uterine septum, IUCD, or polyp

* In cases of Asherman syndrome, to dissolve uterine adhesions

* To distinguish between fibroid polyps and chronic inversion

Reference:Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition page no 570

questions.text: Which filter is used in a colposcope?
questions.solution:
Filter Used in Colposcopy: Green Filter

Purpose of Using Filters in Colposcopy:

Colposcopy is a diagnostic procedure used to closely examine the cervix, vagina, and vulva for signs of disease, especially after an abnormal Pap smear. The colposcope is essentially a specialized microscope with a bright light source, often supplemented by colored filters to enhance visualization

Why Use a Green Filter?

  • Enhanced Visualization of Blood Vessels:
    The green filter selectively absorbs red and yellow light, allowing mainly green light to pass through. This enhances the contrast of hemoglobin-rich structures such as blood vessels and capillaries in the cervical epithelium.

  • Better Identification of Abnormal Vasculature:
    Abnormal blood vessel patterns (e.g., punctation, mosaicism, atypical vessels) are crucial markers for detecting precancerous or cancerous lesions during colposcopy. The green filter makes these vascular patterns stand out more clearly against the surrounding tissue.

  • Improved Contrast:
    By filtering out wavelengths that cause glare or reduce contrast, the green filter sharpens the image and provides better differentiation between normal and abnormal areas.

    How the Green Filter Works:

  • The green light is absorbed differently by normal and abnormal tissues, particularly because neovascularization (new abnormal blood vessel growth) in dysplastic or cancerous lesions reflects green light differently.

  • This contrast helps the colposcopist to pinpoint areas that may need biopsy or closer examination.

    Other Filters and Their Uses:

  • Red Filter:
    Rarely used in colposcopy. It allows red light, which is absorbed by superficial vessels and may reduce the contrast needed for vascular pattern assessment.

  • Yellow and Black Filters:
    Not typically used in colposcopy; these filters serve different purposes in other types of imaging or microscopy.

    Summary:

The green filter is the preferred filter in colposcopy because it enhances the visualization of the vascular patterns of the cervix by increasing contrast, allowing for more accurate identification of potentially precancerous or cancerous lesions.



Reference:Shaws textbook of Gynaecology 16th edition page no 106
